Aroma of saccharified fruit with slight floral notes, spices, the different aromas become dominated by the yeast after pouring it in the glass. The flavor is sweet with a spicy flowery hop finish that ends fairly dry, decent bitterness.
Superb Triple, but I like it more without the yeast in the glass.

Pour out looking like the perfect Tripel.  Lots of carbonation, big head, but not over the top.  Head is light tan and thick, you can float a bottle cap on it.  Pale orange in color with a whirlwind stream of bubble rising from the center of the glass  Aroma malt and a little spice.  Lively taste with a stingy finish.  I think this might be better with age.
330 ml bottle a amber colored beer with a white head aroma fruit yeast  honey spices and some hop taste sweet spices some fruit and bitter

I drank this from a 12oz bottle into my Rochefort chalice.

This bitch pours a dark gold with a hint of orange. There is crazy carbonation with at least five fingers of off white head, that is is very pillowy. The retention is good staying several minutes with great retention. 

The aroma is on the lighter side with a little floral arrangement and a a hint of dry white wine with grass, a sauvingon blanc?

The taste is light and very smooth to drink, total session beerish. The flavor is light flowers and grass from start to finish.

The feel is nice and lasting, incredible drinkability.

This is an awesomely easy to drink tripel, especially at 10%. My only complaint is that the flavor is a light, wish there were some bold flavors that would make this world class.

Delicious.  Poured golden/orange with ample head and awesome lacing.  Flavor is huge.  Super sweet with some sour notes in there and a bitter but pleasant finish.  Booze comes through on the end but nothing overpowering.
miticaaa mad bitch!!!! il tocco inconfondibile del de dolle!! questa birra rappresenta troppo bene sto birrificio

11.2 oz bottle poured into a Duvel tulip. First DD beer Ive had that hasnt spewed foam all over the place. Not really the most attractive shade of brownish-orange, but the head on it is great. Classic tripel nose of apples and pears, with orange oil, pepper, clove, and grass. Very pleasant-smelling. Flavor is also very smooth and full, with zero alcohol presence to hinder the enjoyment. Estery up front with pears and candied orange, then a nice caramel/toffee character that takes over until the finish, which is grassy with a modest but welcome bitterness. The body is sublime on this one, perfection. The only complaint here is that it is over-carbonated. A few swirls around the glass immediately reconstitute a nice head while simultaneously getting rid of the excess bubbles. In terms of flavor and aroma this is basically the quintessential tripel. Great beer.

Pours out golden coloured with a dense white head. Flocks of yeast are floating in the glass. Hazy colour. In the nose theres orange, lemon or citrus and some fine herbs. In the mouth its a thick feeling. Also fresh with lemon. Its hoppy dry and average to much bitter. Long finish, nice. In spite of the added candy sugar the beer is more bitter than sweet. Good one.
Cloudy brown pour with a dense head. Aroma- hay, honey, caramel,  hops, esters. Flavor- Belgian yeast, sugar, hops. Somewhat complex, yet somewhat forgettable.

Bottle. Poured a cloudy amber with a fluffy white head. Nose is a bit hoppy  with some honey and Belgian yeasts. . Nicely carbonated makes and bubbly makes this feel quite refreshing. The abv is totally hidden. Not quite the classic but a nice take on the style. Some hops add an interesting twist. Finish is quite dry.
Bottle split with pat. Pours a orange gold body with slight haze and large foamy head. Aroma is typical triple, sweet malt and candi. Taste is sharp alc, with candy sweetness and malt.

Bottle. 11.2 oz. Pours light golden blonde with a thin, off-white head. Aroma of apples, pears, honey, hay, hops, and wheat. Medium bodied with a crisp, tart mouthfeel. Slow, clean finish. Good tripel.
UPDATED: OCT 21, 2010 Love this beer.  One of the best tripels I have had.  Aroma is sweet but subtle.  Full on the palate.  Great balance between the sweet and bitter.  Smooth with a great finish.

Pours a slightly hazy honey with citrus nose. Very sweet aroma slightly reminiscent of a fruited wheat. Crisp lemon flavor with a beautiful sweetness to it. The real beauty is the crisp finish
 Very neat and dry finish with balanced carbonation.

Hazy peachy pour with a light offwhite head.  Aroma is spicey yeast and a nice lemon zest.  Candied sugar and nectar fruit in the mouthful with a bit of bubblegum.  Stickiness and sweet sugary fruit in this one with a touch of booze.  I love De Dolle

Pour is hazy peach whilst the head is thin and white. The bottle gushed like a bawse. Aroma is orange citrus- like that fine fruit mist left in the air upon shooting your friend in the eye with an orange slice. Further aromas present in the form of Christmas angelfood cake, and pie dough- nunce the grain. The most modest of alpha acids are present- only enough to entice the nostrils but never overpowering or abrasive. Doughy with the quintessential De Dolle bugs. Flavor is like putting orange, lemon and grapefruit in a blender with copious sugar (of the most widely varied and stereotypical Belgian types), adding sugary lactose, and gratuitous ethanol. Baller. A yummy, spicy, sugary dough fest that kicks your ass with elegance and thorough complexity. Palate is medium to full bodied with mouth bursting carbonation, massively warming booze, and a semi-dry and sticky finish. Thanks James.

Cloudy orange pour that gushed upon opening the bottle. Aroma holds yeast, spice, wheat, lemon, grain malt, and perhaps a bit of orange and nectarine. Flavor is quite sweet, with candied sugars, wheat, spice, and some more citrus. Palate is medium bodied and stays on the tongue nicely. A really nice tripel, but not earth shattering for the style. Nonetheless, up there in the best 5 or so that Ive had so far in this genre.
Sample at Buckeye Beer Engine. Cloudy gold pour with a thin white head. Fruity nose of bananas and bartlett pear with a touch of funk. Syrupy sweet banana flavor with a bit of pepper in the finish.

Golden with dense long lasting white head and lots of visible carbonation.   The aroma is pungent from a foot away, spicy, hoppy and a bit musty.   Flavor is initially sharp but then tempers itself with candy sugar sweetness.  The mustiness is present in the flavor as well.  The sweetness is a bit cloying but the hops balance it so its not unpleasant.  A very distinctive brew, full of passion, perhaps slightly angry?   Reminds me of a few ladies Ive met.

Thanks to MaxxDaddy for sharing this at Pauls homebrewing session yesterday.  Pours a hazy gold with a white head and lots of floaties scattered about.  Very pleasant aroma of yeast, citrus, spice and a little bit of funk.  The flavor is yeast with a little bit of mustiness, citrus and some spice.  Some mild funk and some faded hops also present in the flavor (I believe this bottle was four or five years old if I recall correctly). There is an underlying mild sweetness as well.  Very good.
dark golden pour TONS of carbonation and head...wonderful yeast, citrus, and spicy goodness

Tap at Redlight. Pours a dark gold with a huge white head. Aroma of apples, citrus, brown sugar and clove. Taste is tart, tangy, crisp malt with candy sugar, citrus hops. Smooth drinking with a little kick of alcohol. Absolutely the best Tripel i have ever had.

Dark golden color. A little darker than I expected for a tripel, but that excites me. Very nice and tasty looking. Big foamy head with excellent retention and lacing.

Bananas and citrus scents dominate the nose. Bret yeast notes follow close behind. Notes of clove and coriander. Sweet candy scent. Almost a hint of dark cherry.(??)

Malt, in a big way. Sweet bread mixes with candy sugar. Citrus notes. Apple, pear, peach. Nice warmth from the 10% ABV, but not overdone. A light touch of hops provide a nice bit of balance.

Feels like liquid velvet, as all of the best tripels should, IMO. Lots of tiny little bubbles help provide a smooth creamy body. Wonderful.

The overall sweetness, what with the malts and candy sugars, combined with the high ABV would keep this one in my special occasion category. Not that multiples couldnt be consumed, its just more special than that.

Great looking golden-blond beer with a big white head sitting on top. Aroma is yeasty, malty and slight peppery with hints of green hops and herbs. You can also spot some honey and some higher alc components in the nose. Taste is very present for a Belgian blond, it has a nice peppery bite with a Duvel like taste. A full bodied golden-blond beer with a nice dry malty touch and a body warming alc feeling. A great heavy Belgian Blond.

33cl bottle. Pours clear yellow with a big foamy white head. Nose is fruity yeast, spicy. Extensive lacing. Head retention is long. Very nice looking beer until the end. Quite spicy.Quite a lot of alcohol. Taste is quite yeasty with lots of spices and quite a lot of alcohol. Finish is spicy, yeasty and bitter. Rather dry. I like it. A bit too spicy and alcoholic for my taste.  Very well made brew. Top quality.

Definitely gives head like Hollywood Boulevard whore. It took me almost twenty minutes to pour this thing. Absolutely yummy beer with a great nose and a perfect palate... Fresh inclosed courtyard orchard scent, very intense, Palate and actual taste is the selling point on this beer. I would love to have one these every day. Awesome

Bottle. Pours a deep amber with a huge fluffy head for days, sheets and sheets of lacing. Aroma of pears, fruity, some cherry, hints of citrus and grapes, slight honey, a touch of spice over a sweet malt backbone. Fruity, spicy, a bit of alcohol, hints of cherry, vinous. Honey, drying finish with a nice spicy hop bitter finish. Lush carb, a bit hot as it warms.

Bottle from 2002. Pours a hazy golden color with a small white head. Has a fruity spicy aroma with some yeasty hints. Fruity malty spicy warming flavor with hints of yeast. Has a fruity malty spicy yeasty finish.

Bottle. 
Pours hazy orange with some floaties and a big fluffy off white head. 
It has a very nice and spicy aroma with notes of orange peel, rock candy, yeast and a hint of banana, cloves and grapes. 
The flavour is sweet with some bitterness as well and got notes of spices, yeast, malt and hops.
Very nice and complex.

A yellow - golden beer with a huge white head, very beautiful beer! Aroma is malty and fruity, with some spices for a light grassy note, but also with some light sweetness around. The taste: it is a malty beer overall. First the beer starts with a spicy, grassy, hoppy taste in the mouth, some bitterness, but very soon the light sweetness is coming to the foreground, making this a highly enjoyable soft beer to drink, with a fruity taste added. Another top beer of "De Dolle Brouwers"!

Bottle from City Beer in SF.  This is one hell of a tripel.  Bottle was a gusher, but fortunately not much was lost.  Pours hazy golden with a large white head with fairly large bubbles and good lacing.  My friend that I shared this with said, "It looks like a real beer."  Aroma is typical De Dolle yeast, bready malt, banana, apple, citrus, and spice.  Flavor is yeasty with pale malt, green apple, citrusy tartness, banana, and some Noble hops.  Palate is medium-full with lively carbonation.  ABV well-hidden, but this is definitely not a weak beer by any means.  Another great one from De Dolle.
bottle thanks to bleeng.  poured light gold with a white head.  aroma of banana, lemon, and spices.  flavor was much the same, but you could tell it had some age on it.

Bottle courtesy of bleeng. Dark cheese color pour. Lots and lots of chunks. Aroma of dry bread that has sat on the grocery shelf a day past its prime. Tastes dry and bready. Flavor has hints of sweet.

330 ml bottle - a little hair of the dog with this mad bitch this morning; mild gusher leading to huge, eggy white head once poured; dark orange with haze from the yeast residue and bubbling carbonation; musky aromas of orange, lemons, spicy sweetness, grassy hops; spice a little harsh at first with grassy, old malt kind of flavor; slight fruit and hoppy kick; pretty bitter with spice just barely trumping the sweetness; maybe get a little ginger too; just a tad too much spice for me to push it to the top
Beer tasting at wine world. The wife really dug this (not me). Too sweet for my taste and its more expensive than other better tripels?

11.2 oz bottle.  Active legs.  Cloudy golden pour with a long lasting large bubbled pure white head.  Fruity aroma of grape, sour apple, with spices and a drier hop (maybe saaz) note.  Wow, this is an excellent tripel.  Bready yeasty, nice carbonation level.  For the style, this is top notch.  Impressed!

Pours dirt-gold.  Aroma of pastries, pears, baked apples, with a little yeast to funk things up a bit.  Tastes sweet with flavors of dessert pastries, spice, grass, sugar, and grapes.  Finishes drier, but the dessert flavor lingers in an uncloying way.  Full bodied.  Nice!

(Bottle, Stockholm Beer Festival, 19 Sep 2009) Cloudy golden colour with a frothy, off-white head. Fruity, malty nose with notes of citrus peel, tropical fruit and a hint of yeast. Malty, fruity taste with tropical fruit (pineapple, mango), citrus peel and a spicy finish with a touch of yeast and warming alcohol. Full body, with some alcohol sweetness. Generous spicy bitterness. Very nice beer.
A beer that smelled good tasted good but was a bit of a gusher. The brown sugar on the nose and the flavor dominate this beer. A pretty tasty offering even with the gush.
A nose of grass, citrus and butter. Taste is buttery, salty, candylike, and with a bit too much alcohol. Maybe I shouldnt rate brews of the style tripel - I always find them boring and overrated.

Bottle. Pours hazy brownish orange with a big fluffy white head. Despite careful pouring still got lots of chunky sediment. Nose has strong aromas of yeast and orange/citrus. Flavour is complex and is quite spicy with notes of citrus, ginger, clove, dried apricot and malt. Full bodied with a long finish, its also quite dry and bitter but with a balancing sweetness that is just about right. A great beer that works on many different levels.

Large head orange pour some sediment my fault,great carbonation,aroma spicy soapy,banana,wheat,fruit,lemon,orange,sugarsweets, creamy smooth banana,clove,very plesant bitter,orange sweetness,lovely stuff,finish smooth creamy wonderful flavours,tops.

Barely chilled:Not a gusher.  Dark golden. Careful pour still releases a big fat head. Aroma is grassy hops ,phenolic,with big waves of candi sugar and malt. Fizzy,medium to thick texture.  Upfront flavors are metallic(at first-rust),peppery,lightly grassy,with big pale malt. Following are nice sweet bread,flavors and more peppery,clovey,yeast flavors. Complex finish of grassy hops,pale malt,and the yeast is a slight afterthought,though stands out in the rest of the beer. Sweet and dry.  As usual great lacing and head retention from a De Dolle product. After finishing lingering candi sugar and gummy yeast. Never really a sign of alcohol even after approaching room temp. Could drink much of this though it will sneak up on you. Up there with the best,although I have a bias for this brewery.
Ahhh cant remember much about this one...I did give it a 3.8 overall, but thats about it.

(bottle) pours a murky dark amber colour with a frothy off-white head and good lacing. very unusual aroma of citrus, powdered sugar and vanilla, peanuts, fermented cherries and balsamico. flavour is the same, with notes of grainy malts, wheat and kidney beans. medium body and carbonation with a grainy warming finish. didnt really know what to think of this.

Nice looking beer.  The nose is malty with some bourbon, I do not catch the corriander as some of the reviews note.  A thick palate, first thing is brown sugar flavor.  A very complex flavor.  Dried fruit, some alcohol, yeasty.  It lacks some bitterness, needed for balance.  Sweet clean finish.

Unfiltered straw. Uniform medium-small bubble foam. Nice retention.

Aroma sweet yet citrusy.

Strong alcohol, but softly warm. Very well balanced.

Mouthwatering prickly all over the tongue. Symphonic.

 Alcohol numbs tongue. In a nice way(!) Not my style though. Tough in the long drink.

33cl @ Ons Te Huis (@ Diest)Pours an amber colour. Nice big white head. Citrus, grassy nose. Flavor is spicy and little bit sour. Excellent finish! Very nice beer, would recommend it to everyone! I was very impressed.
Blonde beer with a foamy head. Taste is sweet and bitter. Very refreshing!
Bottle. Hazy orange pour with thick fluffy white head. Aroma is sweet, spicey and rich. Quite sweet, fruity, caramel, spicy taste. Delicious Belgian Tripel which I would drink regularly.

Bottle at PIB. Poured a hazy dark yellow with a tan head and solid lacing. Aroma was hefty on clove, pepper, candi sugar and coriander. Flavor is spicy with clove, coriander, pepper, some nice bitter citrus hop notes but balanced by candi sugar sweetness. The mouthfeel is bubbly and effervescent. Loved the beer, loved the name. Would drink again in a heartbeat.

Bottle from Brd D.
Hazy golden towards orange with loads of sediment. Fluffy creamy everlasting white head. Aroma is very spicey with notes of coriander, citrus and white candy suger. Carbonated palate. Quite bitter for a tripel with some dry hop notes and sugery sweetness and a good amount of alchohol both in the flavor and finish, which is quite warming.

(330ml bottle) Pours a murky orange with yeast at the end. Huge 4 finger head that lingers forever. Nose is extremely complex, pear, candi sugar, alcohol, dried fruit. Taste is also extremely complex. Biscuity sweet, raisins, light hops but zero bitterness (good!) with a perfect carbonation and body. The linger on the palette is absolutely delicious but towards the end of my glass it is maybe SLIGHTLY too carbonated and sweet. Probably the best tripel I have had.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs.  Pours deep orange with a good amount of haze.  An enormous frothy off white head in the tulip glass, spotty lacing.  Big nose of Belgian yeast, citrus, banana, green apples.  Flavor also held many of the same qualities, lots of apple.  Very carbonated mouth feel, light booze and tons of yeast on the finish.

Another de dolle gusher when opened. Aroma has a lot going on: cotton candy, slight citric, and signature De Dolle yeast. Taste is apples, peaches and a yeasty caramel roll taste upfront, with a middle of warm alcohol burn with a hint of bitterness. Finish is slightly dry and slightly herbaceous. Really interesting and well constructed take on a tripel.

Medium head, golden orange color.  Aroma was coriander, citrus fruit, slightly smokey, sweet, root beer candy.  Taste was yeast, spices, ginger, pepper, granny smith apples, alcohol, and a slightly bitter finish.  Very good beer and there was plenty more in there we couldnt quite figure out.

Dark orange pour with thick white head. Yeasty aroma with some apricot, lemont, citrus. Flavor is candy lemon, some earth. Almost like a lemony cough drop with a honey center. Very creamy mouthfeel with dry, yeasty finish. Absolutely coats the glass. This is pretty special for a tripel, really different for the style.

31-JUL-2009, Bottle @home.
Very light orange colour with high almost white head.
Yeast, oranges and flowers.
Honey element in the taste.
Strong, high alcohol can be felt, it is nicely warming.
Morten brought it and calls it a party beer.
Nice tripel.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2012 PFFFT!  It opens. What an aroma, almost a geueze like candy-lemon acid intensity! Pours a thick Dark gold with hints of red, active noisy white head vanishes, leaving a viscous menacing liquid. I smell lemon candy. But I said that already. It tastes very full and... lemon candy, spice, cherries and caramel and granny smith apple.. whoah what BODY... the carbonation is absolutely invisible but creamy on the tasting, VERY unique texture. Its insanely oily and sticky because I have not cooled the bottle... but there is some nice honey presence as well. Late hops presence is a bit dry-wood and herbal and grass. Weltklasse!
Tart aroma...a little in flavor with a candied balance with hints of caramel... a fun beer

Bottle. Moderate malt notes of cookie and caramel, flowers and lemon for the hops, light yeast note of barnyard, and hints of over ripe pineapple and toffee. Head is large, fizzy, slightly off-white with fair slippery lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is muddy tan with a small amount particles. Flavor starts lightly sweet and heavily acidic, then the long finish is lightly sweet, acidic and bitter. Palate is medium, oily, with a fizzy carbonation and a lightly alcoholic finish. Excellent balance and the flavors finish in this Abbey Tripel is one of the best Ive had in any beer. Whats with the friggin label?

Bottle - Num num num. Only my second bottle from De Dolle, but both have been extraordinary. The freakish woman (troll?) on the label made me think this beer would be unappetizing, but man, was I wrong! Its a nice pour, hazy amber with a huge white head and all-caps FLOATIES! Nose is honey, and sour and funky like a lambic-lite--its just toned down a bit. Theres some sweet malt in there, too. Taste is sweet and bready, and finishes with an herbal presence. Its smooth, medium-bodied, and made me want to search some more out for my cellar. At nearly $6 a bottle, I probably only afford one every three years anyways. Superb.

Watch the head...it can go wild.  Murky yellow.  Aroma is fruity and sweet.  Tastes to me like cherries and apples with tempering spices.  Alcohol presence to me was hidden well enough to hurt you with 2 or 3.

Bottle purchased at Mos while in the area for the night.  Pours a hazy tan with bubbly looking body.  Nose is a delicate grain and apple funk, wet biscuit, yeast, and candied sugars.  Taste is dominated by notes of biscuit and sugars.  The carbonation is rich and lifts up notes of caramel, spice, and yeast.   I could not detect any alchol, however that was likely because I was sipping on gold label moments before.  All in all, an outstanding trip..

Wow, this is some wild stuff.  Like many De Dolle beers this one stinks of what I would consider a flaw in other beers, yet I conceed.  Huge nose of dark apple cider, the unflitered sort.  
Honestly, this beer has apricots, some light red fruit, fresh buttered toast, and nice creaminess.  Hauntingly as familiar as Blanc de Noir Champagne, really.
Behind that is another world of fresh stone fruit and layers of exotic spice as the rambunctious CO2 expands over the palate and lets these flavors seep into every nook and cranny.  As the beer finishes a coating of spiced pears rests on the tongue with a touch of cream and a grating of fresh nutmeg.  Yes, it is complex.  Expect wild shit from De Dolle and pay the man!  95

2 year old bottle thanks to ballewblake.  murky amber with a cream head.  nose is green apples, alcohol, dried fruits and spices.  nice thickness with a flavor of caramel, dried fruits and dates.  alcohol is pretty well hidden surprisingly.

UPDATED: JUL 7, 2009 big dry cidery nose with some booze. appearnce is cloudy copper with a head that just dont quit! flavor is very spicy with another large dose of booze that almost causes a cringe at the first sip and a grin a few further down the line.  very dry as predicted by the nose. powerful tripel, beware!

Bottle 33cl from crackedkettle.com. It pours  a murky golden beer with a tall white head. Cork, melon and grape in the nose. Really true to the style. Grape, white bread, coriander, melon, cork, orange and earthy hops showing up in the taste. Decent bitterness. Full bodied. Long bitter finish which is reminiscent of cork and melon. A very pleasant, typical Tripel.

(bottle) a nice dark honey color with a good head.  This tastes a bit heavier than other triples, probably because Im sensing more malt.  A strong flavor of dried fruits.  Alcohol flavor is evident, but not overpowering considering 10%abv.

A ridiculous amount of gushing, even after soft handling! Rather annoying. Thick, rich honey-golden color (dirty but wonderful) and the head took years to dissipate! Aroma of pilsner malts, lemon, honey, piney hops, orange. Sweet, yet also a dry austerity in there. Sweet, strong flavor with honey and lots of fruits like cherries and apples. Big alcohol burn as well. Maybe too evident. Very interesting, though, like but then unlike any other tripel. Extreme.

Pours slightly hazy golden orange with a 2 finger fizzy white head.  Lasts for a couple of minutes.  A lot more carbonation than I thought there would be considering the cork almost blew out by itself.  Aroma is a grassy straw funk with some apples and perhaps golden raisins.  Flavor has a strong bitterness with some cotton candy sweetness.  A slight brown sugar malt.  Extremely dry with a nice warming alcohol.  Body is very rich.  A solid find while on vacation.

11.2 oz bottle.  This one was so carbonated that it began foaming over before I even got the bottle top off.  Poured a golden color with a white head so large that it overtook the actual beer.  Aroma and flavor are of many tart fruits; apples, grapes and pears.  If you like carbonation, this is the beer for you.  Although I enjoyed it, I felt something was missing overall.  Good, but a bit pricey.
A very champagne-like brew.  Excellent robust flavor with a subtle alcohol content. Hints and tastes of sour apple, fruity citrus aromas.  Great long lasting head with excellent lacing.  Good brew!
Wow a sweet malty aged Belgian ale smell. A perfect cloudy orange sunset color with lots of sediment. It is delicious, strong, and malty after 10 months of aging.

330ml bottle from grape & gourmet. pours a beautiful, slightly hazy, straw gold with a huge, soap bubble white head and great lacing. aroma is wonderful with huge, tart, fruity notes of green apple, pear, and lemon zest with notes of spiced cider, belgian yeast, and a hint of clove. flavor is delicious as well with dry, apple, pear, and green grape flavors up front, backed by slightly sweet, biscuity light malts, yeast, and cinnamon spice with, long dry, and slightly bitter finish. mouthfeel is crisp, very highly carbonated, and the 10% is barely detectable. overall, on hell of a tripel.
Bottle. Huge head with good duration. Color is hazy golden with lots of sediments. Aroma and taste are yeast, malt, fruits, citrus and caramel.

Beautiful looking beer .If this beer were a woman, it would maybe be a "Mad Bitch" but hardly a Gargoyle like that thang on the label. This was funky and wacky and darker than most Triples. The head was like foam party foam. Duvel-esqu flavours..dry with spicy,  fruity esters...then sweet caramel and floral grassy hop tangs . Complex and drinkable enuff to knock you on your ass.Classy beer.

Pours a hazy light copper brown with a gigantic fizzy and mostly lasting white head with nice lacing. Spicy and hoppy nose mixed with yeast, bread and sweet fruits. Aroma is also sweet and yeasty with a nice spicy complexity. The alchohol is sometimes a bit too much but the aftertaste rounds it off with a fruity nicely lingering bitterness.

Pours from the bottle a slightly cloudy, dark golden color with a thick, white head that fades on top of a very highly carbonated beer, so much so that there are bubble popping faster than soda. Aroma reminds me of the tartness sometimes found in a chardonnay. Aroma holds a lot of biscuit and bready notes, light citrus and spice hoppiness with some sour apple coming through toward the end.  Flavor begins with a grape and apple dry fruitiness followed by a nice biscuit malt presence and finishes with a sweet candi sugar and spicy hop note.  Alcohol is very sharp at the end but melds very well with the very dry ending of the beer.  The alcohol definitely warms your throat after the swallow. Carbonation produces a beer which is very lively in you mouth, producing  bubbles that pop exploding taste everywhere. Overall an excellent tripel and one that really represents what the style is about.

Bottle at Papago.  Great beer and a SICK tripel.  Aroma is of date and raisin at first but becomes more like even yeast and alcohol when used to it.  Flavor is thick, sweet, clean and evolves into dark fruit of a quad (oddly) as it progresses.  Very unique and tasty.

330ml Bottle:  Aroma of yeast, slight fruit nectar, light cloves, biscuity pale malts, light pear, and a hint of citrus.  Poured amber/orange in color with a large, foamy, off-white head that lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Full of small particles throughout.  Flavor is lightly sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes of yeast, pear, pale malts, hops, light cand sugar, slight honey, bitter hops, a hint of spices.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Lively carbonation.  Yeasty, slightly sweet, lightly bitter finish.  10%ABV is undetectable.

Bottle pours slight hazy light golden color with white head that lasts the entire beverage.  Aroma is belgian yeast, candi sugar, and some biscuit.  Medium mouthfeel with a lot of carbonation.  Flavor follows the nose and has sweet caramel and candi sugar, alcohol, belgian yeast, and finishes with an alcohol then biscuit flavor.  Nice brew.  Just a bit stronger than I would have liked.  An aged version of this probably mellows nicely.
Colore dorato molto vivo,schiuma scarsa e poco persistente.Aroma dolce,maltato e di vino.Sapore dolce e fruttato.Ottima tripel-
bottle, misty dark-golden liquid with lots of carbonation (and foaming when bottle was opened). smells very good, taste a litte bit too sweet. lots of fruit and some yeast and caramel. pretty good.

Bottle. A fruity and light sweet aroma, also a little bit soapy. The head is large, white and foamy, long lasting. The body is orange. The taste started light bitter, the finish is mild with a long duration. The body is creamy-lively with a lot of carbonatiion and medium strong

Top at map room.  Shared with cgarvieuk and flssmrbrewalum.  Damn good times!   Yeast, fruit, honey, bread and alcohol on the nose.  Flavor is sweet and fruity wtih good yeast notes, some honey and maybe a hint of bubblegum.  Nice.

On tap at the Brick Store.

Pours a clear yellow with a soapy white head that hangs on for ages and leaves very good lacing.

The aroma is very light with lots of light fruit, apples and pears maybe, with some sweetish pale malts.  Some lemons hang around the nose as well, though not too intrusive or tart.

The taste is a slight step up from the aroma as the sweetness kicks up a notch with light fruits still playing the major role but with some candi sugar thrown in for good measure.  The citrus comes out a bit more than the aroma and balances the sweetness of the fruits and yeast very well.

The mouthfeel is very smooth and actually pretty sticky with the fruity and sugary sweetness on the palate.

This is a fantastic beer.  Its been a while since I had one and I really forgot how good it is.  one of the better tripels out there.

Tulip poured on draft at the map room (Chicago, IL). Good time with cgarvieuk and daknole. Pours a golde slightly hazed hue with moderate white bubbly head that dissipates to a film. Aromas are sweet, honey and slight belgian yeast and good fruity esters. Taste is similar, pushing sweetness, light florals, and honey and belgian sweetness over. Pear and apple, with just faint banana. Body is good, sweetness pervails. A very good beer, just not necessarily my thing.

Bottle. Pours a translucent amber with huge head. Lots of floaties, typical of bottle conditioned ales. Lots of fruity esters on the nose, but a lot of alcohol too. On the tongue its sweet malts at first and then bitter hops on the backside. I like that. The alcohol doesnt have as strong a presence on the palate as it did on the nose. Overall this is a good brew, and id recommend it. Cool label too.

11.2oz bottle, Pours hazy gold, light cloudy white foamy head, aroma is fruity, spiced heavy alcohol, mouthfeel is fruity sweet, big, spice evident, taste complex, finish is sweet and strong, good tripel.

On Tap @ The Maproom Saturday. Love De Dolle stuff, and never got around to this on. Also love the name. Hazy yellow golden beer with creamy off-white head. Aroma is filled of bananas, apricots, yeast and notes of spices. Tastes very malty, yeasty and notes of oak. The aftertaste is hoppy, spicy and the alcoholic taste very well balanced. Nice but prefer a stronger darker belgian beer.
This is a excellent to Triple.  Fruity taste with a sweet aroma.  Leaves a nice cool feeling in your throat, fun and easy to drink.  This is a must try for everyone
Smells sweet and fruity.  Taste is fruit yeast and some spice.  This is a fine tripel.  The body is thick.  I will be trying this again.

Bottle, 33 cl.
Lovely golden colour with a nice white head. Nice fruity aroma. Tastes like gold, no serious, like citrus and other fruits and yeast.
Excellent triple. Nothing more to say.

The aroma is rather complex, you got your yeast, fruits and then some spices with some sweetness. Hops in the taste balance this out quite nicely. Excellent tripel, have to try again for a rerate to see how it stands now.

11.2oz bottle, a couple years old.  Poured brighter orangey-golden with a well-retained cap of white head.  The aroma picked up some funky pineapple and starfruit notes over a pale malt and fruity base.. subtle notes of earth, grains, and citrus as well.. came together quite delightfully!  The flavor opened with some tangy citrus and sour funk, rolling into a pale and light fruity base.. bitterness was light and grassy/floral inspired.. spices came from orange peel and coriander.. finished warm and spicy, but with an ample malty impression.  Medium-bodied with low-ish carbonation on the palate.. sweeter and a bit funky on the finish, again with excellent balance.  I need to drink more of these!

Bottle. Golden reddish coloured with a huge lacing egg white head. Aromas of passionfruit, cookies, oranges, spice and yeast. The flavour is fruity with peaches, pears and apricots. Yeast, spice and sugar aswell..

Crushed with Jakebra.  Yes, I am rating a tripel highly.  Wasnt sure the day would come either.  Nice and fruity.  A little too overly-carbonated, but its all good.  Lots of yeast and fruit flavors with a nice dry finish.  I knew this style could be good if someone did it right.

Murky golden-orange, large long lasting white head, great lacing.  The aroma is very yeasty, bretty, lots of citrus, some spice and caramel.  The flavour has some light alcohol, lots of citrus, the brett is coming out of this quite nice, very musty and yeasty, some sourness.  Yeasty and bitter mouthfeel, medium body, very high carbonation.  Finishes warming, long and yeasty.
A major gusher, not sure how the bottle didnt explode.  Showing no signs of age, fantastic stuff.
330ml bottle obtained in a trade with ClarkVV, thanks Clark.
Opened on June 21, 2008.
Vintage 2004.
Bottle. Look: Hazy orange with long lasting white head. Smell: Coriander, fruit. Taste: Bitter orange, hops, honey. Spicy dry finish. Overall: Funky tripel. Too much carbonation.

Thanks for sharing, bro!  Pours a crisp golden color with a medium white head which leaves some nice webs of lacing.  Aroma is slight yeasty funk, some citrus, and a bit of toffee and caramel.  Taste is mostly caramel, toffee, and brown sugar.  Different.

Pours an amber color with some medium off-white head.  Aroma is a bit of brown sugar, simple syrup, and light Belgian spice.  Taste is cloyingly sweet, the spice is all off,   I dont get the hype over this beer.  To me, its a mess.

Pours a pale tan. Firm head and good Belgian lace. Aroma of ripe fruit, bananas, orange, brown sugar. Great aroma. Sweetness quickly trails off to fruit, and then a tart unripe fruit bitterness. This is amazing. Its so complex, words escape me.

Tap Courtesy of Eric at Trappeze. Athens GA
Pours hazy golden with thick creamy white head, leaving light transparent lacing.
Aroma, bready with plety of fruits, candi sugar, some tart raspberry.
Taste, yeasty, very smooth and delicious, overall thick palate with several fruits fighting to be noticed. Getting some apricots, pears (giving the little tart finish) melon as well as some well placed candi sugar.
bottle, pours hazy orange, light white head.  Fruit and hop aroma.  Wonderful candied white grape flavor ending dry with a very bitter bite of hops.

pours a dark hazy yellow-gold .. great freakidy head, and phat ass lacing .. tasty and good spritz .. abv is on a perfect level, and the good and prominent bitterness is faaaantastic! ...  a well made brew, would have been shocked if it wasnt- De Dolle is always quality ... up, up and buffet! ...  quite a big tripel, enjoyable, quite bitter, recommended for a tripel hoe!!

UPDATED: FEB 23, 2009 Pours a murky unclear orange with a large off-white froth foamy head that collapses into a lovely dense froth.  Strong fruity aroma, candi sugar, whip cream, spicy.  Full lively abundantly carbonated mouthful,  gritty sugary feel.  Very sweet tasting fruity triple, citrus and cream, light toffee, strawberries, exceptionally rich, some doughy notes,  super sugary, candied peaches, confection sugar.  Somewhat corse, this bottle is about a year old... I suppose a longer aging is necessary.  Although, its not very bitter as it is now.  Intense, however, I prefer Stille Nacht.

I had this on tap at Lucky Baldwins Belgian fest

It pours a dark yellow with at thin white head. A bit yeasty with some orange and tartness.

Cloudy dirty orange with a big white head of small bubbles that has good retention and nice lacing.    Suspended yeast sediment.  Aroma is small with citrus fruit and some sour funk.  Flavor is also citrus fruit with yeast, sugar, and alcohol.  A bit of funk, as well.  A nice fruit, yeast, and alcohol aftertaste lingers.  Thick and zesty in the mouth.

Dark blond with thin foamy head. Aroma is a bit funky, bread-like and yeasty. Flavour is similar with some lively spice on the tongue (coriander, clove?). Mouthfeel is quite thiick and syrupy although overall the beer is not overly sweet.
Cloudy dark golden color with a large cream colored head. Aroma is of honey, buttermilk, dough and yeast. Taste is of yeast, brown sugar, honey and alcohol.

10 degrees Celsius. Slightly sweet tripel with a bitter undertone. Too bitter and not the finest hoptones to my opinion. Decent head, golden brown. A nice beer but not well balanced. A bit of a common tripel.

Draught at Maxs 36h of Belgium. Gold color with a white head.   The nose is yeasty, with banana and some spicy hops.   Distinctly yeasty flavor, fruity, and a lightly sweet honey flavor in the end.   Some alcohol is also noticeable, along with a spicy,earthy hop bite.   Medium bodied with medium carbonation.   A solid tripel that has a nice spicy hops quality to it.

aroma-yeast, banana, pepper/spice; light and creamy, somewhat lively palate; bittersweet/balanced flavor reflects the aroma while there is a well-hidden alcohol note; great stuff! and not mad nor a bitch.

Bottle @ De Kelk, Bruges. Pours amber to orange with yeast particles. The head is medium-sized and creamy. The aroma is fruity (orange, grae fruit), it has wine gum-like malts and sharpish spciness. Long spicy finish with fine hoppy aroma. The flavor is very complex. It has fruity maltiness and medium bitterness. The yeast gives strange, fruity aroma. There´s lost of everythig. The palate is soft, smooth and sticky bitter in the finish. A bit strange but very enjoyable beer. It has somehow cleaning and fresh effect inside the mouth.  Great stuff.

Pours murky brown with a vanishingly small white head, looks like pond water.  Nose is a revelation... sweet, caramel malts, molasses, apricot, dates, and a hint of tripel yeast spiciness at the end.  The spice hits first in the flavor, peppery and coriander. Apricot, belgian candy, dates in the middle, spice comes back at the end.  Nice, rounded, bubbly mouthfeel.  All the flavors come together in the aftertaste.  Extremely good.

Bottle. Pours hazy orange with a huge stand of off-white head. The aroma is spicy and fruity, with notes of apricot, coriander, zest, and a very pleasant floral note reminiscent of rose hips. The flavor is dry yeastiness at first sip. Then kick in some subtle spicy notes, coriander, white pepper, maybe a little bit of ginger. A smooth, fruity, dried apricot malt profile lingers in the background. It finishes dry and warm with alcohol and a very distant grassy hop note. The alcohol and spice sticks around for quite some time in the aftertaste. Pretty good beer.

Big three finger, lumpy white foam over a brown-orange body with sticky lacing.  Big spicy malty aroma, honey, dusty.  Nice fruitiness and alcohol in the taste, a bit of sourness, some spice and citrus zest in the finish.

Bottle. Hazy deep golden with a big solid yet creamy forever lasting white head. A beauty. Very fruity aroma with the Dolle yeasty notes. Banana, oranges, hops and a touch of acid. Malty and somewhat spicy flavour. Again with the Dolle yeast in front that makes this very fruity and ends up with a bitter hoppy finish. Alcohol is very well hidden. Very tasty beer!

Had a bottle of this at Maxs in Baltimore.  Poured a cloudy yellow/orange color with a big rocky head.  Aroma was citrus, lemon, lime, grapefruit with some great Belgian yeast action in the background, the barest hint of some hops and a good malt base.  Flavor was more citrus with a nice touch of light sweetness on the tongue and just a hint of bitterness.  Dominant flavors were citrus and malt with a good candi sugar kick.  Really enjoyable beer.  Love the De Dolle.
Bottle. Hazy golden body, with a huge white head. Aroma is fruity (orange), yeast. Flavor is fruity (citrus), sweet with notes of caramel, with a light alcohol finish. A quite good beer.

One of my favorite Tripels.  De Dolle always amazes me, and this is one of their top 3 in my opinion.  On draft its exquisite, and in the bottle its exquisite.

Rich tropical fruit esters rise from a chunky, straw colored liquid.  Slight funky flavors brighten the high gravity of this beer, along with an expectedly aggressive carbonation.  Mouthfeel is a little fleeting, but it quickly remedied with another pull.  Just a damn fine beer.

Bottle - Shared with MatSciGuy on brewday. Tall, rocky fluffy head that is slow to dissipate. I get strong lemony tones, dry and champagne-like - zippy in the nose! 
A tad darker that I expected, brownish and cloudy. A bit sweet with a numbing alcohol feel (nice!). Light and crisp on the toungue. A good Triple - I like this beer a lot.

Poured from an 11.2oz bottle and served in a tulip.  This beer poured a pale amber with a slight cloudiness and a thick head of foamy, beige bubbles.  Very slow to settle, and very heavy on the lace.  The aroma was made of apricot, lemon zest, sugar-coated orange peel, and some alcohol.  The flavor heavily favored dried orange peel and alcohol warmth, with some mild honey and caramel coming in at the finish.  The mouthfeel was full-bodied and creamy smooth.  Moderately carbonated with a slightly dry finish.  The aroma didnt come across as overly inviting, but the flavor was very nice, if not a little alcoholic.  Worth a try.

[Bottle] Pours a murky brownish gold with a bunch of yeasty floaties and a huge, dense, fluffy whitish head. Aroma is sweet with candi sugar, some alcohol, fruitiness, brie cheese, lemon, and other citrus. Flavor is very sweet and a bit tart. Lots of citrus, some alcohol, especially on the finish, apple. Rich, full, almost like a carbonated syrup mouthfeel. A big, actually caramelly finish that is remarkably bitter and dry for a tripel.

Murky and flakey golden with huge rocky pale head. Nose is grainy malts, liquorice spiciness, loads of yeast, alcohol and faint fruitiness. Spritzy sourish flavor with strong herbs, liquorice and alcohol, mild berries and dried fruitiness. Sugary herbal finish. Medium to full bodied, strong but smooth carbonation. No BBE found, but feels quite old and poorly kept. This way it was pretty messy, but still good.

Bottle. Cheesy and banana-y aroma. Rubber cement. The 10% is quite noticeable. Plenty sweet. Simple and mostly inoffensive. Pours a cloudy,, dark orange with plenty of floaties. Flavor has lots of alcohol. The yeast phenols lean toward the rubbery and band aid side. A hint of sweeter fruit. Not much in the way of hops. The candi sugar rears its head upon warming. Some honey and gingerbread? Medium to full bodied. Mouth filling carbonation. Slightly chalky on the tongue with a rather hot, alcoholic finish. Meh...
Hazy golen to orange in color with a nice white colored head.  Smell is fruity, almost tart, spiced, honey, and sweet.  Taste is spices, yeast, malts, some sweetness.  Decent.

33 cl bottle from Total Wine Tucson - Pours a slightly hazy golden color with a 1/2 finger thick white head.  Very light spotty lacing.  Aroma is sweet esters and alcohol.  Flavor is esters, sweetened malt, candi sugar, and spice.  Fairly smooth, but the alcohol is noticeable in the finish.  Medium to full body.  A nice beer.

Bottle. Cloudy dark yellow with floating particles and a white head. Aged malt, dust and light lemon/herbs in the nose. Flavor was sweet with notes of light caramel, lemon, grass, hay, fruity yeast character, mineral-like water and resinous bitterness. Full and round body with moderate carbonation.

UPDATED: DEC 29, 2015 bottle at ørsted, cph.
aroma of yeast, sawdust, faint sweetness. appears cloudy yellow with a white head. flavor is alcohol, yeast , faint pices. there are sevral better abbey tripel out there if you ask me. or this bottle was perhaps not at its best.(6,3,6,3,12).
33cl bottle from kihoskh, not sure about vintage, but likely quite fresh. cloudy unclear yellow with particles, giant thick smooth head. Dusty and triple like fruity aroma, very dry, belgian yeasty spicy notes, faint fruity notes like a dry saison,sweet flowery malty base, lovely aroma. Flavor is yeasty, dry, flowery, do purple flower taste make any sense, thats what i think of, the flowery sweetness is balanced by an immense drynesss and the spicy yesaty notes, all together it is not at all cloying, and an interesting brew a little sweeter than average perhaps, but super tasty and refreshing nonetheless. my first rating was way off, or a bad bottle.

Bottle.  Poured a cloudy orange color with a huge sparse white head that quickly faded and left quite a bit of lacing.  Aroma was orange and grapefruit, with something else that I can’t place.  The flavor was slightly underwhelming.  Sugar, grass and pepper with a tingly finish.  Full bodied, with good carbonation and a clean mouthfeel.  Overall I think this is a good beer, but not my favorite tripel

Brown bottle, 33 cl, best before JAN08, purchased via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savoured on December 8 2008, eye orangey caramel, lightly hazy, average effervescence, suspended matter, voluminous white head that falls and looks like foamy milk, a bit of lacing, nose yeast, banana, orange, citrusy, mouth alcohol, coriander, banana, yeast, orange, nice layer of caramel, finale in yeast and orange with a good presence  of alcohol, foamy, mildly sweet, slightly bitter, full body, rather carbonated, overall quite likable

The pour was hazy gold with a nice white head that stayed around only briefly and did not produce much lace.  The aroma was yeast, citrus, herbal, minty and corn syrup?  The flavor was of a fairly standard tripel.  Yeast, light spice and some citrus and banana flavoring.  Nice mouthfeel, well hidden alcohol.  Enjoyable.

Pours a peach colored brew with some amber, lots of fine floaties, gave a two to three finger high white foamy head, there were a few off-white bubbles, aromas of honey and sugar sweetness, some bananas and vanilla cake, faint floral and orangelemon citrus fragrances, yeast in the background, no alcohol aroma, flavor is initially sweet with some honey flavor then changes to a medium bitterness and citrus-sour at the finish, flavor of pale malt, faint light fruit, pepper and light spice, no alcohol flavor but I can feel a touch of warmth on my tongue, mouth feel is medium maybe a touch more with nice carbonation on the palate, creamy feel, a very nice tripel ale.
Tasted like caramel candy, sweet and cloying, but with a background of assorted dark fruits and spices.

UPDATED: JUN 1, 2009 Sampled from an 11.2 oz brown bottle this beer poured a murky orange-golden color with a medium sized white head that faded quickly. The aroma was strong tart pineapple. The flavor was strong sweet, tart and tangy pineapple with a sugary and yeasty undertone. The finish was long sweet pineapple. The body was full. Marvelous!

On draft at Brouwer’s. Light, hazy orange with a thick, dissipating head. Aroma is of tart citrus - oranges and grapefruit - and a bit of grapes. Definitely a blend of sweet and tart. Flavor is like a good tripel with lots of hops added - full (big!) body with herbal and citrus notes - this is definitely the thickest tripel I’ve had. Great stuff.

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2009 33 cl. Orange-golden and cloudy with a huge, enduring meringue cap that frosts the glass. Aromas of spicy pear, grape and honey. Flavors of hard fruit candy with lots of grassy resin and peppery citrus zest bittering. Light-medium body is soft, mostly dry, tongue-tingly and has some chest-warming alcohol.
Fabolous tripel with a smooth flavour with a complex blend of yeast, orange, hops and fruit. Unclear and with a ever billowing head.
UPDATED: OCT 31, 2008 bottle, @ home very complex beer great bitter after taste this golden triple rich on sugar and malt
a great tripel !!  nice orange blonde with a white head.  rich, spicy with lalcohol, strong hop, sweet caramel

Mucho Gracias to Immy for #100!  Not sure what he meant when he called it my namesake beer...

11.2 oz. bottle pours cloudy apricot color with golden highlights. Large off white head melts to a soft blanket leaving no lacing of note. Aroma is of yeasty candied apples, corriander and soggy leaves with a sour twinge. Flavor is reminiscent of spicy Tang tea (if you don’t know what it is, don’t ask), with earthy undertones of malt. Front palate is sour with a malty caramel middle and mild hoppy finish. High carbonation. Complex with a lot of different flavors. The body is medium to light. It would be interesting to pair this with a citrus marinated grilled pork loin or an earthy, not too sweet dessert like pumpkin pie.

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2008 Bottle straight from De Dolle Brouwers brewery. Its not aged so Im prepared to taste some extra bitterness and yeast. Nose is fantastic (but apparantly bottle depended (rerate)). Pours hazy orange golden blonde with a medium white head. Nose of candi sugar very distinguishable. Aromas of coriander and caramel, bread.
Very balanced in sweet- and bitterness. Alcohol rather upfront in the mouth and a bit too carbonated on the swallow.
Hazy almost amber beer. Nice lasting head. A very complex beer both in aroma and taste. Some notes of spices, fruits, alcohol and malt sweetness. A very good beer.

Rich beer from De Dolle Brouwers again...Hazy orange- amber body with a huge foamy lacing head. The aroma is spicy, complex with coriander, bitter orange, citruses, caramel and candi sugar.  Some liqueric-alcoholic perfume. The body is rich, the texture is complex and oily, flavor is spicy with liqueric alcohol, strong hop, sweet caramel but all of this parameters are well balanced. Nice hop, dry aftertaste. Strong personality, agai and again. Is there any job at De Dolle Brouwers? I will give a hand to the old woman!

330 ml. bottle into sniffer.  When I popped this it started foaming out gently and stirred up some yeasty i think because it has a very cloudy golen/yeasty tan color.  Huge creamy white head that holds and sizzles long and fades to a rocky inch-tall head and stays there (great head).  Aroma is unbelievable; I am not the biggest belgian fan, but this is the most full, delicious, complex, creamy, refreshing, and UNIQUE belgian aroma I have encountered. Hints of bannana, vanilla, soft alcohol, sugary cherries, oak, candisugar (but not overly dominating like many other belgians I have had), and more.  The flavor is good, but not as balanced.  It starts very sugary sweet (pale malt and candi sugar) with some nutty notes, which transitions slowly into a strange bitter sourness, and then about 5 seconds after swallowing fades into a great fruity and creamy finish dominated by vanilla oak and cherries.  A bit of booze on the nose, very warming on the stomach.  Medium bodied on the palate with very active carbonation that prickles the mouth.  Overall: truly astounding aroma, very unique and diverse (amorphous transforming) flavor.  Could be very interesting with age.
Pours hazy yellow with a lot of white head.  Has the tendency to bubble over.  A crisp taste, with a bit of sweetness to it.

Billowing head, hard to control.  Smells very sweet, almost like a liquid candy.  Hazy golden color.  Hoppy for a triple, can sense some spice, maybe nutmeg, and lemons. Bitter and sour finish, but the initial sweetness remains to keep it balanced.  Very good beer, will try again
Bottle thx to Noize. Golden colour, white head. Aroma has yeast and some citrus. Flavour has fruits and some spices. Finishes a bit dry, with some pleasant bitterness. This tripel is a winner.
Thanks to toncatcher for bringing this to the Alesmith line tasting on 9/26/2008. Lots of malts and cadied sugars. Very good.

Brewed in Belgium !!  Courtesy of AFI96, thanks Waylo. Pours a hazy yellow color with wonderful long lasting white head. The aroma of the abbey triple is awesome !!!  smell of candy, zesty fruit, and spices. The taste is of candy, spices, and lemons. Mouthfeel is very spritzy that ends dry !!! De Dolle make some fine beers, get some.

Suprised to see the Alc at 10%. Hidden. Interesting nose of dark butter, wood and orange carmel. Really interesting. Somewhat of an acidic mid and short finish. Still the aroma is outstanding. Almost tannic and closed. Maybe time would help this brew come around? Still very interesting. Would have been better served with friends and shared, not sure even an 12 oz bottle is for just 1 person.

330ml bottle shared with BeerGestapo, served in a stem glass. Hazy golden-yellow body topped by a lasting white head. Amazing tart lemon zest, fruity, Candi-like nose. Might be one of the best smelling non-IPA beers that I have had. Just keep on sniffing it, it feels good. Taste is also very good, sugary sweetness, lemon, tangerine. Crisp dry palate making it oh so easy to drink. Another very solid brew from De Dolle.
Red/orange colored brew. Yeasty, fruity aroma. Flavor is fruity and spicy. Coriander, sweetness, yeast.

Pours a very pale golden straw color, ever so slightly darker than most tripels that I’ve seen. Big creamy white head dissipates quickly but never leaves entirely. Nose is of heavy booze, definitely not what I would have guessed for this. Reminds me of some of the super-high-gravity Dogfish Heads. Thankfully, the taste does not reflect this, but is still a very heavy tripel. The residual sugars are palpable. Definitely not as enjoyable or refreshing as a Westmalle. After about half of a glass the booziness really starts to accumulate to an annoying level. I’ll be sipping this for awhile.

What a lovely aroma of malt and sweetness with a nuance of spice. Just right for a triple.  Hazed pour of light brown to yellow brown with a nice tight bubbled head. It’s the flavor of heavy butterscotch and malt with a variety of fruit estery flavors that seals the deal.  Wow. It packs a lot of flavor in only an average (for a triple) body.  The finish is long and smooth with some hops and barely noticeable alcohol.  One of my favorite triples.
Very dark blonde colour. Stacy Top and beautifull bruseells pearls. Carbonated bubles. Tripel smeell. Sweet and tender great Beer. Thanx again to Oğuz Can Yıldırım....

(bottle) Pours hazy light brown with an off-white head.  Aroma is composed of toasted bread, pears, honey, brown sugar, sultanas, light cinnamon, with a hint of citrus peel and light alcohol which lurks underneath and rises more towards the top as the beer warms.  I think this beer smells quite similar to the Arabier.  The flavor begins with a fleeting sweetness of honey, but a subtle tartness (which intensifies as the beer warms) takes over until yielding to a finish that is bitter with some bready yeast.  The mouthfeel is thinner than I expected with some lively carbonation.  A solid beer, but I was expecting a little more flavor from this.

golden copper color with a monstrous near white head and lots of webby lacing. it’s cloudy enough with yeast to be opaque to light. highly yeasty fruity aroma... honey pears, canned/ cooked pears too, some grass and flowers, yeast, spice and some sweet pale malt. low sweetness on the palate. though i’m really glad it is in a small bottle otherwise it could get tedious. flavors of white grape juice, honey, light malty/grain, earth and yeast. dry spicy finish gets a bit floral. full bodied. soft velvety mouth feel and abundant airy carbonation. alcohol and spice really warm up the bones! very complex... this is the softest most elegant tripel i’ve had...

From a bottle from By the Bottle in Vancouver, WA--Poured a bright yet hazy orange-golden hue with a thick and dense white head.  Nose of sweet yeastiness and fruity malts.  Great mouthfeel and sparkling finish.  Tasty brew to be enjoyed with the mad beeotch in your life.

bottle.  Aroma of alcohol, fruit, yeast.  Hazy medium orange amber hue with a large foamy white head that mostly lasted and left some lace.  Flavor is sweet, earthy, and fruity.  Palate is lively and medium bodied.  Not bad but the aroma has a bit too much alcohol.

Great Tripel... Dark yellow to orange cloudy beer.  The beer is very malty and has a slight spice. Various fruit flavors (sour to sweet) depending on the temperature of the beer.  This beer was best at about 60 degrees.  Tight bubbles with light alcohol flavor (especially for 10%).  Very enjoyable beer

Hazy yellow in color with a nice white head.
Aroma of fruit and spice. Flavor is fruity, spicy malty goodness with a touch of sour in the after taste. For a 10% beer this one is very easy to drink. I’ll have another.
Bottle @ Café Gollem. Hazy yellow/amber colour, big white head, lots of carbonation. Aroma is fruity, spicy, yeast, malts, tart. Flavour is fruity sweet, yeasty, spicy and ends a bit sour.

Yellowish copper pour with a big, rocky white head and some floating sediment.  The aroma has notes of honey, white grape, citrus,spice, yeast, dust, flowers, and faint alcohol.  The flavor is sweet, dry and flowery with a faintly doughy malt backbone.  Lots of lingering, spicy European hops and alcohol on the finish.  Sticky medium body with loads of carbonation.

bottle 330m shared at One Pint Pub Helsinki
amber fizzy fruity bit sour tickling in the mouth alcohol presents esters pleasant aftertaste.

330ml bottle (One Pint, Helsinki)
Cloudy orange, small head. huge estery aroma, a little gluey. Alcoholic and fizzy palate. Rich malty body, a little bit of rubber. Heady - winey and a little alcoholic, but spookily pleasant. Too much alcohol, but otherwise a lovely brew.
Bottle, oragnish, lighter than I had anticipated, there was a citrus sour or bitter after taster which was not expected and overall I did not really like all that much.

bottle.  Pours a hazy golden color, medium white fizzy head, lots of visible active carbonation leaves a nice layer of foam that sticks around.  Aromas of  sweet candi sugar, yeasty sharpness, and some sweet fruit.  Flavors of sharp yeast and a hefty dose of booze balances with a smooth sweetness, notes of table sugar, tangerines, and sweet breads.  Palate is very crisp and sharp, booze shows up a bit much leaving something of an oily finish.
Overall: an interesting and tasty brew, but one that suffers from a couple distinct problems.
33cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, complex, balanced, cloudy, rocky head, very good brew

330ml bottle from WLV....pours a hazy golden orange brown, very bubbly with a thick white head.... aromas of sweet candied sugars, yeast, and a little mustiness....flavors of sweet candied sugar and a pretty assertive malt profile overall.  pretty full and velvety mouthfeel with quite a bit of carbonation.  very light bittering at the tail end. not bad for a tripel style ale.

33cl bottle. Pours gold with shades of yellow and light brown. The head is medium in size and off-white in color. It was difficult to pour of the sediment, so there were specks of sediment loosed into the glass. The aroma is thick and complex - vinous white raisins, thick malts, and a slight note of perfume. The flavor starts malty and sweet with heavy and delectable light-colored malts. There is a light, spicy, floral hop note that provides balance and a soft, fruity ester profile. At mid-tongue, the beer is lightly hoppy with sweet malts. The finish is dry with a nice hop bitterness to balance the malts. The mouthfeel is full, but definitely lighter than other De Dolle brews I tried this evening (Boskeun and Arabier). The carbonation is vigorous and tickles the tongue - in fact, it almost feels like the bubbles numbed the very tip of my tongue. Overall, a very malty tripel - sweet and tasty. It was not nearly as strongly hopped as I remembered - I shared a big bottle with a friend way back in 2001. That big bottle was a gusher, and it smelled and tasted very strongly of Saaz hops. This time around, it didn’t seem remotely as hoppy - but it was still quite good.

2006 Bottle. Pours with a very large, rocky, off-white head covering a hazy yellow body. Aroma of bananas, raspberries, spiceyness and yeast. Taste is a nice fruitiness, and also a bready/biscuity flavor alonh with Belgian Tripel spices. Good presence of alcohol and yeast in the taste. Dry with lively bubbles. Good stuff.

Hazy light gold with a robust white head. Aroma of peach, banana, demerra sugar and sweet yeast. On the tongue, you get a peppery spicyness at first, then candy sugar notes come through and finally some hoppiness balances it all out and makes everything awesome. An enjoyable beer.

Definite must for any Belgium fan, very distictive in every way. To me it smells and taste much more like a Saison than a triple. Obnoxiously huge stiff head, hazy yellow color. Funky barnyard smell and taste. Overall impression was standing between a bakery and a cattle farm and inhaling. Glad to try it, but I might pass next time. Don’t know the age.

My favorite of the De Dolle beers that I’ve tried.  Amber/brown color with medium white head.  Aroma is of yeast, bananas, brown sugar, and citrus.  Tastes of brown sugar, caramel apples, and cookies.  Slightly sour, bitter, and dry finish.

Bottle: Contents were very eager to make an appearance, cap off & foam flowith over. Cloudy golden w/ an off-white two finger head. Crazy flaky sediment through out: including the lacing, which is nice by the way. Aroma is citrusy clove w/ alcohol present in the background. Also sweet candy sugar. Flavor has a candied sugar sweetness w/ a malty backbone & some major alcohol warmth. Slightly bitter finish. Leaves a syrupy sweetness behind, pretty good.

Bottled sample. Gold in colour with a bit of haze and string carbonation. Aromas of pilsner malt, riesling grapes, peach, and a bit of booze. Flavor wise, it’s got that typical tripel pale malt+sugar+citrus going on, along with a nice floral component, yeast, and honey. A touch of bitterness rounds out a honey-sweet mouthfeel. Very classy.

0.33l bottle, trappist glass, amber pour, off-white foamy head.

Smell peach, hops, alcohol.  Taste hops, fruit and sweet, some spiciness with a bitter finish with quite a lot of alcohol.

The sweetness is a bit unsual in a good way, all in all very enjoyable.

12oz bottle. This one seems very promising. Pours a gorgeous amber with a perfect foamy white head. Very thick. Incredible nose of creamy caramel and tropical fruits. What an amazing smelling beer. I am expecting some serious hops but you can’t tell it from the nose. The citrus is the only hint. This is not hoppy at all? In fact this probably the best tripel I have ever had. Much in the vain of Triple Karameliet. This is so creamy on the palate. Truly amazing. Another magical creation from the masters at De Dolle. I bet this is incredible in the Reserve form. If you expect a hop bomb here, you won’t get it, this is creamy smooth. There are hops there but only for flavor the bitterness is completely overshadowed by the creamy flavor with a hint of tart. Alcohol is almost non existant. The palate is thinner than some of their others but I think thats due to the creaminess.

From bottle. Has a dry and mildly funky nose at first, bit of aged straw with a hint of lactic acidity. Mild yeasty aroma, with some lemon rind and light bubblegum. Some floral hoppiness, but faint. Hazy golden amber liquid with a foamy-pillowy off-white lacing, lasting head. Medium bodied, with medium to heavy carbonation and a distinct alcoholic warming among the fizzy quality. Starts with boozy alcoholic warmth, pilsner malt and some honey. Candi sugar sweetness and a bit of carbonic acidity. Yeasty notes with decent chalky bitterness in the finish, but still plenty of sweet and vaporous alcohol. This is one you can feel. Pear and grain, honey and wheat. Light astringent-sweet after.

Bottle.  Pours deep hazy gold with some lovely stray bits floating around and sending bubbles up to the foamy white head that sits atop.  Nose offers candied apricots, perhaps a bit of banana, some malt and burnt sugar and a fruity bread wallop (think banana bread or fruitcake, but yeastier.  Bit of a hoppy nose for a tripel, too.  Similar palate, with added distinction of an orange peel oil flavor from the hops added to the mix and a pretty big alcohol punch.  This is an excellent beer; I’d say the alcohol burn is my only real critique.  Other than that, it’s not too far from perfect.

Pours a visibly effervescent hazy golden colour with a dense, frothy white head, leaving good lacing. The nose is full of candi sugar, bubblegum yeast, orange cream, clove, apple, and noble hops. The flavour has fruity  impressions of apples, peach and passion fruit. The banana/clove complex is also present, with a spicy, dry yeast and some peppery spice in the finish. The palate is a perfect representation of how a tripple should feel, creamy, effervescent and dry. Exellent.

# 950.  Pours a hazy golden orange with a thick and creamy white head.  Unfiltered with plenty of hops floating around.  Aroma of candied sugar, clove, banana and other spices.  Taste of belgian yeast, candied sugar, banana and cloves.

2008 Bottle...upon opening, the foam shoved its way out, head takes forever to shrink...cloudy body golden in color....head is beige with brown sediment flaking the top (looks like a chocolate martini)....sediment galore in this beer, chunks I say, chunks(but they are small enough to drink)....a delicate lacing forming--clove a plentyin the aroma, also sweet candied sugar aromas...I get some sweet orange also, reminds me of the childhood jelly orange candy coated with sugar....its quite sweet on the first sip...alcohol apparent....its a little salty.....good though....making me want more sips...it has a very interesting appeal to it...orange peel finish with a bit of clove....body is medium with very low carbonation....just a bit of bubbles in the back of the throat...would like to re taste it with some age

33cl bottle courtesy of Markwise. Pours a golden caramel with a one finger white head that recedes slowly. Aroma is intoxicating and almost overpowering. Smells of candy sugar, ripe dark fruit, caramel, malt and yeast. Medium bodied with a somewhat creamy mouthfeel. Flavor is much like the aroma: intoxicatingly sweet with strong notes of caramel, toffee, apple, pear, fresh fragrant flowers and honey. Alcohol tends to come through a little especially on finish but is still not overpowering. Lingering, sweet-phenol finish. One of the best tripels we have sampled.
Bottle.  Pours a hazy orange body with a frothy white head.  Aroma is spices, some maltiness, some citrus fruit and a little etoh.  A good beer.

Thanks to Bigmmartin for sending this bottle. Pours a cloudy orange with a thick and creamy white head. The aroma is fairly sweet with apple, yeast, alcohol and sugar notes. The taste is a well balanced mix of light spices, citrus, a lot of brown sugar and other sweet candies, a nice balance between the creamy head and a dry finish. Very good. One of my favorite breweries.

(Dégusté avec french tickler) Une biere blonde avec un mince collet moyennement collant. Odeur de fluor, pommes, épices, gateau aux carottes, lime et tres fruité. Biere un peu trop carboniser. Gout sucr/ et de pommes.

Shared with Pyrozoid	 

App.: 
Lightly cloudy golden poor with a thin off-white head.

Aromas: 
green apples, pine, florine, carotte?, lime... brown sugar

Palate:
Slightly overcarbonated... perfectly balanced sweetness and bitterness... medium/full body

Flavors: 
Green apples, brown sugar... very malty

Notes: The carbonation is overwhelming palate wise... unfortunate because this beer is very good overall.

Bottle.  Pours a light golden color with darker sediment.  Smells vaguely of lemon and other citrus.  Sparkling, carbonated taste of light sweet bitterness with hints of dry orange flavor.  Very fizzy with pleasing carbonated aftertaste.  A pacifying and relaxing intoxication follows.

11.2 oz from Knightly Spirits.  This is one of my favorite Tripels.  It pours the golden yellow/ orange color with a healthy very frothy head.  The aroma is of caramel, apples (Granny Smith maybe?), I swear I smell whiskey, and sugar.  The taste is much of the same with a sweet finish that is unique.  I would definitely buy it if I could find it in more places.
Bottle. Pours cloudy orange with a beige head. Ripe apple aroma with nutmeg and caramel. Medium body. Body, flavor is spicier than the aroma with clove, nutmeg and apple. Very nice.

Bottle. Pours hazy dark gold, with a big, soft white head. Nose is honey, pears, yeast, alcohol. Taste is sweet, candy sugar with rich ripe fruit, with a spicy, yeasty finish with a restrained hop bitterness balancing out the sweetness, and more alcohol. Palate is crisp carbonation, with a nice syrupy, heavy body. Delicious beer.

Bottle 33 cl. Pours a clear golden with a big white head and a nice strong aroma of fresh picked berries, some oranges, grass and a caramellic notes. The taste is sweet and sticky with notes of overripe fruits, caramel and sugar syrup. The finish is a bit bitter and sticky sweet. A very nice tripel!

Tasted 4/28/08.  750ml from Deliliahs in Chicago.  Hazy with a golden hue.  White head.  Grassy and yeasty aromas.  Full bodied and sweet.  Butterscotch and chocolate.  Nice dichotomy of dried and fresh fruity esters.  Doughy and lemon citrus.  Absolutly fabulous!  Good burn.  So good.  So fn good.
Bottle from Market Street Wine Shop Downtown. Pours clear golden with big frothy head. GUSHER alert! Yeasty stone fruit aroma. Taste is caramel and fruitiness. Nice.

Tap at The Bavarian Lodge, Lisle, IL into 12 oz. Tulip glass.  A hazy gold-orange with a chunky white head that left magnificent Belgian lacing.  Aroma was a mega-powerful blast of malty fruitiness.  I smelled this long before the glass got to my nose.  The flavor was an absolutely crazy, yeasty, malt-fruit with a significant alcohol tingle-burn all around the palate.  The alcohol runs out in front of all things: aroma, taste, palate.  The mixture of flavors that I admittedly coudnt distinguish because it was such a menagerie were shocking at times.  Definately a sipper that left me, not a small man, mind you, a bit light-headed by the end.  Ill almost certainly try this from the bottle for the comparison and am glad to have had the rare chance to taste this from the tap.  Other than that, I may not drink this again.  It was a fun experience, but maybe too extreme a ride for my regular enjoyment.
This was really a tasty little treat.  Lots of fresh citrus fruit qualities, rinds and skins and all.  Rich and sweet maltiness, with just a bit of honey and caramel.

(An aged bottle at Pikkulintu 2008-03-04)
Golden colour, almost clear. Fruity nose with lots of malts. Taste has got lots of malts and salty liquorice aromas. Some whisky. Chocolate. Barley wine like raisin flavours.
Bottle at Ørsted Ølbar. Hazy amber/brown color, big off-white head. Aroma is fruity and sweet. Flavor is sweet, with hints of hops and yeast. Nutty finish. Great stuff!

Nose has spicy aroma with some grassy citrus and sweetness reminiscent of bubblegum. Opaque golden color with huge white head, lacing galore. Taste has citrus coupled with some bread, alcohol, a little metal, some sweet caramel. Palate kicks with alcohol. An intense and unique tripel, if thats what the bitch wants to be known as.

Pours a cloudy orange with a loose foam head. Aroma of candied ginger, alcohol, light fruit. Strong alcohol, good strong tripel, very tasty, nice and fruity and malty. Good carbonation, almost creamy. An excellent, potent tripel - thanks to Boutip for the trade!

hazy golden with tan head.  flavor is tremendous with great depth.  strong appearance of candy sugar and some spicyness with alcohol adding great depth.  probably the best tripel i can remember having

A hazy dark yellow colored beer. It has a huge white creamy head. It stays for a while, after that it leaves a nice lace on the glass. The aroma is great, sweet, bitter and fruits, like bananas, and apple. Also some hop and yeast. The taste is great too. At first its sweet and bitter. The fruits taste are there, the bananas and in the back the citrus. I think its a great beer, at a warm sunny day and  on every other day.

Bottle. Aromas of generalized light-medium fruits, orange and other citrus rind, other spices, got some ginger somewhere in there. Flavor brings out the tripel bitterness, alcohol, and is perhaps spicier and less fruity than the nose. Got a little weird at times with the spices rubbing up against the alcohol, but nothing overwhelming. Overall a very nice tripel.

bottle - Pours hazy gold with a big white foamy head.  The aroma of of yeast, bananas, and perhaps some other fruits.  The flavor is sweet malt and fruit at first with a little spice and some mild hops.  The alcohol is somewhat noticeable and the finish is very dry.  Excellent tripel.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy dark golden color with a thick white head that persists.  Aroma of light fruit.  Flavor of light fruits, gumdrops, rind, spices.  Initial sip is nice and fruity, but the swallows got some bite!  A heavy tripel, really warms your mouth.  One of the better tripels Ive had, although Im not particularly a fan of the style.
Heavy hoppy aroma. Huge, creamy, white head. Excellent lacing. Cloudy orange body. Moderate bitter flavor. Medium to full palate.

UPDATED: MAY 4, 2008 bottle poured into a tulip glass has a orange amber color with lots of fine brown sediment and a beautiful thick one finger white brown head that slowly faded. aroma has figs, plumb, candy sugar, spiced yeast, and alcohol. flavor is thick and sweet with molasses, spiced yeast, fermenting fruit, and alcohol. really a sharp yeast flavor and a hearty malt go well together but virtually no trace of hops here at all.
Little hazy golden appearance with a huge thick lasting & lacing head. Really triple nose with the usual vinous/acidic dolles feature. Very ethilic, both nose and MF. Bit yeasty, spicy, dry end.

Bottle acquired through Brussels distributor via direct-to-home shipment.  Hazy, light amber w/ moderate head which quickly dissipated.  Nose of butterscotch, citrus, and fruit.  Taste dominated by butterscotch with underlying fruity notes.  Warm alcohol finish with a bit of lingering citric tartness.  As this is my first "Mad Bitch", I dont know if the diacityl effect was an intended flavor profile, or if my bottle is an aberration.  I enjoyed the beer, but am bothered by the uncertainty over whether this was a true representation of one of the worlds great tripels.  I suspect it was not.  It certainly was not a "97", at any rate.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2008 Pours cloudy orange gold with a huge foamy head.  Aroma of yeast, geass, citrus, light fruits, and spice.  Tastes much the same with a vineous quality that shines through at the end.  Finishes very smooth with a warming alcohol.  Excellent beer.  One of my favorite tripels.

Courtesy of Cheeseman, by way of Boboski. Vintage 8yrs+. Pours a cloudy copper color with a white head; lots of sediment. Aroma is mostly yeast. Tastes of aged sweet light fruits, spice, yeast, and very little hop presence. Finishes with a smooth carbonation feel, almost like champagne. Thanks Dan.
Unclear golden of color with a big cloudy white head. An nice aroma of spice, yeast, hops and fruity. A flavor of fruits, yeast, hops, sweet notes and oily texture.
A beer of joy that gives a rather sleepy feeling when drinking too much. The taste is typical for "De Dolle Brouwers" because of the choice of sugar.

bottle courtesy of thecheeseman
750ml 7-8 years old: pours a very golden with a small white head small pepper like floaties. aroma is extremely fresh smelling, amazing fresh apple, peach, pear aroma simply amazing almost cider like with a slight spice. flavour is a pungent bright spice some fresh fruit that is sweet great dry finish. just awesome.
Bottle. Creamy white excellent fully lasting head. Yellow colour. Powerfull hoppy citiric aroma. Complex. Moderate bitter flavor. Long heavy bitter nice finish. Creamy palate. Great stuff.

Bottle.  Sweet apricot/apple malt aroma with an alcohol bite.   Hazy yellow amber with giant white head.  Tart lemon initially followed by a sweet apricot/apple flavor with strong alcohol bite.   Nice - a tad harsh.

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2008 (3/6/08) Bottle shared with jerc at Trappistenhuis in Ghent. Cloudy orange with a white head. Sweetish aroma of fruits, caramel, some yeast and some hops. Sweetish flavor of malt, some caramel, yeast, lightly spiced. Medium-bodied. Good.

Pours a hazy orange/amber with a massive off-white foamy head. Leaves nice lacing. Aroma of citrus, some fruits, yeast, and a dry alcohol. Very sweet, creamy caramel at first in the flavor with a spicey, fruity middle. The fizzy citrus and alcohol dont surface until the finish, leaving a slightly bitter dryness.

Diksmuide, Belgium
On tap
Very alcohol dominated
Yeast and fruit
Nice complexity
Light fruity aroma, amazing lacing, white head. Alcohol and carbonation dominated the flavors in the palate. When it settles fruits prevail.

The Dolle Breuwers...with a crazy bitch.
Appearence like a apple-cider. The nose is light fruity, peach and something sweet. The body is round, fruity and firm and has notes of champange...though missing the bubbles.

extremely hazy tea colored pour with rocky head. nice tiny bubble make their way up with tiny yeaties at bottom of the glass. Head lasts forever. Spicey aroma, with apricot and standard issued ester profile. tart apple aromas add to the nose as well.
