Flavor is spicey strong alcohol (rubbing alcohol) some fruity ester, but booze really dominates. Moutfeel is tingly with dry boozy finish.

Cloudy orane tinged-golden pour.  Huge pillowy, tight white head.  Alcohol macerated  dried apples, peaches and apricots.  Faint traces of coriander and clove.  An exuding wonderful sweetness.  Bread, tart apples with a sharp tongue piercing  flavor.  Some honey and candy sugar.  Dried pit fruit and warming spices.  Alcohol very present on the finish, but warming and welcome.  If all Mad Bitches were like this Id take two.
Bottle. Very effervescent. Aromas and finish are pure tart apples.Sme yeastiness is also present but it remnds me a lot of a French Cidre. The alcohol is well hidden.

330ml Bottle Pours out a hazy light gold. Topped with a off white foam head. A nice aroma of sour apples and pit fruit. Tast more of the apples and some belg yeast. Very nice. A big thanks to kmeves for this one.

bottle thanks to drmatt.  Pours a hazy, faded yellow/golden color with a white head which lingered to create nice lacing.  Some residue in the glass.  Smell was of apple, raisin and yeast. taste was of yeast and apples.  Mouthfeel was medium with carbonation and a hint of alcohol.  Not a big fan of blonds or tripels.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2008 Bottle. This one was a big disappointment. I normally like tripels very much, but this one just wasn´t what I expected. On the cap an inscription said juno 08 I wonder if thats a best before date. Anyway a dark golden beer with a huge and long lasting head. The aroma begins with a little fruity notes and then just applejuice, which I don´t like in my beers. Taste of sour apples, malty and after a while just like applejuice with vodka. No sweetness at all. I guess this one was quite old, as it seems like all the interesting things has gone and lots of alcohol stands back. I think I ´ll give it another chance some other time. A real turn off.

Tasted again september 08. It was better aroma fruits, apples esters. Huge head. Sweet malty with a strong alcohol burn. Raised my rating from 2.1 to 3.1. Maybe something was wrong with the first one, but still not an especial tripel, have to say I don´t understand it´s rated so high.

Very fruity aroma, bananas, peach, apple pie, etc. Intensely sweet flavor, sticky syrupy feel and carbonated. Also somewhat creamy, in a Pannepot kind of way. In the end though, too sweet and too alcoholic for my tastes.

Fruity aroma, grapes and even vanilla. Hazy carrot colour, big biege head which disappears. Taste vanilla, malt, and not much alcohol at all. Very good long, bitter finish. Actually, the finish was more bitter than youd think: this was the first beer in the morning on a trip to tallinn. The morning after was very bitter indeed, and I blame it all on this mad bitch.
UPDATED: FEB 29, 2008 Pours golden with a large white head. Aroma of yeast and spices. Nice flavor, good palate. Very nice.

I pour the contents of the undated bottle into a tulip. It is a slightly hazy golden color. The nose is malty and spicy. 

This is one of the drier tripels I have tasted. Hints of cloves and bananas up front, followed by spices. I am not familiar with the names of spices, so I will just say that there is a lot going on here. 

The mouthfeel is creamy, and well carbonated. The drinkability is good. This beer has a very clean finish.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 08-23-2005 23:53:07

Bottle, split with after4ever. Pours a cloudy gold with a massive white head. Some funk in the aroma along with fruit, apples and flowery, grassy hops. Sweet full body. All of this plus some oxidized apples show up in the taste, which is nicely bold.

UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 Bottle. Pours a murky caramel color. An absolutely obscene amount of sediment residue is present. Looks like I shouldve been more careful with the pour. Huge billowing fluffy white cotton head. Dry lacing. Aroma of apricot, peach, banana, clove. Flavor is great. Apricot, ginger, banana, warm cider, plum, a slight chalkiness. Very drinkable, with a spicy thin-body (despite the Volkswagen-sized sediment), and well balanced. Very well made.

Been sitting on this bottle for about a year now... cant wait any longer! As far as Abbey Tripels go Im a fan of La Fin Du Monde, so thats kind of my standard. This is a textbook Tripel IMO. The palate is exceptional. It has a nice carbonation but with a silkiness that may have developed during the aging. Lots of particles. Tripels are probably my favorite type of beer to smell and this is no exception. Typical yeasty aromas with some nilla wafer. A deeper inhale reveals some alcohol and rubber cement? I enjoyed this one and its a hard one for me to find.

On tap at Maxs Belgian fest in Baltimore.  Transparent straw yellow with a slight white head ringing the glass.  Smells yeasty and floral.  Flavor is grapey with some barnyard funk, yeast and bananas.  Finish has some strong heat from the alcohol and some bitterness.  Solid, but nothing unexpected.

330. Pours a cloudy buttery medium amber with a thick and billowing platinum blonde head. Intermittent starry lacing. Caramel, butterscotch, sugar, and hay on the nose. Medium, creamy, slightly fizzy body. Caramel, green apples, sugar, hay, grass, and floral notes on the mid-palate. Slight alcohol bite. Nice appley finish. Great stuff.
Draft.  Amber-orange pour with a nice white head.  Spicy and sweet aroma.  Nice sweet raisony fruity flavor on top of a spicy wheaty taste.  Hop flavor as well.  Nice

La stappo e ne esce un vulcano di schiuma che mi annaffia tutto il tavolo porca miseria; cè qualcosa che non va?! In effetti dopo averla versata in modo da limitare il danno il più possibile, pian pianino, acquista un aspetto guardabile sia fuori che dentro la bottiglia. Aroma un po caramelloso ma pungente con uno stranissimo sentore di umidiccio/marcio non so come giornali bagnati, però bagnati di succo di pera, o mela, o forse banana; il sapore è molto più "tranquillo" (o forse meno martoriato) e comincia con un dolce stemperato da un asprigno che si evolve nel piccante dellalcool. Chissà se i Sanniti bevevano una cosa del genere quando mangiavano le uova cotte nella cenere. Ottima tripel, ma secondo me questa bottiglia ha subito qualche trauma e ha qualcosa che non va... se no, sicuramente un poco inferiore alle mie aspettative. Ah menzione dovuta ai sedimenti di lievito: talmente tanti che sembra una pasta e fagioli dorata.

Dark gold color with a frothy 2" head. A yeasty banana smell took me back to the days of Redhooks Original Ale. Medium bodied and lightly carbonated. Nice taste is a yeasty, fruit centric concoction with banana, apple, and cherry flavors. Has a slight alcohol sting to finish. A tooty fruity tripel here. 1107
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Pours a cloudy orange color with lots of effervescence and a massive, brilliant white, creamy head which is mostly lasting and leaves lots of nice lace.  Nose is nice for a tripel with lots of doughy and spicy yeast notes, pear, some floral hints, and maybe some cardamon.  Flavor could be nice but is overshadowed by large amounts of candied sugar; other notes of include spicy yeast, light doughy yeast, faint pear, and some nice bitter hop notes.  Palate is nice; lively, round, creamy, and more than medium in body.  Finishes somewhat unpleasant with candi sugar, spicy notes and some bitterness lingering with some definate warmth.  Not what I was expecting with such high scores.  The nose, appearance, and palate were all good, but the overpowering candi sugar and the offputting finish just killed it.
citrus, floral, clove, bitter, long finish, lively, creamy, full body, orange,

hazy burnt gold color with a fluffy creamy head. sweet spicy yeast aroma with some fruit hop notes. soft bodied with a dense carbonation. fruity alcohol flavor of apples and pears, yeast,  a cookie dough maltiness, and a strong spiciness. full and strong flavors but balanced and surprisingly easy drinking

Poured a dark golden yellow with a huge fluffy white head that came bursting out of the bottle. Aroma is of yeast, hops and sweet fruit. Flavors of yeast and dough really come through. Body is medium with lively carbonation, almost too much, but it is still an excellent brew. Easy drinking for 10%.

Pours hazy orange with huge bits of pulp-like sediment and large fluffy white head.  Aroma is yeasty and spicy with notes of candied sugar, apple, pear, some citrus, nice floral hops.  Nice fruity flavor melds well with yeasty notes- apple, cardamon, peppery notes, some alcohol, hop bitterness.  Palate is medium-thick and oily with a dry finish.  A nice beer that makes me wish I was more of a fan of tripels.

Bottle (33 cl) at Tre små rum, Göteborg, Sweden. Hazy deep golden with a large fluffy white head. Spicy, yeasty, slightly fruity with clear notes of alcohol. Medium bodied and smooth. Good balance, quite dry.

Sampled blind at "Better Know a Style: Abbey Tripel" tasting.  Huge white heasd, straw colored to light orange amber in color.  Orange, yeast aroma with slight spice, slight green apple.  Bourbon flavor with alc, dough, malt accentuated, spice, orange, red apple.  Medium to full body with slight creaminess.  Not bad.
Bottle at 3-små rum Göteborg:hazy golden colour, with a nice head. Aroma of yeasty,citric,fruity. Flavor is almost the same here, medium body, and a nice medium fruity/Flowery finish. Nice.

Bottle. Two finger, slightly off-white head. Hazy amber body. Some flakes settling in the glass. Nose is cider-like, sweet, hints of honey, grassy hops, fruity flavors of melon and pear. Flavor has sweet malt, bitter orange, grape skin bitternss, alcohol is noticeable. Fruity esters and very mild dusty funky yeast complexity, esp. at the end. Finish is slight hop bitterness, dryness. Mouthfeel has some alcohol burn, some residual oiliness from the hops.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy dark golden color with an abundance of yeast sediment floating through the liquid.  The large off white head is mostly lasting and carbonation is persistent.  The aroma is orange citrus, alcohol, some hops, a little spice, and sweet.  The flavor has a sweet malt base with some flowery hops, orange citrus, some alcohol (although not showing 10 %),spices, and a little bitterness.  A fair amount of carbonation with a smooth mouthfeel.

(330 ml bottle from <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/maine/portland/ target=blank>Downeast Beverage Co., cellared for 10 mos. after purchase)  Sweet and fruity...Pours cloudy amber with two fingers of quite sturdy light biege head. Aroma of fruit, candyish malt, cotton candy and sherry. Mouthfeel medium-full, very lightly prickly, quite smooth. Flavor is fruity and sweet with quite a bit of sherry-like alcohol presence which actually doesnt create much of a burn. Notes of fruit, candy-malt sweetness, cotton candy and light butterscotch.

clear golden with a huge lacy white head. Aroma of grapeskin, alcohol, candy and light spice. Reasonably light, but alcoholic body, sweet and pleasant. Flavour has lots of nuts and sweet candy, with some light breadiness and alcohol (not near 10% though). A bit more fruitiness (citric) in a sweet and moderately alcoholic finish.

(33 cl bottle at 3 Små Rum, Göteborg) Shady dark golden color, white head. Yeasty spicy and alcohol scent. Yeasty, spicy, sweet and alcohol taste. Thick almost creamy mouthfeel, grows a bit in the mouth like wet paper.

Bottle @ Beer Circus Nov07. Pours orange / murky golden colour with off white head and lots of sediment at the bottom. Aroma is hoppy / grassy / spicy / citrus. Taste is sweet / apples / spice / grassy. Alcohol is well hidden so do be careful! Enjoyable beer.

[950-20071211] 330mL. Leafy grass booze hops aroma with muted toasted malt. Clear, dark orange body with a long-lasting creamy off-white head. Sweet malt boozy cookie dough yeast flavour. Medium-full body is thick. Alcohol perks up a lot, otherwise quite nice.

Bottled. Clear golden pour with microbubble head and little lace. A good amount of sedimentation as well. Plenty of carbonation that results in a slightly stingy palate. Aroma of green apple, orange citrus, pear, and coriander with ginger spice. Flavors lean towards orange peel, fruity esters and hops. Finishes with a strong warming alcohol statement with yeast. Very nice numbing mouthfeel.

Bottle at Paters Vaetje, Antwerpen. Dirty golden with a huge offwhite head. Complex perfumey hop nose with hints of grass. Sweet flavours which is immediately offset by good bitterness. Perfume, flowers and some grass on a sweet base. Solid alcohol. Fizzy. Very good.

Hazy golden with large head. Aroma has yeast, orange peel, coriander along with other spices. Sweet fruity and yeasty flavor with alcohol very present. A bit unbalanced really. Good candiate for aging.
Frothy head took a while to pour in a pint glass.  Sweet with some hops.  Absolutely no hint of 10% alcohol.  Just so nice and drinkable this beer is dangerous.

Hazy gold, champagne white head.  Nose is lemon & yeast, some hay malt, some bubblegum, unidentifiable spice and apple.  Flavor is apple, yeast, light caramel, bread, spice (clove?  cardamom? coriander?) Kinda bready, aged finish.

750ml bottle; Nose of yeast, citrus, corriander, a tiny bit of funk, and light fruits; cloudy gold with a huge, glass-lacing off white head; flavor is slightly sweet fruit, corriander, nutmeg, some slight tartness, and yeasty bread; finish still shows a small amount of hops.

sampled blind at "Better Know a Style: Abbey Tripel". pours golden with big white head. nose is yeasty, fruity, white grape, and lots of pear. flavor is very fruity, white grapes, pears, white wine, some boozy, yeasty. full body. lively carbonation. just wonderful. that de dolle yeast is pretty amazing here. this was the run away winner of the 26 total tripels at the blind tasting.

The stopped selling this in Oregon for some reason. Pours cloudy dull orange with a tall off-white head. Nose of spices, tropical fruit, bread, and apples. High carbonation keeps this beer fizzy on the palate and amplifies the spicy textures. No excess alochol present, very crisp tripel. Woody flavor towards the finish melds with the spiciness, dry and a slight grape flavor shows in the finish.
Light gold color with large off-white head and some light lacing. Aroma and flavor is of citrus and oranges with nice light malts. Some bitter hops. Great overall

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 Very much like the Oerbier but with some lemon rind and breadyness. Pleasant. Once again, that super full body and hop bite is present like in all of De Dolles Masterpieces. The beer is truly beautiful. Very yellow-copper than is so thick it looks like lemonade with thick creamer poured inside. Absolutely beautiful, nearly perfect, and among the only bear of which I will suck down a six-inch head to get to the beautiful liquid beneath with pleasure. Beautiful, pleasureful, describe this beer.

From bottle at the trappist in Oakland.  High carbonation, excellent head.  Very ripe fruit flavors, especially tangerine.  Nice bready, doughy notes in the aroma.  Extremely low hop flavor and aroma as you might expect. Nice and dry, but not bone dry.  I really enjoyed this beer.

330 ml bottle purchased at Spirits RB. Pours a brownish orange solid body with an enormous pure white super dense, rocky, frothy, large bubble having, incredible staying power showing, great lace leaving head. (Is that enough adjectives for ya) Fruity yeasty aroma with notes of apple, banana, white grapes, pine apple and sugar. Full mouth feel with rather lively carbonation and some noticable alcohol warmth on the back of your throat. Grainy bready flavor with notes of yeast and possibly a slight touch of apple but no where near as fruity or sweet as the aroma. Solid beer. Drank this while watching Live Free or Die Hard, if I wasnt trying to lose wait it would of been LIve Free and Drink Hard but Im trying to keep it to just a few beers today.
MMMMM.. Sour undertones define this tripel.  Mouthfeel is perfect.  Rather carbonated, Blonde.. definately a great beer.

Pours a cloudy yellow color with a huge yeasty head. Smell is of citrus and apples and biscuits. Taste is fruity, yeasty, dry, grassy, and bread like. Mouthfeel is dry and acidic. Finish is medium and of bread. Good trippel but I like mine sweeter.
Smells of biscuits. Custard cremas maybe? Great appearance, great taste. Made me forget about chopping wood thats for sure. Mad bitch by name, mad bitch by nature. Arent they all?

Pours a hazy orange with a dense, one finger head that lingered until the beer was gone. The nose was a heavy funky yeast, almost like what the vitamins my grandmother made me take when I was a kid mixed with dirt.  The flavor is sweet and yeasty, a lot like the nose.  The finish isnt too bad and lingers for a while, the yeast fades leaving the sweet spice that the yeast covered.  This is a well made beer from a brewery I seem to like but it doesnt seem to do it for me, it may have been because I ate shellfish earlier.

Draft: Medium sized white head when poured from the pitcher. Good retention and solid lacing. Hazy blond, coppery hued brew. Nose is spicey, grassy with some yeasty notes as well. Body is medium, well carbonated, lightly creamy. Citrus flavors, spices, light honey notes and a bit doughy, medium sweet malts and nicely fruity. Finish is fairly dry, spicey and lasting. Nice Tripel! Enjoyed @statelineliquors last Belgian tasting. 11/10/07  Thanks Robert!

33 cL bottle. Pours clear and golden orange with a crispy off-white head. Sharp alcohol and barley aroma, wineous and strong yeasty spiced. Flavour is powerfull sweet cane sugarish malty and with a subtle set of yeast spices. Finish holds a warming sugarish and alcohol dense flavour and quite warming.

Bottle shared with yespr. Pours a hazy orange colour with floaties. Big creamish good lasting white head. Aroma of alcohol, caramel, dark fruits and some yeast. The flavour is sweet with yeast, dark fruits, alcohol, some spice and bitter hops. Thanks Jesper.

The aroma was exciting with a hint of sour, that I was a little disapointed did not come through in the flavor more.  At first taste I was surprised by the sweetness that that lasted through the very pleasent warmth of the alchol.  Over all I was glad I opened this bottle to enjoy tonight.

Pours a humongoid-sized inch and a half white head over a golden body. Heavy carbonation is evident from fervent bubbles that continue tenacity. Strong yeast in the nose; past-ripe fruit and sweet honey are noted as well. Lacing coats the glass, yearning to be assimilated. Flavors include sweet grapefruit, subtle wheat, more honey, raisins, spices, mild caramel, and other fruits. Full-bodied palate, lively carbonation. The sweet, sticky palate and consistency up front is demolished in the finish with warm alcohol. Not the most drinkable, but still a great beer by a great brewery. One of the better Tripels Ive tasted.

11.2 oz bottle. Complex and engaging, this tripel moved to the top of my tripel list within three sips and remained there. Cloudy golden pour with a white, diminishing head. Big, juicy aroma of chewy fruits  grapes, cherries, raisins, plums, mango  and sweet brown sugar and malts  cookies and bread. The flavor is heavily sweet and moderately bitter. Finishes sweet, but then leaves a long, slightly bitter sensation on the tongue. Medium body and velvety texture. Slightly sticky. Pure enjoyment. Thanks Santa.

Draft at Eulogy, Philadelphia.  Deep golden with a thin top.  Sweet sugary aroma.  Drinks with that syrupy backdrop, honey, and maybe a pinch of corriander spiciness.  Fully bodied.  Delicious.  (#3182, 11/8/2007)

Hazy, yellow with white, bright head with lasting laces. Aroma is yeasty and citrusish, almost bordering on artificial lemon. Its very fruity in taste, most promenently with notes of lemon and sour green apples, it is also yeasty and spicy. The beer has a suprisingly bitter hoppy taste to it, even too much in my opinion.

11.2 oz bottle:  Hazy gold pour with a sticky white head.  The nose is initially fruity, with notes of concord grapes, black cherries, raisens and lemon.  A blanket of sweet caramel and dough lies beneath.  Almost like a fruit covered sweet danish.  The body is creamy and just as complex as the nose.  Vanilla, caramel and butterscotch are abound here.  Finishes sweet with white sugar and other caramelized sugars.  Very, very good.

(bottle): Pours a brown color. Frothy white head. Strong banana aroma, clove & spices. Some alcohol, complex aroma. Fizzy mouthfeel, spices, some banana. Clean aftertaste. Sweet and nutty. Watery as it warms up.

(33cl bottle, received from bierkoning more than a year ago) Hazy, orange coloured hue with loads of yeast-floaties and a huge, almost white frothy head. Slightly dusty, moderately sweet and fruity (citrus, apples) malt aroma with a distinctive vinous touch, accompanied by spicy herbal notes. Sweet flavour with sourish fruity accents, full bodied with a lively carbonation. Full malty body, moderately yeasty with a pleasant fruit-character (apples, grapes, citrus); sweet malty, slightly tart fruity finish with a light but balancing hoppy touch and a remarkable alcohol management. Very good !

Draft at Eulogy in Philadelphia, PA. Pour golden amber with a white head. Bold aroma of yeast, spice, and citrus. Medium bodied with a fine grainy texture. Very bold flavors of belgian pale malts and anise, with some orange mid palate. Finish is yeasty with some white pepper. Does not have that annoying overwhelming rubbing alcohol that other tripels have. Not bad, but still a sipper and a palate killer. Save this for a nitecap

Hazy orange yellow. has a white foamy head. Aroma has fruits, yeast, pepper and peach. Also some metal. Flavor is peppry, metalic, fruity and sweet. Is quite round and pleasent but has maybe to much of a harsh feeling because of the pepper flavor.

Pours a slightly cloudy gold with a nice head. The aroma is filled with spices... I notice mustard, coriander and citrus notes.  Really refreshing smell. The flavor has a lot of spice on the front, but has nice sweet and crisp finish. Very similar to the Smijse beers... if I had tasted it blind, wouldnt have pegged it as a De Dolle. But still, another excellent creation from an excellent brewery.

Mad Bitch beer chosen in honor the Mad Witch fire going on in San Diego right now.  $5 12oz bottle from Hi-Time. Big 3 finger white head head that wont die, much like the smoke from a fire.  The fire (liquid) is a yellow amber color.  Lots of little floaties (ash).   The head settles to a masterful thick creamy microbubble head with thick remnant blobs clinging to sides of the glass..  The head is a little reminiscent of Orvals head.  Aroma is a little cardboard/hay, some corriander, some orange.  Alchohol is pretty well hidden.  Kind of odd tannic bitterness that works with the beer. Leans sweet.

8/13/05 330ml. side by side with Westmalle. Hazy golden/amber with massive white head. Sweet fresh fruit and hay/grass aroma. Sruity spicy hay and orange flavor. with a strong ending bitterness. The Westmalle was a little more balanced and just a little better.

Cloudy and slightly hoppy.  Huge flavor of fruits and spices.
Oh man!  Delicious!!!  Alcohol is hidden pretty well.

Pours cloudy and coppery, with an enormous white head that last, lacing the glass beautifully.  The nose is strongly ruled by grapefruit and coriander tones followed more subtly yeast,  and sugar.  The flavor is sweet , sugary with touches of citrus and fine belgian yeast, that cover the alcohol very well.  A great tripel!

Bottle poured cloudy amber large white head. Aromas of grapfruit and spices . Sweet fruity and spicy flavors along with a alcohol warmth and a light bitter finish . Bubbly and dry on the palate . A great Tripel

Bottled: Hoppy aroma, light herbal and notes of grapefruit and alcohol. Light fruity and spicy. Hazy, dark yellow color. Extreme huge, frothy and creamy head. Sweet flavor with intensive candy notes. Fruitiness (apricot, rum-cherries) and very spicy (coriander, cloves). Alcoholic but well balanced. Dry finish, very hoppy with notes of grapefruit and citrus peel. Long herbal and bitter finish.

33 cl bottle from Bieropholie, served at just below cellar temperature in a tulip glass.
App.:  Bright orange amber with a small white froth and huge, light-coloured yeast floccules.
  
Aroma:  Lots of peach/apricot jam, citrus peel, some meaty notes, raisins and dark dried fruits, molasses/brown sugar (just a bit), very slightly woody and bright; intensely sweet.
  
Palate:  Medium body, lightly powdery, full, large effervescence.
  
Flav.:  Quite fruit, some spice and flowery, leafy hops, honey, some citrus peel; sweet, a bit bitter and fairly alcoholic (tingles in the mouth).

Mad bitch indeed...

Bottle.   Pours a cloudy amber color with a rather large pillowy, white head.   Aroma is banana, cloves, some bubble gum and pale malt.   Flavor is pepper, yeast, clove, banana, pale malts, cnadi sugar, alcohol.   Palate is medium bodied, highly carbonated, finishes warm, sweet, and doughy finish.   One of the better tripel Ive had!

Pours a cloudy orange color int the trappist glass.  There was a huge thick, creamy white head that settled into a half inch of head for the tasting.  There was a nice ringlet of lacing that crept down the glass.  The scent was of bubble gum, banana, clove, malt and yeast with some sour notes to accompany.  A huge bubbly effect on the tounge and lively carbonation.  A perfect sweetness balanced with an alcohol burn.  One of the best tripels that I have tasted.
UPDATED: FEB 6, 2010 A lovely Belgian tripel. Re-rating after so many years. Saw one today and had to have it. The carbonation is intense, but so are the flavors.

Pours a mellow orange golden with clumps of flocculated yeast and a lucious rising head that sticks around for infinity and leaves delicate lacing. As for "taste evolution" it starts off strong in the nose with dark yeast, buttery, perfumy hops, some unusual citrus.  Cantoloupe pops up on the tongue along with more dry tart yeast (seems a specialty with De Dolle), champagne effervesence, strong bitterness towards the finish, with definite alcohol presence through all stages.  Im not a huge fan of tripels, but this has enough idiosyncrasy to keep things interesting.

Bottle, from Fin. Thanks! Apricot pour, lots of ridiculously thick white head, lingering in clumps that look like you could scoop them up and use them to shave. Aroma is unapologetically strong--a big peppermint alcohol presence. Spicy pepper, brine, apricot, a little bready yeast. Tastes a whole octave lower than it smells: the pepper fire is here too, but there is a lower, dark cardamom accented malt as well. Very drinkable for such a strong beer, but warming too. Something about this makes me think of sipping good bourbon. Another well-crafted beer from De Dolle...

UPDATED: SEP 11, 2007 12oz bottle, 2004 vintage, courtesy of mj.  Thanks, Mike!  Pours a hazy, particulate-laden yellowish-amber color; white head with great retention and lacing.  Exceptionally dense aroma profile: candy sugar, yeast, and bready notes; exquisite white pepper and yeast character.  Full mouthfeel: dense, yeast and candy sugar; white pepper; slight viscosity; vanilla and toasty grains; beautifully complex and balanced.  Just awesome.  Lengthy, candy sugar and doughy finish.

Not sure of the vintage, the only date I see on the bottle is98, but Im not sure if that has anything to do with bottling date. Pours hazy golden with a massive rocky/foamy off-white head. Strong citric aroma of lemon/lime zest, a ton of yeast, and a strong overtone of caramel. Flavor is semi-sweet with a really nice note of caramel upfront that quickly gives way to a dry spicy/zesty mid-palate, some grassy/herbal hops in the finish, and an undertone of candy sugar throughout. Palate is medium, lively carbonation, dry, and full of yeast and herbaceous spice.

Truly, a winner among the many Belgian brews. Taste is rich and complex with many flavors of herbs, fruits a taste of caramel.  The Alcohol hits you hard and doesnt let you go. A must try for beer lovers

The aroma is sweet and citrusy with yeast and spice. The appearance is hazy dark gold with a large head. The flavor is like the aroma and is a little acidic. The palate is OK but the finish is soapy. This is a quality beer just not my thing.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2009 
Name: Dulle Teve Mad Bitch
Date: April 01, 2005
Mode: Bottle
Source: Brick Store Pub
Appearance: cloudy yellow, big white head
Aroma: light spicy aroma
Body: great body
Flavor: spicy and sweet flavor, rich, hint of alcohol
Overall: best tripple ever because of the great body, this mad bitch can slap me around any day

Name: Dulle Teve Mad Bitch
Date: March 20, 2007
Mode: draft
Source: brick store
Score: 3.3 to 3.4
Score: iii to ii+
Appearance: hazy yellow, dense off white head, thick lace
Aroma: sweet spicy and fruity aroma
Flavor: lots of floral and spicy hop flavor on a sweet candy malt base

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 7/10; Palate: 7/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.4/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **+/4

Bottle. Strongly citric aroma. The white head was hardly there. Golden amber color with small floaters. Medium bodied. Vigorous carbonation. Mixed flavors of citrus, light molasses, plum pits, clove, peaches, and maybe other stuff. As the sweetness slips away, there is a bitterness attributable to hops. Finally an astringency develops.  The mouth continues to tingle. There is some heat, but it is hardly noticeable against the complex flavors which seem to constantly change. Very nice.
Hazy yellow with a thick white head. Citrus and yeasty notes. Sweet, malty and some fruit. Full body with a long, warming finish.

Flaske. Kæmpeskum på denne øl. Hele glasset blev fyldt. Lidt mere rødlig end andre trippels, men ellers flot. Meget spicy syrlig smag, der ikke skjuler alkoholen på enbalanceret måde, hvilket trækker ned. Lidt skuffet, men stadig en rigtig god øl.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2010 Citrusy yeast aroma.  Sexy tall fluffy head that proudly rises out of the glass, strong carbonation.  Hazy pale golden color.  Simply amazing flavor.  The classic banana appears in peaks and valleys and is joined with caramel, plum, and cinnamon.  Once i drank 2/3 of the bottle i swirled the remaining liquid to lift up the sediment and poured the rest in the glass to turn it a shade darker toward brown.  It then became more fierce and bitter with a musty aroma, overpowering yeast flavor, and warm finish down into my chest.  Sensational.  101210  De Dolle beers continue to have an above average carbonation, never a gusher, but Im still forced to have the glass at the ready to pour quickly.  Bubble gum aroma, tropical mango burns off to become dark woodsy caramel and aggressive yeast.  Ticked it down one because these beers are a bit sharp with the carbonation.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2008 Unfortunately I did not take any detailed tasting notes when I had this at the Brugge Beertje. I put a big smiley face next to it in my notes and thats about it. Must re-rate!
 re-rate from 7-year old bottle at Merritt Island Throwdown. Cloudy, honey-gold with hazy milk-colored layer on top. Nose of fruit basket with bananas, nutmeg, and other pie spice. Detectable alcohol, grainy character, thins out in the finish. Mild, soft, chewy palate. 9-4-8-4-15 = 4.0 no changes to overall score!

11.2 oz bottle. No freshness date.
Hazy golden with a massive meringue like head. Head dissipates slowly and leaves a thick coating of lace in its path.
Aroma is sweet orange, pineapple, lemon, honey, and some spice.
Flavor starts off sweet, peaches drizzled in honey, spicy clove, bread. Finishes dry with a pleasant hoppy bitterness. Alcohol was hidden quite well.

This poured a golden yellow with a large white fluffly head that was well retained. The head left a lot of lacing all around the glass. The aroma was of sweet fruits, orange, lemon zest, spices, and yeast. The sweet fruits are upfront in the taste with peaches, oranges, and bananas. I also get some sweet malts and some caramel in there along with spices. It is medium bodied with a creamy mouthfeel that finishes clean and spicy with some alcohol warmth. This is one tasty brew that is really easy to drink especially for being 10%. All the flavors are incredibly well balanced. Another great beer from De Dolle.
UPDATED: JUN 25, 2009 33cl bottle.  Poured a golden color, definitely some banana esters in the aroma and flavor.  Good beer but not my favorite from De Dolle just due to alcohol burn/overpowering.

330ml bottle.

Pours a very cloudy golden with a massive four finger head that takes a good ten minutes to fade to a thick cap. The remaining foam leaves behind a ton of lace on the glass.

Snell; it took a while before I could get a goof whiff of this one with the huge head. Once it settles though there was a bunch of tropical fruits with pineapple, tangerine and peaches. Theres also a pretty good malty backbone in here, and a bit of a spiciness form the yeast.

Taste; the fruits are very evident with the pineapples and peaches coming through the most, but theres a really nice earthy/herbal presence that I wasnt expecting. The sweet malts come through as caramel, sugar cookies and a little honey. The finish is a touch on the spicy side from the yeast and some alcohol.

Mouthfeel is medium to full bodied with a bit of a biting carbonation, and the drinkability is good. I bought my bottle several months ago, and it took me forever to get around to it because I was a little sick of tripels at the time. Im glad I waited until now because I think I enjoyed more now than I would have when I purchased it.
user_location: Where the hell am I?, Nebraska, USA

text: pours hazy yellow with a big foamy head. big fruit aromas of banana and yeast wih a hint of spice and some tarness. taste is exciting and changes is full of changes. erathy and yeasty with sour lemons and belgian spice. easy smooth drinker at 10%. nice beer.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2008 7-8 year old update, courtesy TheCheeseMan, from boboskis cellar.  750ml bottle.  Incredible how well this brew has held up over the years.  So few brewers do Tripels well.  This is one of them.  Great beer.Rated 8/3/07.  Bottle at Redlight Redlight.  Courtesy boboski.  Cloudy yellow-orange body.  Thin white head with a prominent rim around the edges.  Minimal, spotty lacing noted.  Aroma was sweet banana, sour lemon, yeast, and coriander.  The fruity esters really almost fizz on the nose, which is quite pleasing.  The flavor incorporates all of the aromas, along with a good dose of creamy lemon meringue and a mildly dry, spicy finish.  Medium body that goes down incredibly smooth.  Great beer.
Bottel.33cl. What a head, over the top aroma of sweetnes and souer notes, and it come´s together just nice. The taste is just the same what a beer.

Very spicey and peppery.  Bitter and hoppy with an nice warm alcohol waft at the end of each sip. Nice color with a massive rocky head.  Color darkens with age and looses some of the bitter notes, so drink while it is young.
UPDATED: JUL 29, 2008 oro carico poca schiuma non molto persistente dolociastra fruttata  leggera speziata profumi intensi piuttosto alcolica in bocca abbastanza secca e abbastanza amara

Bottle: Poured a golden color with a fast acting white creamy head also as you reach the end of the bottle the sediment begins to appear. The aroma is a citrus of some sort and spicy yeast. The taste is very sweet fruity spice, there is also that yeasty taste to it as it finishes. Another fine sample by De Dolle to grace my lips.

Bottle.  Sweet aroma, yeast with lemon and orange peel, bready and full.  Angular coriander.  Pepper and apple and a touch of alcohol.  Very heavily sedimented orange-golden pour with a big soapy, fizzy off-white head.  Big, bold taste, boozy sweetness behind yeast, crème brûlée, vanilla, lemon and orange, coriander, ginger.  Loaded with fruity esters and floral spices, wildly robust and assertive.  Sweet and tart.  Full body begins crisply but smooths out, warms by the end as the rush of alcohol makes its presence known.  Er, I mean burns the throat.  Aftertaste is yeasty, bready, and somewhat dry.  Tons going on here, yet a lovely, flavorful blend seems as natural and simple as can be.  A tripel to recommend!
Bottle at Gollem. Smells fruity, sweet and gummy. Quite strong. Well hidden - at first - but eventually catches up with you. A pretty good beer nonetheless.
Pours a murky golden color. FLOATIES!!!!!!! Smell is strong, sour fruits, light malt. Taste is very good, not as sour as the smell. Crisp fruity finish. Very good, drinkable brew.

Great aroma of wheat and yeast.  Lots of particles in the beer definitely hurts the appearance.  Lots of punch to this though with a lot of flavor.  Other than the particles and being a little on the strong side for my tates this was pretty solid.
From my fall 2006 notebook.  Sweet hoppy nose on this hazy dark yellow beer.   Bread like malt body with a little bit of hops.

Hazy darker golden with sizeable quickly fading head.  Wheaty, and the Belgian yeasts are featured strongly.  Banana, light spice  aromas.  The beer had a small sour crispness with apple/sweet caramel taste to a spicey drying finish with whispers of citrus and pepper.  Considering the abv the alcohol is pretty well hidden, not a bad tripel for sure.
yellow orange lazy coloured body whit a average white head a hoppy fruity aroma a sweet fruity taste with a sweet alchoholic finich

11.2 oz bottle.  At least a year old.  Hazy gold with sustaining white fluff.  Sweet and sour nectarine with some duck sauce and lemon yeast.  Sudsy carb with a sharp tang.  Unripe apricot and dry woody caramel.  Alcohol comes out toward the end.  Clean finish with light citrus peel.

Pours like a typical tripel, a hazy golden orange color with a nice, low white head.  Aroma is of banana, clove, and candy sugar.  Taste is incredibly smooth, with banana, clove, malt, and candy sugar thrown in, with a nice lilting finish.  Great example of a tripel and yet another winner from De Dolle.

330ml bottle from dsnowden, thank you!
cloudy orange color, hue white head, wicked lacing on my glass. Aroma is big on pear, apple, and yeast, Flavour is much of the same. Very nice tripel., well made and VERY flavourful! nice stuff, and at 10%, wow the alcohol is VERY well hidden.

Bottle. Orange copper, huge billowy white head. Aroma is sweet and slightly sour. Alcohol aroma evident. Initial taste is strong malty sweet with notes of oxidation. Toasty bready tripel-like taste. Some honey flavors. Robust flavor here. Maybe slightly oxidized but serves to compliment the complexity toward finish. Very good.
Bottle at home ... light golden orange ... bright fruity belgian triple hop, lots of mouth fizz, orange bitter hop, lots of flavour. lovely up front but quite bitter in linger.

The color was and orange/yellow and had floating sediment.  The head was creamy, frothy, foamy, and off-white.  The aroma was fruity, playdough, a little sour, salty, and citris.  The flavor was earthy, bitter, alcoho, aged, and musky.  The palate was lively and the finish, warm.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2007 Poured a dark hazy amber. More consistency than most of the recent tripels Ive had. The head is thick, off white, quickly receding, and creamy. The aroma is sweet, slightly spicy, candyish, and a slight sourness. The flavor is very strong, spicy, dry alcohol, hot feel, Belgian sourness. The palate is warm and well carbonated and it finishes hot.

I wish the aroma of this beer was a little stronger so it would score in the fours. Aroma of alcohol and strong spice. Pour was was a murky orange with a thin little ring for a head. Taste was unlike any tripel Ive had. The spices in this beer were strong and defining. A little yeast in the background. Sour and tart finish that was a great suprise. Delicious
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Poured golden with haze, with an aroma of yeast and spices. The taste was a full frontal attack that zipped through the taste buds. Yes this beer was sweet but despite this and its strength which was also there throughout, this beer had  enough bitterness to create a super diversion and really was a classy number.
cloudy golden color with nice white head.  has a strong alcohol aroma and taste.  Nice fruity taste with a sweet finish.

pours golden with big fluffy head that sticks.  aroma is some clove, banana, pear, a little green apple, candied sweetness, ripe fruit, and some peppery hop.  taste is very spicy which consists of some clove and generous amounts of black pepper.  flavor is like a spicy banana with some candied sweetness and carbonated smooth full mouthfeel.  finish is spicy with some lingering sweetness.  another good one from de dolle brouwers.

Intens golden blond beer with the most beautiful white head on top. Aroma is strong with typical Tripple caracteristics. It has a slight dry fruity touch in the nose, it is stong and hoppy and has some hints of infuzed flowers. Taste is strong and refreshing but oh so dangerous, I drink this stuff from de fridge, when it warm up it begins comming to heavey. Nice powerful stuff from De Dolle.

Repulsive!!  I cannot believe the high overall rating of this beer.  Its completely undrinkable.  Aroma upon opening this one was alcohol, alcohol, alcohol. Taste is exactly the same, alcohol and an astringent slickness that Ive never experienced before.  Id swear that this was a bad bottle except the bar that I bought it at is one of the best beer bars on earth.  This liquid is definitely not something Id drink again...more like something Id pour on a wound!  And yeah, the $8 I spent on this doozie, made me a Mad Bitch.

Pours a hazed golden blond with a healthy, relatively dense offwhite head, thinning to a dense film.  The nose is big and sweet!  I get orange blossom honey, a little bit of cinnamon.
Not too thick, not too thin.  Low carbonation and a bit of a thinness to the body make this rather smooth.  
Again, big big sweetness.  Honey.  Dries out very quickly like a minerally white wine.  A bit of appley yeasty tartness lend this delightful balance, in accord with the noticeable alcohol.  Lends a lightness t othe palate in the finish and a warming.  Really smooth with a hint of the butterscotch diacetyl.  The finish is lingering and dry with some diacetyl and alcohol.  I cant remember having such a cloying tripel ever, but I also cant remember having such a good tripel.

Bottle in Westmalle glass.  Pours light amber with lasting head of medium density, not much lacing.  Several floaters.  Not sure what that means but its not good for appearance/presentation.  Faintly tart aroma but mostly yeast and honey-like sweetness. Flavors of honey and tobacco with some yeasty esters, very delicious but seems to have aged out the spiciness I remember.  Nice soft mouthfeel from small bead carbonation.  Overall an excellent beer, but Ive had better triples and Im sure Ive had better Dulle Teves
Bottled. Hazy oranger colour, mediumsized beige creamy head. Aroma is smooth fruits, yeast and spices. Flavour is yeasty, fruity, slightly hoppy and a bit spicy. Wellbalanced and pleasant.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2007 Bottled.Thx rlgk
Cloudy orange.
Yeasty and spicy aroma with a warm alco-feel.
Spicy flavour with citrus and pomerance. A bit too much alcohol present.

Pours a cloudy golden in color with an off white head.  Had a sweet aroma with sharp carbonation.  Can taste the alcohol when it first hits your palate, but disappears when it goes down.  I was hoping for a bit more from this with a name mad bitch and 10% alcohol.

De Kuppe, Bruges, New Years Eve. Deep amber pour with heaps of rocky froth. Lacy as grannys doileys. Sweetly fruity, unspicy snout with yeasty hints of pineapple and apricot. A bit bland and thin for the ABV. Drinks way below its strength, with a vague fruitiness. Smells better than it tastes. So-so elephant tranquiliser.
Cloudy yellow color, white head. Malty, yestyt, fruity aroma, spicy notes. Quite alot of alcohol in flavor, malty, spicy. Pepper finish and again with alittle too much alcohol.

Bottle.  $4.99 @ Holiday Wine Cellar.  

Holy crap, this is good.   Golden color.  Aroma of Bubble gum, banana and spice.   Flavor is incredible.  I really dont know how to explain it, but its that typical belgian triple yeasty flavor intensified by 20.  Delicious.  Sweet, but not overboard.    These guys must have scientists working on their yeasts.
UPDATED: DEC 1, 2007 good beer! lots of carbination pour caramel in color and a nice thin head.  I agree this beer is very herbal and the alcohol is hidden well.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2008 Bottle. A very nice and fruity beer. Also very herbal. The alcolhol taste is not there. So be aware of the strength.
Could tast it also from draft. A whole different beer. On bottle it has more body and on draft it is more subtile and complex.

Bottle @ Brugs Beertje, Brugge. A deep orange/golden colored beer. Lively body with a slight haze. Big lasting beige head. 
Aroma is like a fruit-bomb to the nose, oranges, apricots, bananas, peach, melon, apples detected... Also scents of perfume and bubble-gum. Sweet, alluring citrus in the flavor, along with pale malts, candy-suger, mild spices, noble hops and an inoffensive alcohol touch. Lingering bitterness towards the end. Very easy to drink, very smooth, and still lively and refreshing. A favorite!

Sample at Firewaters in Atlantic City. This beer pours a hazy yellow-orange color with a medium rocky white head that lasts the whole (small) glass. Large patches of lacing. The aroma consists of yeast, citrus and different spices. Medium body with sweet clove and malt flavors, along with touches of hops and alcohol. Nice fruity undertones as well. The finish is both fruity and spicy. All in all this is a solid Tripel.
Pours a murky orange with a funky head. Citrus aromas. Citrus and spice are well balanced in a beautiful beer.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2008 Medium off-white head, glowing orange-amber body.  Aroma of orange peel, sugar, licorice, clove, and dried apricot.  Intense citrusy, floral, malty flavors with hints of spices and a bit of pepper.  Flavors of sweet roasted/bready malts, candy sugar, and fresh fruit: pineapple, citrus, some light spiciness.  Everything is made even more intense by the alcohol.  Very soft, champagne-like mouthfeel.  A really intense and powerful beer.

Bottle from Kingdom Liquors Brandon, Fl. Pours a slightly hazy dark golden with a very large long lasting white head that leaves great lacing. Aroma of De Dolle yeast, citrus, light caramel, and earthy hops. Taste is the same as aroma with a very spicy and tasty yeasty goodness. Slightly sweet medium mouthfeel with good hop bitterness to balance. Alcohol is very well hidden. Another wonderfull beer from De Dolle.

Bottle. Cloudy yellow / orange color with a average frothy good lacing mostly diminishing white head. Aroma is moderate to heavy yeast, bubble gum, heavy fruity, some caramel. Flavor is moderate sweet and light acidic and bitter with a average duration. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft.

From the bottle.  With all the De Dolle ales sampled this evening, this proved to be the most unique and satisfying.  The body was backed by thick yeastiness and the flavor was smooth, strong, yet the alcohol was not very noticeable.  This would be a danger beer if it werent for the pricing.

Another winner from the masters of yeast.  Golden and very cloudy with a giant, huge, enormous head.  Aroma of yeast, malt, citrus, honey, and coriander.  Flavor was similar except the yeast was wonderful.  Alcohol was barely noticeable.  The chunks of yeast floating around are a little weird but do not interfere with taste or palate.
Cloudy golden color.  Sweety citrusy, with some alcohol peeking through.   Full bodies... very good beer.

Poured an orangish-straw color with a tall rocky white head that leaves behind some lacing in irregular swaths.  Aroma has a definite sweetness to it, but the aroma isnt a one-trick pony like most tripels.  Theres an earthy spice component akin to a saison present, but the overall aromatic impression is heavier than a saison.  Mouthfeel is thick.  Taste is slightly hot, with some spice present, and a good deal of sweet.  An interesting tripel.  Not much of the De Dolle funk present, at least in the vein of brews like Oerbier, but still a unique brew.
Bottled 33cl at Le Bier Circus, Brussels. Pours hazy pale orange. Aroma is yeast and hops. Taste is sweet, fruity and toffee. Bitter finish with notes of hops

Disappointed in this beer. I was thinking that I was buying a top quality brew when I payed a ridiculous 12$ for this beer from the local farmers market. I dont want to talk about the price again because now I am especially upset about paying that much. The beer lacked an aroma. When I did pick up on the aroma, bread, and fruits were noticeable. I liked the flavor somewhat. Tasted of bread, hops, and some undetermined fruit. The ABV is excellent, but doesnt save this beer. I loved the color, and the head accompanies you throughout your drink experience. Hopefully, no one on this website paid as much as I did for this beer. The beer I can say is good, but the flavors were not popping out at me. The flavors kind of mixed together and made it hard to determine what was what.

an orange color with a meringue head off the tap.  coriander and honey are prevalent in the nose, while caramel dominates the tastes with the hops and yeast.  light and full, crisp yet milky? good beer.

Pours a cloudy golden light copper with an extremely foamy offwhite head, leaving behind a fair amount of lacing.  Smells citrus, some barnyard hay odor, lemons, and some  hops in the background.  maybe some berries. Tastes alcohol. sweet berries, very carbonated. Lots of burning sensations in the finish and white grapes and hops.
Big frothy head, cloudy blond pour Dough, bread and a bit fruity aroma. Flavor is fruity sweet and the alcohol content is apparent. Medium body with a good creamy texture. A very drinkable tripel.
Hazy pale white a medium sized white head. The aroma is honey candi sugar and herbal. The flavor is honey, herbal, floral, candi sugar and caramel. Medium body with sparkling carbonation.

Pours a four finger, white head that quickly fades to a ring leaving a little lace. Nose is alcohol and raisins. Cloudy pale amber color. Light-medium carbonation and medium bodied. Flavor piney raisins sweet and tart with hints of alcohol.  $5.70 for a 330ml bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, Ma.
Great color and decent head.  Light citrus and a good overall balance.  Lots of hidden flavors.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2007 Sampled at Issac Newtown with stegosaurus. First off I was very dissapoint with this being that it is an average of a 3.8. Cloudy golden pour with serious carbonation.. Belgian spice/fruit and bread aroma. Bread taste with high alcohol that is not blended particually well. This was just ok for me.

Re rated 12/21/07 Found it more enjoyable this time around, maybe a bad batch last time

After buying the bottle today, I poured it into a Leffe glass this evening. As I prefer not to refrigerate Belgian beers, the bottle spewed a little after I opened it. Despite a high amount of foam in the beginning, the Leffe glass permitted it to completely disappear within a minute or so. The flavor is an amazing combination of sweet spiceyness that lowers the perceived alcoholic strength. Lets say its like a Turkish Delight beer! For the US government...just call it a Mad Female Dog. Fantastic beer for our future pub in Taiwan! LEKKER!!!

Bottle.  Above average white head(mostly lasting).  Murky orange in color.  Good lacing.  Bubble gum and spices, prunes with some light citrus in the aroma.  Strong complex flavors-initially sweet and finishes sweet as well.  Something sweetly bitter in the aftertaste that is not all that pleasant.  Long duration.  Light to medium bodied.  Dry textured.  Fizzy carbonation.  Alcohol is hidden well.

Deep orange color, big head. Aroma of honey and citrus and hops. Sweet, sipcy and soupy--and some orange peel esters, like in the brewers Arabier and Boskeun. Sweetness melds with some dry bitterness and alcohol at the end. Not quite balanced, but fun.

September 11. 2005. Indian summer evening, the fire roar in our outdoor fireplace, the dogs snore around us, the last clutch of the barnswallow babies started to fly and are hunting a before-bed-snack. Mother nature is saying goodnight, the darkness comes, the moon is a giant, half orange, the stars are lit - and life isnt exactly the worst you have.... Oh, sorry, it was the rating, this was all about, wasnt it??
Its warm amber with a lot of chunky sediments. The head is huge and creamy, leaving large islands of foam and lace. The aroma has a lot of sweet fruits, among others: Oranges and tangerine. The mouthfeel is oily with a hint of alcohol warming the tongue. The flavour is like the aroma plus a lot more in a nice and complex entirety. The finish is slightly bitter with a touch of citrus. Its a nice triple, but IMO not one of the quite big ones.

Wow I was in for a big surprise. This is in my humble opinion right up there with the best Abbey Tripel that I have sampled. Initial appearance of head was huge light rocky white that mostly diminished. Body was very cloudy with moderated particles in flow. Color was golden orange. Aroma was extremely complex with an array of different notes. Cloves, overripe banana, citrus, orange peel, some spice and pepper, toffee, fruit, candies. Flavor feels medium bodied, but this is only because the alcohol is so well hidden. Texture was light dry with some alcoholic warming feeling in stomach. Nice dry and playfully sweet finish. Amazing how this beer can be 10 % and still be as easy to drink. It goes down so smooth. Unheard-of in my book!

UPDATED: NOV 26, 2013 Bottle. A hazy dark golden beer, with a gigantic, frothy, lacing, almost fully lasting white head. The aroma is moderately malty (bisciuits, toasted grain), lightly to moderately hoppy (flowers, grass), lightly to moderately yeasty (basement, dust), with notes of pear, banana, candy sugar, pepper, alcohol, honey and candied fruits. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly to moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, fairly dry and very long finish with moderate bitterness, moderately alcoholic. No wonder, this is another winner from De Dolle. Sweet, but balanced. It gets better and more complex sip after sip, and you beg for another one despite its high ABV. Best De Dolle beer?

Bottle.  Pours a hazy golden yellow with a huge thick white head.  This clings to the glass.  Very citrus like aroma with a bit of sweetness lingering.  The flavor is great.  Sweet citrus with a slightly tart finish.  This lingers well on the palate.  There is still foam residue on the glass when I finish!  Very well put together beer.

Bottle from Beer Mania. 
Lambic-like citrus smell. Big bubbles, firm head over a muddy golden ale. 
Spices - vanilla, cardamom, cloves, citrus fruit, a sweet malty base underneath this. There could be some more hops to balance this beer, as it lands on the (almost sticky) sweet side. So, a mighty fine beer, while not perfect. But they are working on it, and top score for daring to go new roads.

Bottle, 33 cl. It was a long time ago ill taste this beer. 
Dark blond to light amber color with a white head. Aroma is wheat, orange ?, yeast. Flavour is yeast, alcohol, orange, sweet, and little spices. Full body.
Taste is sweet but not too, good bitterness en dry end. The best we drunk yesterday.

Pours into a Trappist glass with a gigantic white head that leaves sudsy lace and a bright, light golden color with some sediment at the bottom.  Aroma of yeast, bread, vanilla, mild fruits.  Smell is pleasant but subdued.  Has a smooth, tingly mouthfeel with some alcohol in the taste and a little bitterness.  Good.

UPDATED: APR 25, 2008 Bottle. Golden hazy colour with a lot of sediment and very large head. Spicy flavor but too much alcohol. Nice lasting aftertaste. Much better this time. Iam more familiar with high alcohol beers.

Light fruit,slight spice and yeast dominate the aroma.Pours a hazy light copper with a large white head.Yeast and alcohol come thru in the flavor.Thin to medium mouthfeel with some strong alcohol in the finish.
Sour aroma with some sweet malt in the back.  Hazy golden yellow color sports a medium palate.  Sweet malt flavor up front with some yeast.  A unique tripel.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2007 Bottle from Uto - Amber with a Mt. Everest of a head. A strong spicy aroma of tropical fruits - apricot, dates, pineapple and passion fruit. Taste of salt, cloves, pineapple, apricot and a great deal of alcohol. This stuff is FIERCE. Complex, but well balanced. Get in, go mad!

Bottle. Pours hazy amber/copper with a massive bubbly head. Aroma is a wonderful combination of spicy yeast, cloves, banana, mild fruity notes, and a slight tartiness. Flavor is much the same, and with a slight warming finish from the alcohol.

The pour is all about the big head.  The tripel means the head is triple the size of the beer. It just grows as you pour, then grows some more.  

It is a pretty golden hazy color with little bubbles.  

The aroma is funky and fruity.  Like in a barn full of apples.  

The taste is complex, fruity,  funky, maybe a little smoky.  The alcohol is evident.  The beer has a strong aftertaste- it just stays in your mouth.  

It is a nice beer to sip on.  I like it.

Pours a hazy golden hue with huge creamy head, with nice lace.swEEt malts.. Lots of fruit in the nose, maybe pear, definately nice. Spicy flavors with some more of that fruit. Its a  sercret spicy belgian!
Bottly. Hazy golden orange colour with a huge creamy head. Powerful aroma and taste of malts, fruits and spices. Sweet and good. Good mouthfeel.

Bottle. Pours an extremely cloudy light copper with an enormous, frothy white head. I mean, this is in a wide-mouth chalice and the head just expands and develops landscape. The aroma is fruity, spiced, and very complex. It has a distinct tartness, with hints of cloves, apricot, lemon, and just a slightly sour funk. The flavor is pretty well done. Its not as sweet or dessert like as I was expecting. There are plenty of tart and bittersweet notes throughout. Cloves, banana, oranges, lemon zest, sour dough. . . the flavor profile is very expansive.  This finishes on a floral, vegetal, spicy note with just minimal doughy sweetness. Pretty good stuff, very elaborate and wild.
Shared bottle thanks to CMUBEERMAN. Pours opaque apricot, thick white head. Aroma is funky, musty, tangy bleu cheese, sour dough. Flavor is spicy, pumpkin, bleu cheese, salami, wheat, pepper.

First off this is about a 10 year old, 750ml bottle courtesy boboski. So, I will re-rate this when I have another fresh one.  Ill make it a 2 for 1 rating.  The old one first.  It pours a fizzy golden amber with a medium light tan head.  Pretty heavy alcohol and orange in the scent.  The taste is more mellow than the smell.  Light sweet orange, sweet malts, and other citrus.  Definitely can taste the age in this one as its lost a little of its bite.  Still very nice.  Carbonation has held on well. Stay tuned for part 2.

Pours foggy gold-orange with a gi-normous off-white head...ridiculous carbonation; I can hear it percolating. Spilled a little on the rub and my daughters mini-dog is rolling in it like its vintage cat-poo...con brio...I do not know if this is a good sign or not...Aroma of spice, citrus (oranges) and hops. Surprisingly sweet with a persistant carmel note and actually really smooth...didnt expect that...a bit of pepper, and more citrus...this is the Briggs-Rauscher of beer: carmel-citrus-spice-carmel-citrus-spice...Super nice brew!

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2009 Sour orange aroma.  Pours golden blonde with a huge white head, as the bubles keep rising.  Rich flavor, some citrus, starfruit, sweet sugar, a hint of grapes, and a little dry.  Theres some spicey flavor in there i cant place.  Very complex flavor but entirely refreshing!

murky dark yellow pour with a head thats alive.  It doesnt stop growing!  Smells of apples and peppers with a carbonated mouthfeel akin to the Unibroue family of drinks.  Caramels close down the mouth sensations.  The alcohol is extremely well buried and doesnt distract at all from the great character of this beer.  This is probably one of my all time favorites.  I need to acquire more!

UPDATED: FEB 15, 2008 Two separate ratings for this one. From a corked 750ml bottle, huge thanks to Dorwart.   The bottle is about 6 years old at this point, and if coerced properly, the head does not rise and surge out of the bottle for a full 45 minutes.  The key is to just let the blessed thing stand for awhile before popping it.  Historically magnificent nose of oak, lemon, yeast, hay, and soft light fruits.  Pour varies wildly based on how the bottle has been handled.  Hazy yellow-golden, growing darker orange toward the bottles end.  Flavor is a wild collage of many elements married into one cohesive vision.  Kind of oaky, yeasty, funky lemon dominates, but not so dry like a geuze, its  warm, rich, and elegant.  Rum, cheese, and lighter fruits shine as well.  Extraordinarily lush and smooth, pretty much the perfect beverage. 10,4,10,4,19 = 4.8

33cl bottle, various vintages.  Very different beer from the 750ml version.  Im honestly not sure whether the recipe is the same of whether age just transforms this beer massively.  Nose and mouth present alot of nectarine, apple, yeast, but finishes with a long, kind of bitter note that isnt entirely pleasant.  I would just buy a case and let it sit for 5 years as an experiment.  8, 4, 7, 4, 15 = 3.8
11.2 oz bottle.  Pours yellowish brown with a creamy white head.  Aromas and flavors of caramel.  Very good.

UPDATED: FEB 27, 2007 Comments added on second try: First bottle wasnt a fluke, but I "got" this beer this time.  Its liquid butterscotch.  Fabulous beer.  Extreme and interesting.


Strange one, this.  The bottle may not have been good, as it burst out with foam upon popping the cap.  Poured great after that.  Neat aroma.  But the taste was . . . well, different than I should think a Tripel or any beer should be.  It wasnt pleasant at first.  Something of a blend between tart and . . . metallic.  Off-putting and harsh.  Then I got more used to it as I proceeded.  By the bottom of the glass it was hardly off-putting at all; more a mellow Tripel with some mild tartness.  Maybe Ill try another bottle.

Beautiful golden yellow with lots of bubbles. Big, big foamy white head that sticks to the glass. Aroma is yeasty with a youghurt feel, straw- and raspberries. Some alcohol and hay as well. Full-bodied, not that creamy, but fills up your mouth fine. Flavours include oranges, lots of malty sweetness, a vinious feel as well as lots of warmth.

Clear yellow coloured, large white head with a lot of carbonation. Strong yeasty alcoholic aroma, some herbal touches. Strong full body, some sprankling. Finish is yeasty, alcoholic sweet, strong with a long and burning ending. Some fruity touches. A mad bitch for sure.

12 oz bottle pored into an Ommegang abbey glass. Really enjoyed this tripel. Poured a mildly cloudy goldish orange color with nice full head. Tiny bubbles lasting throughout. Citrus, spices medium bodied. One of the best tripels Ive had to date.

Appearance...looking in the bottle, there are tons of yeast particles held in suspension with a small yeast bed stuck on the bottom. The pour gives way to a hazy, pale, orange toned gold with a gigantic, fluffy white head that slowly fades out. Beautiful smounts of fluff stick to the sides of the glass.
Smell is of honey, apricot, lemon, tangerine, sugary, florally, poached pear, mild banana & coriander, along with a touch of funk that is welcomed and enticing.
Taste is of the mentioned aromas with a very nice dose of yeast that makes me want to culture the strain out of the bottle and go nuts come my next homebrew session.
Mouthfeel is smooth, creamy, mildly sweet, and addictive. Tiny carbonation bubbles are aggressive at first. but turn to a smoothness that delivers nicely.

Pours a cloudy gold with a ton, and I mean TON, on nearly white head. The head is thickly packed. It takes a long while to die back, and when it does, it leaves fantastic lace. I sense a mildly tart aroma something like a Fantome, but not as prominent.

Taste is both tart and sweet. And spicy and alcoholic. I taste a little honey, some grain, and some kind of odd hops - lets say tart floral. Mild dry spiciness. I taste no fruit, no candi. Medium to full body. Aftertaste of alcohol. Medium carbonation.

Tasty and rich, this is a good beer. 750 ml bottle. Mad Bitch indeed.

Pours copper / golden with a rich frothy white head.  The aroma is quite spicy with wild yeast, barnyard traits and some white grapes - tart and tangy, drier than most tripels.  Medium body with lots of playful spritzy carbonation.  The flavors start with moderately sweet thick pale malt, some honey, some vineous notes and light spice.  The finish brings out the distinct Belgium traits - earthy yeast, barnyard and such.  There is a bit of spice and some alcohol presence.  A very nice verion of a classic style that is not as sweet as most.  Big thumbs up.

Bottle from Rivers Bend.  Poured hazy orange color with a huge frothy head that lasted with excellent lacing. Complex spicy fruit and yeasty aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture. Medium fruity balanced flavor with a medium sweet finish of long duration with a small alcohol bite. This is a standout beer.

bottle. hazy orange/golden pour with a lot of sediment and big foamy head.  very spicy aroma, baked bread, fruit and alcohol aroma.  very spicy pepper, alochol not well hidden at all.  one dimensional.  I was expecting more.
330 ml bottle. Pours cloudy golden color with a foam off white head. Aroma of citrus and spice. Sweat taste with a clean finish.

The 11 oz bottle was barely contianing this super hyperactive hazy yellow beer.  Overflowed upon opening and released an outstanding fruity aroma.  I usually pour the beer before I smell it.  Apricot, banana, and watermelon.  Yes, I smelled it twice, there is watermelon in there.  Fizzy head was huge, but died off fast like a soda.  Very sweet on the flavor as well.  Some breadyness,  orange, alcohol is present, but not overwellimg.  Very Very good.
Pear orange and cider aroma with a champagne effervescence.  Yeasty sweet flavor.  Very nice.

2003 750ml Bottle, tasted December 30, 2006. Beautiful bright orange pour with a big fluffy white head of lacy foam.  As the foam recedes from the glass it leaves behind some string lace.  Aroma is spicy and flowery, almost saison-ish. Flavor is slightly sweet initially, then the tongue scrapping dryness kicks in.  Flowery and spicy. Tripels are one of my least favorites, but this is quality.  No hot alcohol in either the aroma or the flavor.
Bottle. Poured a murky golden color with a white frothy head. Aroma of friut. Taste is sweet with fruit and the alcohol is very well hide.
Bottle. Murky golden brown color with a big fluffy white head. Tastes of fruity sweetness carried by a texture thats slightly oily and creamy. All in all this is a must have beer.

33 cl bottle.  Deep golden and slightly earthy with a thick creamy white head.  Sticky lace with very spicy/yeasty aromas.  Mango, papaya, lime and lemon top notes, more tropical fruit and even some pineapple.  A touch of warming follows all of these bringing with it intense spices of cardamon, clove, and ginger.  Creamy texture with a lovely wheaty body and spiciness up front.  Fresh tropical fruit mingling with warm baking spices.  Ginger, clove, black pepper mingle with a soft spearmint flavour on the back.  Sweet Belgian malt bring the yeast and fruitiness together.  Warming intensifies the spice and softens the fruit.  Waves and waves of alternating sweet spice, tropical fruit and tart acidity just make this a world class example of the brewers art.  Amazing beer.

Bottle. Golden orange hue with agressively carbonated white head.  Nose is orange, pineapple, guava, mango, a little spices, and some yeast. Love the aroma. Flavor is initially sweet with the fruits and then a bit sharper with more bready and yeasty notes along with a pleasent alchohol bite. This is a great beer. So far, my palate has not agreed with de dolle beers, but this one--i likey.
Bottled. Golden coloured with a rather large head. Yeasty and a bit bready with notes of orange, malts, alcohol, various spices and quite highly carbonated.

Poured out dark-yellow/copper with a typically huge De Dolle Brouwers head. The head wouldnt fade either, it just sat there. Nice tripel-aromas, sweet with enough hops to balance it. Very yeasty & bready, with some vanilla. Taste was sweet, not much bitterness. Loads of alcohol noticable - which went well with this beer and amplified the malty bready sweetness. Thick mouthfeel, almost cloying, with alot of carbonation. A very well made, large, heavy & bold tripel.

Reasonable loking yellow with nicely suspended sediment and big white head.  Aroma is sweet and tangy which carries over into the flavor.  Alcohol is apparent throughout, and burns at the finish. 11.2ozs/$4.10

Bottle. Strong yeast aroma, cheese.  Orange hue with bubbly white head. Strong flavor.  Bitter throughout, slight citrusy orange peel.  Slight cheese flavor.  Sweet up front.   Some spiciness.  Strong carbonation.  Sharp on the tongue and then mellows.  Alcohol smolders as it gos down.  Good overall.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2007 Hazy golden with a perfect head, rich and frothy.  Tropical fruits and coriander aromas.  Flavor is immediately sharp, but not abrasive.  Perfumey and spicy, lemon zest, pear, maybe some wheat.  Briskly carbonated and dry in the mouth,  distantly sour, evolving dynamically as it warms.  Really quite nice.

Updated.  A very old bottle of unknown vintage at the Brickskeller.  Pours murky and golden yellow, towering foam.  Aroma of the perfect apple cider; tart, spicy, and rich.  Caramel, pure honey, almond and maple syrup in their sweet and perfect essences.  Tastes of french toast, lightly dusted with nutmeg and cardamom.  Detailed and dense.  Hints at garlic, pineapple, fruit liqueurs, and cotton candy.  Slick and heavy in hte mouth with a sage-like bite of bitterness.  Very warm finish.  Entirely unique, and unforgettable.

Bottle at home.
Unclaer amber with a very large off white head, good lacings. Aroma heavy malty (fruity, citrus, esters), moderate hoppy, light yeasty. Flavor heavy sweet, moderate bitter, long duration. Medium/full body, lively carbonated, strong in alcohol.

Hazy golden color. Enormous head fades quickly. Extremely carbonated. Spicy aroma kicked up by the carbonation. Tastes of mild fruits with the burn of an alcohol finish. Tingly due to the carbonation. Hides the 10% very well. Awsome beer.

UPDATED: SEP 19, 2009 12OZ bottle VIA mibromeo (thanks!). Wow, as soon as i opened this it started crawling out. The head is like 80% of the glass...only got about 1/3 in my mug and the rest is now crawling out of the botlle. What a mess...perhaps infected? Taste is actually not that bad. It is both sweet and tart, with some vanilla, honey, and berry flavors. Carbonation is high, body is medium.

11.2 oz bottle-pours lightly cloudy orange with a small fizzy white whispy head with some lacing along the edge of the glass.  nose is fruity/ funky, estery with lots of sweet ripe citrus.  smells more funky than alot of trippels i have had  A light dusty ester comes in there as well.  flavors are sweet, light funk, light citrus, tart yeast, actually very tart, especially on the finish.  almost like a grapefuit without the bitterness.  finish is very tart with lingering funky yeast.  Very nice trippel with some nice coplexity.

This is a dry, well-hoped tripel.  Pale in color and an impressive white head.  There is a hint of sweetness but this is nothing like a tripel that is actually sweet, like Karmeliet.  I taste some grapefruit in addition to the dry hops.  I have waited a long time to have this and Im glad I finally had the chance.

UPDATED: NOV 11, 2007 330 ML bottle-Poured a cloudy, hazey off orange color w/almost no head. Sweet aroma of sugar cane/cotton candy. Crisp flavor of citrus & spice, with some dough & brown sugar thrown in. Rich full complex flavor. Long finish. Its good, but its no Special Reserva 2005-but not much else is!!

Rerate-on Tap 11/10/07- Even better than I remember. A lot more of the sweetness came thru on tap. Long smooth finish. Easy drinker.

Pours a hazy thick, orange amber color. The head is minimal. Smell is a bit piny, cedar, and buttery. Taste is yeasty, leathery, and a bit minty. The bottle was cold but the beer poured out perfect temp. This beer had a lot of interesting sediments at the bottlom of the bottle which were very chewy and sweeet/sour.

330 ml bottle from Sams in Chicago. Hazy golden amber colour with a mostly lasting creamy off-white head and thick lacing. Caramel, citrus, spices, light acidity, alcohol, floral, and persimmon aroma with dry yeasty notes. Caramel, candy sugar, orange and lime citrus, spicy, and yeasty flavours, with a sweet brown sugar finish. Full bodied, warming, almost chewy mouthfeel, but effervescent. Very tasty, but seems underattenuated for a tripel.

[bottle, no date] Tart, fruity aroma- sweet honey and pear. Pours a super cloudy, yellowish/gold color, with a huge white head, leaving some nice lacing along the glass. Flavors are initially quite sugary, with apple/pear fruitiness and yeast character. Very complex and full bodied; peppery hops blend with more yeast and candi sugar in the finish. Alcohol is quite noticable, but not harsh at all. Overall a really nice, complex triple.

UPDATED: DEC 20, 2006 2004 bottle. Decent aroma that was kind of funky. Good cloudy appearance with lots of activity and decent head. Flavor is a little bitter and sour at first. Changes personality after warming. Odd brew.

Re-rate with a fresh bottle. I enjoyed this better than the aged bottle. Good taste that only got better as it warmed. Good balance.

33cl bottle.  Cloudy orange/amber, thick frothy head diminishing slowly but surely. Tart fruit and yeasty aroma like other tripels, with a bit more cheesiness here, even a slight hint of truffles at first.  Sweet flavors dominate---raw sugar, some toffee, golden raisin, orange zest and dried and sugar-powdered pinapple rings with some alcohol vapor misting up now and then.  Medium, spirited palate.  Very good, almost excellent tripel if only the sweetness were taken down just a bit.

Bottle.  Pours a cloudy orange, with a finger of bubbly tan head.  Smells like bananas, with hints of citrus and apples. Malty, tingles the mouth and throat as it trickles down.  Tastes like a banana laffy taffy.  Wow, this is tasty, and it warms ya right up.  Cant wait to try more brews from De Dolle.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2007 Imagine all the oozing, corpulent zombies you like.  Envisage haunting specters roaming down hall ways to your hearts content.  Ruminate on swamp monsters, vampires, werewolves, scientific abominations and uncanny murders until you turn cold and clammy, but we all know that there is something supremely scarier than all these blood curling thoughts: the angry termagant, or as its known in the beer community, the Mad Bitch!  It was hardly a choice which beer would be most appropriate for Halloween night.  But its a sardonic beer on any occasion.  I distinctly recall a woman coming into a local wine shop and asking for a Joke beer, maybe something funny in the name.  Sure enough, Mad Bitch was suggested and, rather than take offense the woman seemed rather intrigued.  The label attempts to drill into the psychological core of womens rage but even its confusing colors and alarming visage fail to do justice to the great purging anger of the better sex.  The acrimonious words and bellicose saber rattling of a truly fearsome warrior of the XX clan simply cant be conveyed in image.  From the bottle issues forth a cloudy and richly colored beverage the hue of bees wax with a nigh uncontrollable whipped egg white head.  I had to pace the pour for about five minutes to fit the whole drink in my glass  uncontrollable!  The nose is far more charming, gracing the nose with pear, sour apple, butter, lemon, clove, red grapes, fresh mountains stream, and a hint of generic sourness.  With a little warmth this bouquet includes creamed honey, apricot, honey suckle and sweet yellow corn.  The taste abandons all this deceptively sweet charm and burdens itself with savory seriousness, committing itself to a heavy biscuit theme flanked by yeast and white bread tastes.  It is advised, then, that the Mad Bitch is enjoyed at a safe distance where the pleasing aroma can be appreciated and the coarse and mild mannered taste can be avoided.  If we are to survive the horror of horrors that is a womans scorn (Greater than or equal to Hells fury and all that) then we must learn to keep our distance and, in some cases, find a heavy obstacle to duck behind so that we may later enjoy the lighter side of the same idyllic angel who only yesterday was called the Mad Bitch!

33cl bottle, no date.  Pours a light caramel golden with a huge eggshell head.  .  Aroma of candy sugar, yeast, dusty bananas, peppery spicy hops, and a little vanilla.  Taste is much the same with a little bit of caramel and sweet orange citrus.  Dry finish with some warming ETOH in the back of the throat.  Full bodied, mod-high carbonation.  One of the better tripels.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: Bottle. Dark golden/orange colour with a white head.Aroma is wheat, orange, yeast. Flavour is yeast, alcohol, orange, sweet, spices.

UPDATED: OCT 16, 2006 750 bottle poured in a gulden draak tulip.  Aged at least 1 year.  Drinking this with some very spicy habanero pepper jack cheese.  Foam exploded out of the bottle when the cork was pulled.  From the looks of it I think this is an old bottle (no date).  Pours a very hazy gold with a huge white head.  Excellent head.  I cant see anything through the beer, must be the ridiculous amount of belgian yeast in it.  A very sweet and fruity aroma with spice and alcohol.  As with the aroma this stuff has huge spice fruit flavors.  Flavors of wheat, citrus, bitterness, and alcohol on top of the spice and fruit.  Very carbonated and fairly light body.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2010 Bottled. Hazy, golden-orange, with a nice white head. The aroma has citrus, spices, alcohol and dishwashing-water, but in a pleasant way. Fruity and bitter flavor with alcohol, sweetness, spices and wheat. Sweet, full body and a long finish. A nice tripel, not too sweet. Rating: 7-4-8-4-16-3.9. 060928Bottle. A hazy golden beer topped by a white head of moderate size. The aroma is sweetish and sugary, with notes of spices. Sweet and fruity flavor with a touch of spices, quite sugary. Full-bodied, finishing sugary sweet and spiced. Overall, a bit on the sweet side, but a pleasant one indeed. 100212
