Shared a 750mL with Goob.  aroma of bread.  banana, doughy, alcohol.  Flavors of smoke.  finishes with hichory.  golden orange in color.  very bitter and very dry.  goes much better with food.  probably a smoked pork tenderloin or spicy thai.

Beautiful head, that disipates only slighty.  Mildly sweet aroma, a touch nutty, malty.  Wow, the taste is slightly sweet, slightly bitter, with a wonderful malt zest.  The a after-zing is like a spicy food, dont go too fast the bitchll get ya.  The only downside is the 10% isnt hidden well enough.

cloudy gold with a huge creamy head.  vigorous lacing.  nice citrus, fruity, marshmallow tripel aroma.  sweet, sugary, hoppy flavor.  very smooth.  moderately dry finish.  hint of grapefruit in aftertaste.
Golden yellow with rocky white head. Lemon, grape and apple. Freshness and bitterness are perfektly balanced.

Clear amber color  white frothy medium head  nose of  yeast , malt , cereals , grains and citrus / orange  taste of malts , yeast , cereals , grains , sour red fruit , and citrus   cream raw body , and dry style  aftertaste slightly bitter , chalk , and yeast
Bottle. Golden colour with white head. Sweet fruity aroma and flavour is yeast, caramel and fruity
11.2 pours out camelish looking dirty blonde. tastes of citrusy, pepper, yeast, caramel, crispy, very complex a bit piney. I like not the best thing since sliced bread tho

Bottle at home. Almost clear golden - white head. What a great beer. Obvious DeDolle yeast in the aroma. Spicy, yeast, fruity (apples), citrus, sour (the DeDolle way). And a lot more... oakish !?! This is not my last Dulle Teve 10.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2008 Bottle.  Hazy honey color, scant head, bad retention.  Flavor is tinny, sweet and mellow, apricot notes.  Flavor is overly sweet, nectar, pear, one dimensional.  Mouthfeel is bubbly and silky, good fresh characters.  I was a bit let down by this, above average, but not amazing.  Rerate - better than I remember.  Mellow, well balanced, and super chewy triple.  Doughy with tons of floaters.  Much better than I remember.  Rerate - tremendous, great balance, super beer.

330 ml bottle, at Delirium Café, Göteborg. Cloudy golden colour, huge and lasting head. Spicy aroma with notes of leather and oak. Flavour is again spicy with yeasty notes, leather and oak, fairly dry. Very good.

Bottle. Pours a nice golden brown with a massive, solid, insulating foamy head. Theres a lot of citrus and alcohol notes - orange, some banana, some roasted malt, some abbey dubbel notes. Flavors of orange, banana, yeast, and a good deal of Granny Smith apple. Wonderful stuff.

11.2 oz bottle.  pours a hazy orange yellow with a nice fluffy white head.    Very bready, yeasty,  and alcohol aromas.  The palate is medium body and full of flavor citrus, banana, carmel, yeast, and earthiness all balanced very well with a nice amount of alcohol.

Golden orange beer, slightly hazy. A huge fluffy white head. Aroma is a delight, beginning yeasty and leathery and developing sour and sweet fruity notes over the next half hour. Fruit, pear and some banana, as well as alcohol, dominate the taste, but there are notes of citric sourness, spice and nuttiness that blend imperceptibly into a bitter finish. A wonderful tripel, to be slowly sipped and savoured. Minor complaint: the hallmark De Dolle label, ugly and amateurish, but this is obviously not reflected in the rating.

Bottle: Pours a hazy orange body and a lively, medium sized off- white head that is short lasting. The aroma is with apple, citrus, banana and caramel with a good amount of yeast. The flavour is sweet/ sour fruity (oranges and lemon) with an alcohol bite. Its full bodied. Pleasant sour and slightly bitter finish with yeast and alcohol at the end. Enjoyable!

11.2oz bottle.  Aroma:  Yeasty breadiness, bananas, oranges, and pears, mild spiciness, touch of toffee.  Appearance:  Dark orange and very hazy bordering on murky.  Some floaties spotted.  Head is white, full and creamy looking.  Nice lacing.  Flavor:  Sweet maltiness, a subtle earthiness, citrus, banana, slight bubblegum, and a nice pepperiness.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  High carbonation.  Alcohol warming on back of tongue.  Overall:  A nice tripel with some good deep flavors.

11.2 oz bottle. pours a hazy orange with a big head and the carbonation is very lively.  Nice, strong aroma of fruits such as apples, pears, and alot of earthy and spicy yeast.  Taste is full bodied across the palate, lightly sweet.  Alot of apple, pear and slightly tart citrus along with bready/earthy yeast.  It finishes off smoothly with some earthy spicy notes.  alcohol can be felt in the stomach, but well hidden throughout the taste.  A very good tripel, no doubt.

Pour is a clear amber, lots of effervescence and a massive frothy head that dies down quicker than most Belgians and has bigger bubbles, too.  Aromas of apple juice are hitting me from two feet away as it sits on the desk waiting.  As the head dies down and I put the rest in the glass it has taken a slightly darker color an has become murky.  Fruit still dominates the nose... maybe white grapes enter the mix on a second sniff.  There is good lacing on the sides of the glass as the head dies down.  Mouthfeel is fairly heavy.  You can tell that the fruity aspects are the main show here, mostly sweet up front with a grain presence following and then a little burst of sourness as the sip fades to a memory.  A little more unidimensional than I expected, though as the fruit flavors are definitely the feature.  I had wished for a little more complexity of flavoring here... not terribly disappointed, just didnt live up to my expectations based on other De Dolle products.
user_location: The Wet Side of a Dry Town, Pennsylvania, USA

text: UPDATED: NOV 16, 2006 Pours a murky, yellowish/light brown with a fizzing and bubbly head which diminishes to a film. Sharp aroma, sweet & fruity with a hint of sourness. Slightly barnyard-like aroma with sour apple suggestions. The flavor is smooth, balanced and amazing. It has suggestions of apples, figs, a drop of belgian yeast and a bit of caramel-like sweetness. Slight toffeeish aspect in the finish, a light and heavenly smooth alcohol warmth on the way down. The alcohol is very well hidden in the flavor, you would never think its 10% alcohol from the flavor. Great, lively, tingly mouthfeel. A great triple.

Bottle into De Dolle Oerbier glass, Hop Duvel Cafe, Gent.  Golden transluscent orange in the glass with a fizzy white head that mostly diminishes to a dusting.  Lacing is thin and oily but uniform.  Smells of yeast and decomposing orange peel, cardamom and ginger, muscat grape, Gala apples, and over-ripe apricot.  Fizzy at first.  Smooth, but vacant when compared to Stille Nachts fullness.  Tastes of oranges, orange peel, yeast, and warmness.  Not much of a finish; at first, theres alcohol burn, and then it dries out.  Moderately good beer, but the alcohol presence is a bit too dominant.

Bottled. Golden-amber color with large head.  Acidic and fruity aroma with notes of white wine and whisky-like phenolics. Very heavily carbonated and full-bodied. Sweet flavor with strong pepper character, banana, chocolate and tart alcohol. Pepper,  banana, warming alcohol and some bitterness in the finish.

Bottle-8/3/06, Purchased at The Market Basket in Rockport Maine.  Pours golden, and the head foamed up huge as most De Dolle beers do, and eventually settled to a nice thin layer.  The carbonation on the bottle I had seemed very high making it feel a bit like champagne.  Slightly bitter lingeringing taste.  I love de dolle, but this is one of my least favorites so far, despite the fact that it is very good.

Cloudy orange with a huge white frothy head. Aromas of earth, wine, fruits including banana, bubble gum and some spice. Dry flavour with pepper and some alcohol showing. Lasting complex aftertaste with all of the aroma elements lingering in your mouth.

8/1/06: Bottle. Burnt golden body  a bit hazy.  Head is large and slightly off-white.  Lace clings to glass and is quite creamy.  Aroma is of wheat with spice and florals.  Spices are amazing and complex.  Very creamy and warming with a slight pepper finish.

beautiful amber body with small white head and nice carbonation...aroma begins with vinegar and light fruits, and is followed by belgian yeast, light spice, and circus peanuts...flavor is of light fruits, yeast, bread, and has a dry/bitter finish...fruits open up upon warming, as does the alcohol...there is also a lingering taste of mint leaves upon finishing this fine beer...perfect palate

Pours cloudy orange with a foamy white head that lasts. Aroma is pretty typical of the style and consists of fruit and alcohol. Flavor is complex. It starts with mostly malt and alcohol.  The finish is very roasty tasting and a surprise.  I really really like this.
The strength of this beer defintely comes with its aggressive but awesome aftertaste.  It has all the spice and you can definitely taste the alcohol in this beer.  Enjoy!
Wow, damn fine beer here!  I love tripels, but this one is special, HUGE spicey aftertaste, yet remains crisp, and boy boy boy can you taste the alcohol.  Huge warming.  Good.

33cl bottle: aroma was unleashed from the bottle as soon as the crown was removed.  Banana, clove, yeast flowed into the air.  It poured a dirty orange color with a 3/4 inch fluffy head that settled down into waves of froth with small bubbles coming up from the bottom.  There was also a great deal of lacing left on the glass.  The nose is full of the elements mentioned when the top was removed plus alcohol.  The flavor is even stronger than the aroma full of ripe banana, yeast, alcohol, with a slight funk, and a touch of pepperiness from the hops.  The mouth feel is full of active bubbles that caress your mouth as you swallow.  A very well crafted tripel

Cloudy orange beer that is FULL of suspended floaties all topped by a thin lasting head and a sweet, slightly sharp aroma. The mouthfeel for me is a little too fizzy (the liveliest ive tried from DeDolle yet) but the flavour is back in there.

Bottle.  Pour is murky orange with initially thick, bubbly white head that quickly dissipates to a thin bubbly layer.    Sweet aroma, not very strong.  Taste is a big punch in the face compared to the aroma.  Taste has some dark fruit and yeast in it.  I notice the warming alcohol effect in my stomach.  Mouthfeel is carbonated and acidic.  Not bad, the best offering from this brewer Ive had yet.
Bottle.  Orangey beer with a strong white head.  The flavour is very, very strong, yeasty fruits and very vinous.  The flavour is very strong and mulled fruits.  Overall a decent strong beer.

Bouteille de 330 ml obtenue via Importations Privées Bièropholie. Arôme: Odeur dépices, de citron et une forte présence dalcool. Apparence: La couleur est blonde orangée avec une forte densité de bulle. Présence dun énorme col mousseux et dune large dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel et de fruité avec une pointe dalcool. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement crémeuse. Forte effervescence en bouche. Présence dalcool en arrière goût. (Rating #536)

Poured into my Orval glass.  Loads of color.  Everything from golden to amber and back.  Beautiful white head, with some lacing.  Hay, lemon/lime, candy sugar, and cookie dough come through in the aroma.    A medium candy sweetness to start with a tangy acidic kicker.  I can feel a touch of the alcohol in my nose.  Fizzy carbonation.  Long, alcoholic finish.  My tongue is still stinging long after each drink.  I dont really care for that.  A fine enough beer.  Id recommed it as I would all of De Dolles beers.

Pours a copper orange with a nice fat head. Smells of sharp cheddar and parmesan cheese. It is truly a pleasure to sit and breath in this aroma, spices just tickle my nose and make me smile. Last night I was in a rundown old hotel with a bunch of crack heads all around, and having to use a toilet that reminded me a lot of the one in trainspotting, luckily I didnt need to sit down, and tonight I am in my apartment listening to the clash and drinking this beer after a productive night at work, things are looking up. Dry and earthy flavors are nice. Rich yeasty finish. Dry cracker flavor is present with a light lemony citrus. The alcohol doesnt hide, but it works well with the other flavors. This is blissful. A bit of light toffee is coming out late in this, it is really getting good now. And it goes well with a can of beanie weenies and corn chips too.
Ap-4 ar-10 tas-8 pal-5 ov-18

From 11.2oz Bottle.  Slightly hazy golden pour with a tall, soapy white head.  Clouds of yeast empty from the bottle into my glass, transforming the frosted brass haze to a hue of tea tinged honey.  Semi sweet aromas of toasted marshmellows melted in a hot banana and seasoned with a pinch of cinnimon spice.  A touch of herbal lavender and marigold stems add some gentle hop tones to the otherwise yeast dominated aroma.  Light, lively carbonated mouthfeel with loads of yeast and a bit of cinnmon toast.  Enticing flavors of teriyaki grilled chicken with some mild clove spice.  Final smack is a bit musty, and allows some smokey almond notes and green pepper spice to develop.  Delicious example of a tripel.

A very pleasant surprise, based on the label I did not have high expectations but wow, this is quite a brew. Hazy gold with a giant foamy head, aroma of yeasty fruity esters and light spice. Very complex fruity array, alcohol and phenols. Balannce and mouthfell are exceptional, one of the best tripels I have experienced, but jeez what an ugly label.

High head on a dark gold body. Very strong taste, fruity and spicy, a nice but very strong beer. There are dark fruits there, yet sweet enough. Warm  and soothing, it is a very nice beer after a large meal.

Bottle (from Bitter Virtue). Slightly cloudy golden with massive creamy head and yeasty foam attempting and largely succeeding to escape the bottle. Gentle fruity yeast, smooth malts, spicy almost citrus aromas with lots of alcohol. Upon closer examination there is a nice gingernut aroma. Quite highly carbonated in a pleasant way which helps to cut through the full malt sweetness. A light bitterness in the finish with just a hint of not unpleasant yeast bite. I enjoyed this (and the pleasant mellow feeling it left behind after it was finished) but I think it could have done with slightly less alcohol and a dryer body.

Bottle. Its been a while since I had to stop pouring a brew because the head was so large it threatened to overflow. The head is so huge and so slow in disipating that Im not sure when Im going to actually be able to drink it. Very similar in aroma to the De Dolle Dulle Teve Special Reserva. From the description on the latter, I am deducing that the reason the Teve 10 is a little lighter in color is perhaps due to the fact it was not aged in the Calvados casks. But hold that, now that I am able to pour the rest of the bottle in, the sediment/yeast at the bottom of the bottle makes the body darker and very similar to the orange of the Special Reserva. Head is beautiful, cumulus cloud-like, enduringly lasting. This brew is supposed to be more lively in its carbonation, but Im not getting that. I really should have done a side-by-side, because my frame of comparison is spread over 24 hours. Its hard for me thus to tell much difference between the two brews. Sweet, Belgian candi-sugar. Im not as enamored with this brew as the Special Reserva, but its still darn good and very similar.

I am no expert in advertising, but naming your beer "Mad Bitch" doesnt sound like a recipe for success. The recipe for this beer, however, need not change as it is an excellent example of the style and simply an excellent brew. The color reminds of Charentais melon, subtly clouded and topped of a superb creamy white head that recedes with equally dense lacing. Classic esters and grain form the cynosure of the nose, a wonderful combination of bubble gum, dried banana, raisins, mandarin, apple juice, cherries and peach yoghurt balanced by the rich sweetness of caramel, biscuits and honey. This enticing complexity is not as ebullient in the flavor as it relies more on a soft malt profile than the panache of fruits found in the aroma. Butterscotch and unctuous grains hide the relatively high alcohol content that is only reminded by the slightly burnt finish. I would love to try some older samples of this wonderful tripel.

Golden orange body, huge creamy white head, thick lacing; Good, not huge special nose: citrus, some dries nuts and eucalyptus; Huge a bit sharp carbonation, balanced fresh body; Into very long finish, incredibly present alcohol, very harsh orange peel, fresh nuts and again eucalyptus.

UPDATED: MAR 7, 2007 (Bottle at delirium cafe, Göteborg) Very hazy orange with a big white head. Pretty fast decreasing with big bubbles. The aroma is interesting. Belgian yeast and sweetness. Violet. Bubblegum-ish. Smells like a young beer. Marzipan. Strong flavour that leaves a peppery feeling in the mouth. The alcohol shines through. Tastes young and straggly. Champagne carbination. Little soapy. Good afterbitterness. Marzipan and some fruits. Yeast. Cool bottle.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2012 33cl bottle, vintage unknown
Consumed at Bier Circus, Brussels, May 2006
Cloudy, deliciously glowing with a light amber murkiness.  Has a firm, well-supported white head.  Nose of gummy sour fruity, a sharp scent of alcohol, some pineapple and bubblegum.  Well-carbonated, very light on the tongue but with a thick body.  Full of a fight between sweet and sour fruits.  One of the best tripels Ive had.

Rating updated to 4.7 based on 4-5 year old bottles... the dry cobweb character of these aged bottles is nearly-perfect.
Bottle. White lasting head. Orange hazy body. Fruity yet spicy aroma. Sorry mates but I do not like your flavor of alcohol and hops.

Deep hazy golden beer with massive head that doesnt quit. Aroma winey, with sauvignon blanc notes of gooseberry, pineapple and mango. Second whiffs revealed the almost raw barely underneath. Flavor is complex, layers of thick tropical fruit, sweet malt.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2006 From the bottle.
Pours a hazy light brown  amber with an ample head. The aroma is orange and spice with some yeast; the flavor follows with the addition of strong coconut tones. This one has a (too-)notable alcohol burn early on and corresponding alcohol flavor; the hop finish is not particularly dry or exagerated.

While this is nice, head to head with the 7.5% and lower-rated Abbeye des Rocs Blond, this one comes in second place (for everything except the huge amounts floating matter in the des Rocs.)

Pours a cider-like, cloudy brown into a tulip.  Earth and spicy citrus notes.  Microbubble head lasts and continues.  Full and bubbly. Upfront gorganzola that turns to sweet dried apples and pears with a lasting bitter yeast and hop finish.

Im a huge fan of tripels (maybe my favorite style). And I was pleased to import this for about $1 while travelling in Belgium. However, this one wasnt all I thought it was going to be initially (having been impressed by some other De Dolle selections). Poured with a humungous head. After the first pour into my Westvleteren glass, I waited five minutes, returned, and then poured.... still about 50ml in the bottle. So, I took an initial aroma whiff of the poured beer and then sipped away straight from the bottle. It was a bit ridiculous: harsh high abv presence with a rather bitter hoppy finish. So, I took the goblet and went to the family room. The carbonation was really high and the bubbles rather entertaining to watch as they rose up the amber-wheat colored (cloudy) beer to the pillowy REALLY big head (which was persistent). The aroma was vinous more than anything else, although not lacking some candy sugar. After another five minutes or so, the flavor was harsh, vinous, with a hoppy bitter finish - aggressive all the way around. Allowing it to warm, though, things got a lot better and the apples and citrus flavors came through with a rather nice yeasty and hoppy bitter finish. Still a little on the aggressive side for a tripel (and very thick mouthfeel), but a nice tripel. If youre sitting on one of these, let it sit for a few years, maybe things will work out even better for you.

Bottle (donated by bierkoning !): Cloudy, orangey coloured, small lacing off-white, creamy head; strong orangey nose, combined with traces of sweet malt and caramel; sweet (fruity) flavour; sweet and - towards the end - strong spicy bitter finish, very well hidden alcohol. Deceptive, moreish.............

330 ml bottle. Pours to a hazy, deep golden color with a thick, creamy, white head, and a soft to moderate carbonation. The nose on this beer is excellent with fragrant aromas of sweet malt, candy sugar, earthy/spicy yeast, and peppery alcohol. The palate is firm, with good pale and sweet malt flavors, spice, funky yeast flavor, and flavors of candy sugar. This beer finishes with more of those complex malt, yeast, and candy flavors up front, then ends with a soothing, peppery burn. Very well done abbey triple from the Mad Brewers of Belgium. A great after work or after dinner brew to sip and savor.

Mildly cloudy, dirty gold. Big white head. Decent aroma - white wine, raisins, mostly. Sweet and musty at first, then a touch of alcohol. Then another touch alcohol, with a noticeable alcohol note. Finally ends with an assertive alcohol burn.

Hazy yellow gold hue, with a rocky white head, with nice lacing, yeasty fruitiness nose of citrus fruits of orange peels, grapefruit, and pineapple, floral hops, hint of sweet pale malt in the aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with a zesty sweet citrus fruits accent of grapefruit, lemon, tangerine, also a pineapple note fruitiness, yeasty, hint of spiciness, maybe coriander, with a warming alcoholic note, floral hops, leading towards a fruity bitter finish.

UPDATED: DEC 16, 2012 33 cL Bottle. Pour of clouded marmelade in yellow corn syrup, with a frothy soap head of ivory. Aroma is a bright and extremely fresh lemony sage, with hints of tangerine and apricot as a fresh new Glade plug-in. Fairly light, though. Flavor is an intense rich bready wheat, with a whole broad swath of curried lemon flavors, stewed with clove and coriander. The freshly grated peel mingles with pinches of dried ginger and the juice flows sweetly with raw sugar and perfume. The alcohol is quite noticable, but not offensive or troublesome, instead carrying a gentle sloping race of warm fusels and light acteyls. It has bright yeast spices and a nice coating of almond dust. The palate is clean, sweet and clear, with a touch of tingling tartness that leaves a fresh smack of rosemary sprig on the tounge. Finally, an elegant smack of pear skin and apple core, blended with a drop or two of cognac. As fine french candy, this is. Does have gushing problems I will note. Sorry, Andy. This was supposed to be for you, but it didnt make it. Ill get another.
Robe dorée voilée sans mousse. Arômes de malt et de levure. Saveurs de malt, de levure, de co2 et de houblon amérisant. Très pétillante.

<!-- B -->Bottle<!-- /B --> Poures a slightly hazy light golden color with a very nice dense white head.  Even after i slowly sneaked it into the glass.  Nice fruity musty aromas.  Apples, pears, some spicy cinnimon.  Nice sweet flavor.  A little butterscotch, apple butter, slightly musty belgian notes, a decent ABV kick and very lively carbonation.

Slightly hazy gold under a big, foamy, effervescing head that collapses quickly. Aroma is bready and yeasty with some faint floral notes. Nice medium body with lively carbonation. Light toffee sweetness gives way to sour and spicy flavors. Finsihes with a lasting sourness and a bit of astringent bitterness that lasts quite a while. I dint really note the alcohol in the aroma or flavor, although I sure noticed it by the end of the glass.

Pours an amber color with golden hues, beneath a ridiculous mound of white foam. Flowery and earthy yeast aromas flow out of the glass followed by sublte hints of white grapes. A light sweetness hits the tounge followed by a peppery spice, biscuity malts and some herbal notes. Not bad.

Aroma is strongly bready, tobacco, and a dominating aroma that neither me nor my friend can recognize. Slightly sweet and soy saucy. Pours deep cloudy orange with a huge white head that dies quickly. Taste is extremely strong and assertive, with almonds and spice, sour bread, and yet more tastes Im failing to recognize. A pretty extreme and crazy beer; just what Id expect from De Dolle.

Aroma:good spicy hops,citrus....
Appearance:Hazy gold,goos white head...
Flavor:citrus,spicy,alcohol,light caramel....

from the bottle. poured acloudy copper with lots of bubbles and a large fluffy white head and a ton of lacing. aroma, spicey coriander, gloves, lemon, orange, yeast, some sweetness. flavor, cinnamon, orange zest, gloves, bready, hops, sweet as it warms alcohol came out nicely. good beer

UPDATED: APR 26, 2006 Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours a  copper with a white head. Aroma of caramel malts, citrus and spices. Flavor is sweet, alcohol, and bitter in the finish. Wasnt impressed.

Bottle.  Spicy coriander apple aroma. Generous eggshell head on clear orange-amber beer.  Active fizz.  Very fruity, like biting into apple - much more so than many similar tripels.  Cinnamon coriander is detectable. Lively hops.  Bored of this kind of beer though, dulle teve 10 doesnt do much to rise out of the huge pack of similar tripels for me, too much spice and sweet, heavy, almost syrups, unsubtle.  Still very good but not my cup o tea right now.

Fresh, light and citrusy hop aroma with a light malt, hint of black pepper and some vinous notes.  Light golden color with a frothy-white head.  Malty, fruity, citrus flavors with a warming hint of alcohol.  Hint of a skunky, funky note in the finish, but it isnt bad. Lighter body, dry mouthfeel, very enjoyable.

750 ml bottle, thanks to Sprinkle for this beauty.  Pours a hazy, orangey golden color with a huge creamy white head that lingers well and leaves a bit of lace.  Aroma is sweet, spicy and yeasty, orange and clove with noticible alcohol.  Citrus and bready flavors, mellow summer fruits, more clove, coriander and alcohol.  Medium to full body, creamy carbonation.  Yummy!

Light yellow/orange pour with a thin head that holds a pineapple, grapefruit, acetone aroma.  High carbonation, with a strong honey strawberry overtone in the body and the alcohol isnt well hidden.  The alcohol flavor and bitterness continue to increase as the body warms.  Dry finish.

Pours a dark bronze amber with a ultra thick white head...that lasts and lasts and...goes away.  Aroma is yeasty...and is the first beer of de dolle that smells of bread.  Aroma is also a bit spicey, fruity sweet (citrus), and a tad malty.  Taste is very spicey and sweet...tons of fruit...tons of malt...healthy amount of alcohol...a bit acidic and sour (maybe a bit of bret)...rich caramel/honey...shit this is good.  This is a big beer...big in the american since...there is so much going on...very unexpected for a tripel.  Mouthfeel is crisp and wet...fairly light bodied...lets put is this way...I wouldnt want a six pack of these, an hour wait, and a speaking event.  This is definitely a great great beer.
Cloudy gold with a nice head.  The nose led to hints of dough, fruit and malt.  Nice and smooth with hops on the tongue.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2010 Hazy golden, huge head. Just as abstract as any de dolle beer, but not as complex.n A tripel that holds 10%..Fruits and hops. live carbonation! Not the best de dolle beer, but still a quality product!  Rerate Sep. 09. Vintage 3 years old bottle. Vinous, smooth, herbal, spicy. Very yeasty, some brett and tropical fruits. Complex and war. 3,8 - 3,9.  Re-rate Oktober 2010. Had 12 , 5 year old bottles in the cellar. Nose is complex. Tropcial fruit and dolle yeast. A bit of pepper. Wauuuwww.  Reminds me more and more of the Reserva edition. World class. 3,9 -4,1.

Sample at Indy tasting Dicks BBQ 3/31/06 - 2001 or 2002 bottle - Aroma is yeast, malt, apple, and citrus.  Pours golden with small head and decent lacing.  Flavor matches with some hop tartness in the back.  Palate is smooth and clean.  I have not had a freshy to compare, but this was an easy drinking  tasty brew.

12 oz bottle compliments of hezron

Shared with hezron and malachi.  Smells like orange peels, citrus and cherries with a very faint hint of hops.  The thin head sat on a light golden, mildly carbonated body.  Very flavorful - there was a distinct presence of hops along with orange peels, barnyard/earthy tastes and grapefruit.  Very easy to drink with a great finish.  Unfortunately, it is also a little pricy so Im not sure how often Ill be trying this one.
(Bottle at Delirium Cafe in Brussels): hazy golden color, malty aroma with a slight alcohol aftertaste.  A pretty solid brew with a good name.
Huge Huge head that goes quickly. Opaque strong yellow to orange color.   Intense Melon Apple nose.    It separates from the palate at the tail end and leaves you with a warming burn.
huge head, visible particles in a murky yellow appearance.  fruity aroma, kind of a apple jolly rancher.  carbonated mouthfeel with spice and fruit taste, alcohol noted.  nicely done.

UPDATED: NOV 5, 2007 Pours hazy light golden with a huge foamy off-white head. Aroma of intense fruity esters, notes of bubble gum, cantaloupe, honey, mango, coriander, and chamomile. Taste has notes of honey, herbs, and sugary sweet malts, and is lightly sweet and sticky. Mouthfeel is medium to heavy bodied with lush, lively carbonation. I bought two bottles of this, the first was pretty hot with a nice alcohol burn, but still scores a 3.9. After three weeks the second bottle was noticably more mellow and scored a 4.3. Give this one a little bit of time to age, but I wouldnt age them too long.

.345 l. bottle pored a hazy gold with a brown tint and a huge sudsy long lasting white head. Aromas of apples, pineapple, yeast and a hint of honey. Palate was light bodied and crisp. Flavors of apples, burnt sugar, pepper, and yeast with a warming sweet finish.

Ugly brown/bronze. Huge, foamy, sudsy, white head. Aroma of light fruits, sugar, malts, funky yeast, and subtle alcohol. Sugary sweet fruits up front, strong malt in the middle, crisp and lightly bitter hops and alcohol in the dry finish, stand by de dolle funky yeast underlying throughout. Burnt sugar and alcohol aftertaste. Medium/full body, well carbonated. Great after dinner tripel.

finally opened up the bottle jbrus sent me back in late 04. thanks john! useby sept 04 - so i guess that makes it 5 years old now. or 4 i dunno. anyway i was curious as to how tripels evolve. some of them seem too flimsy to survive the cellar but this one is robust enough in alcohol and body to work with the slight oxidation. beautiful to look at, a bright pale amber (like, the colour of amber itself rather than the colour of an "amber ale") with the most enormous creamy rocky head that sticks around forever. having only had the calvados-aged dulle teve before i was amazed that this one smells very similar - theres a definite apple ester in there. i guess thats why they aged it in calvados casks. brilliant. along with apple i got peach, crisp german hops, rich caramel and brown sugar, and dough and leather from the yeast. very complex and unique aroma. it shows its age once you taste it - the raisiny finger of Oxidation (the 5th horseman of the apocalypse) has tainted this beer. After a couple of sips I decided that this wasnt a bad thing, in fact it works well. all the bitterness that this beer must have had is gone, leaving a mellow, warm, very fruity and alcoholic and sweet beer. caramel and strawberries and sherry. but dry and with traces of herbal hops in the finish. a delicious tropical fruit tartness lingers. yummy, a powerful and hefty tripel that is a real tripel, caramelly and robust - nothing like the bush blond sort of souped up duvels that you get. i would love to try this fresh.

Definitly one hell of a beer. Flavor is full of alcohol with the usual yeast flavor that belgians have and has a very dry aftertaste with the alcohol sticking around in your mouth for a while like taking a shot. I am really picky with belgians, and while some i absolutly love, there are many highly rated that really dont tickle my fancy. This is kind of one of those. While it is a good beer and im not complainin to much, i just wouldnt buy it again.

33 cl bottle. Yeast at the bottom. amber colour with a nice head. Great smooth aroma of yeast, orange, caramel and hints of alcohol. Very alcoholic flavour with notes of yeast, caramel and ends very dry with a high carbonation.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2006 12 oz bottle. Pours a hazy pale yellow with a thick white head that lasts a while.  Smells very sweet with a slight almond  and earthy aroma.  The taste is very sharp and sweet at first, with an incredibly smooth malty finish.  The abbey has an incredibly bubbly yet smooth mouthfeel, with just a slight warm alcohol tingle.  Highly reccomended.  Im not sure the going price elsewhere, but here, single bottles of this stuff is usually $4.95, but Davis Liquor had these on sale for $1.99 each!  For me, a steal.

From bottle.  Poured with a lot of beautiful head.  Smells of citrus and spices very strong, very refreshing.  The color is a murky blonde, cannot see through the beer.  The taste is great as well. I am surprised it was a tripel,, drinking it I was thinking Belgian Ale/Blonde all the way.  I was extremely surprised by the 10% alcohol, I would not have figured more than 7, very well hidden.  The body is a heavy medium.  A refreshing feeling going down the throat.  Great brew.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: [bottle from dorsvlegel] Pours an orangey colour with a bit fluffy head. Lots of fruity aromas, orange, peac, banana also cloves, yeast. full bodied with a bit of alcohol in the finish.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2006 Lots of carbonation. Some spice and lighter fruits, I thought it felt a little yeasty. And the alcohol certainly came through a bit. Re rate: Bottle: Hazy yellow orange, big white head. Aroma, spicy, yeast, corriander and banana. Flavor, yeast, bready mouthfeel, light citric notes, some mild spicing. A little warming on the tail end. Good stuff.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2011 Bottle at The Kulminator, Antwerp.  Not sure what year this one was but the label said bottled in 07/96.  Cloudy gold colour.  Lovely caramel aroma.  Sweetish in mouth.  Just an unbelievable beer.  Raisins/sultanas.  Slightly musty. Some plastic/rubber aroma.  Bizarre, but hops are superb.  Bottle a more up to date bottle, so will re-rate later.  Re-rate.  As one of the beers that puts me in a completely different state of mind, the best beer to do that.  Takes me on a journey no other beer can.  Truly frightening, but also a beer I really adore. Re-rate 3/1/10.  Bottle I had been keeping for a couple of years in a box and then decided to open as hops go off??  But its a freakin Tripel you idiot!!!  But yes, it has improved definitely with Im guessing here 2-3 years age at least.  Poured into an Oerbier glass without getting any of the yeast in the glass, then decanted into a De Molen tasting glass.  Golden orange with a slight hae and lasting off white head.  Aroma of jellied fruits like orange, tangerine and lime.  But also some puke as well, which I have to admit I dont mind on this.  Some esters delivering vanilla and over-ripe banana.  Keeps the carbonation and condition remarkably well given the age and the decanting.  Very firm in the mouth, somewhere between silky and syrupy.  Flavours on the swallow have some pepper and herb and the finish has some definite hop bite.  Blow me!! this is an exceptional beer.  Some residual puke flavour does run through it.  Which is why I think it is a special beer.  It has a bunch of faults, but there are some amazing flavours and aromas and it makes me FEEL different to any other beer.  The mouthfeel and swallow are sublime, almost perfect and this pepper and slight heat on the end with expanding jellied tangerine and lime are just totally wonderful.  A once in a lifetime beer that Ive had several times.  Must buy more.  It is fabulous.

Has a rather unattractive aroma that is mostly dominated by a medicinal scent.  Pours a dark gold with a big fizzy white head.  Flavor is pretty big on the alcohol, but there is a rather delightful sweet malt finish.  I guess Im not a big fan of tripels, or at least these last two that I had.

On tap at Lucky Baldwins Belgian Beer Fest 2006 in Pasadena. Cloudy bright gold, beautiful color. Thin coating of white bubbles that left excellent lacing. Aroma is sweet malts and light hops, very crisp. Grainy malt and light, indistinct hop flavor. Becomes increasingly sweet as the glass wears on. Pear note. Quite carbonated on the palate with medium body. The alcohol is strong on the palate, too strong.. would be a much better beer with less apparent alcohol.

Luckgirls review is spot on. Ill add that I smell and taste a hint of wood. This is an extreme beer and unlike any triple youve had, youll either love it or hate it. I love it! Aside from the outrageous carbonation I enjoy every aspect of this brew. One of my favorites.

From a 75ml into a snifter. Beer pours a hazy, light amber-gold color with a huge, off-white, rocky, quickly diminishing, mostly lasting head. The aroma fits the nameits floral, sweet, ballsy, complex and beautiful! Lightly malty with a note of toasted grain; a moderate note of hoppy herbs (dill), pine and a trace of grapefruit; heavily yeasty with a note of soap and a trace of cellar; and packed with strong, juicy, miscellaneous notes of flowers like rosewater and honeysuckle, and esters of white grape, coriander, honey and a trace of mustard powder. The flavor is heavily sweet, lightly bitter with a long, lightly acidic, moderately warm, moderately bitter finish. The body is medium-to-full, the texture is watery and the carbonation is lively. This is a work of art and an obvious labor of lovea super star!

Pours out a cloudy golden color with a big frothy white head, very carbonated.  Aroma is sweet and fruity. Taste is very complex and well balanced with notes of fruit mostly apple pear and maybe some grape here or there. This was quite the beer, like the name too.

Golden body with a good gold head.  Heavy carbonation.  Very nice citrus and sweet fruits are evident in the aroma, very pleasing.  Sweet grapes very present in the taste, yeast is noticeable.  Almost a white wine type taste.  Extremely pleasent ending, very smooth.
Pours a cloudy yellow with a huge foamy white head. Almost champagne like. Fruity, yeasty aroma of apple, pear, grape and cherry. Sweet fruity taste. Very lively and assertive body.
Hazy golden color with a thick frothy white head. Aroma of spice and banana. Sweet malty flavor but somewhat sour with some bitter notes.
buy it and enjoy it, rich aroma with an awesome sparkling color.  Heavy flavor and what A BIATCH!!!!

330 mL bottle.  Pours cloudy straw gold (harvest moon) with a large foamy white head, lasts a good while yet calms down a bit.  Aroma is freshly baked buttery bread and sweet fruit (grape, apple, pear) and yeast, malt (biscuit).  Fizzy, biting spicy sour fruit and buttered bread, low sweetness and medium acidity, bitterness.  Medium bodied and warm, spicy palate.

Another beer that an old friend brought over for a night of tasting. Incredible aroma of yeast, some apricots, flowers. Hazy orange-amber hues. Very nice, very hard to find. The Mad Bitch is a nice trippel.

bottle - Brigids (Philadelphia) - one of my favorite tripels.  Not overly clovey or bannanany - crisp, full malt body with great hops to back it up.  Only minor complaint was that it was a bit fizzy and the mouthfeel could have been a bit softer.  Other than that, this rivals La Chouffe fresh over there.
Much carbonation sparkling. Aroma is balanced taste too much alcohol,.but it was fruity. It should be more sour

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2007 pours a translucent copperish color, with a gigantic white foamy head, aroma of sweet malts, citrus and belgian style spices, the flavor is spicey and sweet with a dry finish, alcohol is present in the flavor as well, good solid body, decent brew.

UPDATED: SEP 16, 2007 Bottled. Extremely alive, abundant and bulky head. Persistent and impenetrable cream, optimal duration. Orange clearly color, much torbid and hazy one. Richest and powerful scent; honey notes, spices, wine cellar and flowers with an overbearing and decided alcohol. Much fizzy and solid taste. Impossible (for me at least) drink large swig. Dense and too much alcoholic. A lot perfumed and balsamic in the nose. Long, warm and persistent end. Too much excesses.

2002 bottle.  mostly clear & bright golden yellow color with lots of fizz.  voluptuous white merangue head, with peaks like egg whites beat by an electric mixer.  aroma is sweet bready, yeasty malt, lemon & pineapple.  flavor is spicy and candi sugar malt, some dryness and a bit of alcohol.  dry/sweet aftertaste that is well balanced.  kind of like a white wine aftertaste.  a little fresh lemon peel too.  well worth the wait!

33cl bottle Hazy goleden with lots of head. Sweet yeasty aroma. Great flavor with sweet citrus and spice.  Lots of yeast. Fished suprisingly dry and bitter. A very interesting triple. Not sure if i could drink a lot of this.

(12.28.05) 11.2 oz (330 mL) brown bottle purchased from DiCarlos, Mundelein, IL.  10% ABV.  Overly carbonated hazy golden yellow Belgium ale that nearly exploded out of my chilled bottle when opened.  Brewing error or infection?  Very frothy. Sweet fruity aroma. Light-to-medium bodied that starts dry with fruity, earthy, sour, leathery flavors. Finishes dry with slight medicinal (adhesive bandage) flavors.  Some alcoholic warmth noted. Though not my favorite De Dolle beer, this is an interesting drinkable Belgium ale. Not for the timid.

Bottle. Hazy amber beer with a huge off-white head. Yeasty/spicey aroma with a bit of mustiness and some skunkiness. Nice yeasty flavor with fruit and malt before the alcohol takes over. Nice complexity. Finishes dry. Ive had better - too dry at the end and the alcohol is too forward.

UPDATED: APR 23, 2006 Pours a hazy orange amber with a large off white head and small floaties that left bubbly lacing.  Aroma of fruits and caramel with some some spice, yeast and apples.  Flavor is peppery, fruity with even a bit of a roastiness which kind of surprised me.  Overall a very nice experience from a brewery that has really impressed me.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2006 Opaque golden yellow-orange in color with a huge white foamy head that last a long time.  The aroma is really nice, citrusy and yeasty.  The flavor is spicy and fruity, and it really grows on me as I drink it.  Very complex.  The mouthfeel is  full-bodied with a very lively carbonation.  Very good overall; Ill drink this again for sure.

UPDATED: JUN 15, 2006 Bottle, probably old given the dust collecting about the neck.  Lightly hazy, golden colored with an eruptive white head that lingers indefinately.  Dense lacing collects on the side of the glass.  Funk and coriander in aroma.  LIght bodied, highly carbonated.  Spicy coriander and a funky yeast presence in flavor.  Moderately sour.  Perhaps not really a tripel at this time, if infected it worked nicely anyway.

Hazy orange and sparkling. Aroma is great, alcohol, orange, grass and yeast. Indicates that I now will taste a great beer. And it is! Fruity, sweet and yeasty and warming alcohol. I love this brewery!

Bottle gusher, big time. My Orval goblet was about 90% head with less than half of the bottle poured. Head finally receded, nice and rocky. Color is a super hazy goldenrod with copper highlights. Lots of fine sediment. Nose is mad yeast, like a diabetic womans snatch. Also some malt here and there in the nose as well. Taste is some light malts up front along with the yeast, but sadly, this one was dominated by lots and lots of alcohol. There is some nice subtle spicing and vanilla oak notes that do complement this brew rather nicely. Finishes somewhat sweet. Could use some more body and texture enhancement, as this one is not that great feeling in the mouth. Solid. I need to age one and see if the alcohol mellows out. This has potential.

Poured a cloudy yellowish orange body with a large head. Aroma is spices, yeast, citrus, and light acidity. Got better as it warmed. I believe my bottle said this was 8%ABV and not 10, but whatever. Good stuff.

Bottled Bitches! Pours a lovely cloudy yellow with a thick and lasting head that lets me know that this will be another highly fizzy De Dolle affair. Absolutely gorgeous. At this point I will quit being a ratebeer geek and start rating like the true Dermite that I am. Mafuckers keep talkin bout floaties in their wack ass ratings but I aint tryin to hear that shit. This mafucker looks just like Hoegaarden or something. This sumbitch has a head that looks like a big fluffy white pillow or your mommas cellulite ridden ass if the wrinkles were replaced with bubbles. Ima keep it real wicha man. This bastard smelled like my armpits after I finished moving like eight kegs at work at first. But I got over that because Im used to the smell of my armpits. Eventually this beer reminded me of that yella rock candy I used to get at the North Cackalack Museum of Life N Science. You know, the one that was artificial banana flavored. Except this one had thyme in it or something.  So I got tired of smelling this shit and decided it was time to get all kinds of bamboozled off the drank. Definitely a tripel. All kinds of banana flavors with a bit of citrus tang and rhubarb. The yeast is ever present and your mother never liked you. I enjoyed the hell out of this beer and I enjoyed rating it. Ive dealt with many mad bitches in my day and if all of them would have been this easy to deal with Id open my own Mad Bitch sanctuary. Unfortunately, this beer has a misleading name. I would have named it the Flemish equivalent of Fuck Buddy and left it at that. Nahmeanson??!!??!!? This mafucker aint so pretty on the palate. Rough on your tongue and it coats your mouth with a syrupy film. But I would be goddamned if I didnt go back to this one from time to time until it got too expensive to take on more dates. Thus ends my Dermite style rating of Belgian beer.

33cL bottle.  Horizontal with Special Reserva.  I try to rate a different top shelf beer during Monday Night Football.  Week ten.  Cowboys vs. Eagles.  Keyshawn vs T.O.  Perfect for a Mad Bitch horizontal.  Then TO had to go and get suspended.  Thanks a lot, T.O.!!
Anyway, this was a beautiful pour.  Great head of tiny bubbles with a lot of tiny floaties in there.  At first, the aroma was very yeasty and musty, but it got very sweet about mid-bottle with light fruit (mostly banana) and candy sugar.  By the end of the bottle, it really smelled like vanilla frosting.  At first, the mouthfeel was very sweet and fruity, like the aroma.  A very slight alcohol burn appeared midbottle, but disappeared quickly and was replaced with vanilla and candy sugars.  Gets exponentially drier as it warmed to room temp.  Finishes sweet and dry.  All in all its a top shelf tripel, and I really cant decide if if its better after the barrel aging.  Thanks to Terry Boyd at Mountview in Naugatuck, CT for this one!

The mad bitch certainly bites. This was a lovely slow quaffer that certainly went down easier than an argument with your old lady. Poured into a 50cL chalice at around 10°C after a good year in the cellar. Head rose from the pour, another lively De Dolle, and with the 33cL bottle size it still filled the glass with head and rose a good inch from out its brim. Floaties were in abundance, like pulped oranges and spent hop buds, amid a hazy and almost opaque orangey gold body. Disappointingly subtle in the aroma (most of the action seemed to go into the head). Soft apple and cinnamon nose with a little pepper and doughy yeast. It smelt like apple crumble dessert. Quite sweet, smooth and creamy in the mouth. Toffee and toasted malt seemed to dominate the palate, with some bready yeast and a late hit of soft citric fruits like cantaloupe and grapefruit, before a warming and smooth toffee malt swallow. The alcohol, for its strength, was beautifully controlled especially with its silky and full mouthfeel. A lot more simple than I expected. I love a good Tripel and this just laued in that dividing line of style. Lovely, without definition. (33cL, age unknown, Intl Beer Shop, W. Leederville)

bottle. murky orange-brown with little specks of yeast sediment and a long-lasting rocky off-white head. full complex yeasty aroma - notes of sweet banana, prunes, raisins, and chocolate. this beer is very rich and takes a long time to drink, though Im not saying thats a bad thing! smooth creamy body. sweet cereal/oat and yeast flavours with lots of fruit essence and spice. alcohol is felt throughout but isnt overwhelming at all. the finish has some bittersweet chocolate and stays with you for a while. superb stuff. Ill have to pick up more bottles.

Perhaps the most straightforward beer Ive had from De Dolle and not at all in a bad way. It is a solid abbey tripel, nice yeasty, bready, a bit fruity and slightly alcoholic nose. Spicy, well-balanced, earthy, nice warm finish.

Bottle, 33cl. Very nice this Mad Bitch!  Hazy orange colour with a huge white (almost beige) head, fully lasting. Nice lacing. Body is full of yeasty particules. Aroma is moderately yeasty, with notes of fruits (lemon and oranges) and spices. Smells almost like champagne. Flavour is smooth but complex, slightly alcoholic. Perhaps less carbonation would make this a better beer. Very good but not superb.
Bottle @ Akkurat, StockholmWow! Rich aroma of everything you want and expect from a Belgian strong blonde/tripel. Rich, complex fruitiness balanced by a body worth dying for. Gimme more!
Aroma of parma violets and floural hops with some intresing pears going on too. Taste is also floural, with some bittering pulrple is how i put it hoips, with alcohol giving it a great warming.

Mostly clear amber body, with some sandy particles roaming around, and some champagne fizz bubbling up from the botttom. Large frothy white head.
Semi-sharp belgian yeasty fruit aroma, some sweet caramel backing. 
Way too fizzy of a body to start. Dry yeasty body. Sweet flowers and pear. Sweet leafy weedy hops. Some green sweet plant stems after a while. 
A bit warming with alcohol, even the first sip. Maybe that was the heavy carbonation. Sorry, Just dont like stuff that immediately fizzes in my mouth once it goes past my lips.

sweet rich and very drinkable.  a beer that doesnt leave a bad impression, thats for sure.  pours yellow with a thick white head that will not go away despite having the glass sit on the counter for 10 minutes or so.  taste is sweet, somewhat malty and rich.  very good tripel - not the most drinkable, but certainly worh the try.  these guys dont make bad brews that i know of, so why not get one today?

I like it! Super bubbly, citrus/spice complex flavor that has a comfortable lingering bitterness in the aftertaste. Its missing a little something for me though.... taste didnt develop enough throughout the bottle.

As befitting the label, this is one of the worlds scariest beers.  The overriding flavor was that of dissolved tobacco smoke, which permeated the whole experience.  To be sure, the beer was inadequately refrigerated, but this was definitely a once-in-a-lifetime experience.
Deep blond beer, huge white foam and malty, fruity and hoppy aroma. Taste is massive, slight spicy has fruity touches and is sweet hoppy. This beer has a powerfull afthertaste.
Orange almost solid beer with a huge, lasting head. Lots of fruits (orange and pear) in the aroma. Spicy taste, quite spiritous with good balance. Sweet, quite long aftertaste. Very nice triple.
Bottle. Nose-doughy, yeasty, alcohol. Deep yellow body with nice lasting lacing. Taste-reminds me of a souped up saison-very spicy, earthy, and doughy. Sticky sweet finish.

Aroma: pear, malt and candy sweetness. Definite hint of spiritousness. Appearance: golden with large particles and low flocculant yeast. Solid fluffy headand merangue lacing sticking to the glass. Flavour: sweet malt, spiritous and balanced by a large hop flavour and strong bitterness. Palate: lingering sweetness and bitterness with an aftertaste of banana and bubblegum.

Huge, creamy white head, which takes forever to subside makes a nice contrast with the dark-orange opaque body. An aroma of yeasty bread hangs around it before I even lift it up to smell properly. Up close it smells more of spicy fruit with the signature de Dolle yeast aroma profile. Powerful, broad taste of bread, coriander, yeast with quite a bit of alcohol heat and a good deal of bitterness at the end. The bitterness is mostly overpowered by the taste, however. Very harmonic, yet complex. An extraordinary beer! Very, very good. Has to be one of the best trippels Ive had, mad or sane. (0.33l bottle.)

Pours a cloudy honey colour with a thick lasting head. Aromas of spicy belgian yeast, pepper, and some alcohol. Very big yeast flavour, malt, lingering after taste with noticeable alcohol. It should be noted that the alcohol softened as the brew warmed. Good but not my favorite.

Hazy orange colour with a small white head. Malty and spicy aroma with a light fruityness and hints of some alcohol sweetness. Fruity, light sweet flavor, with a typical De Dolle yeastyness. Sweet light peppery finish.

Pours a lovely hazy gold with a gigantic white head and lots of effervescence. As the head recedes (slowly, leaving lots of lacing), the middle remainsa white, pockmarked ziggurat of foam. Very spicy aroma. I dont know my spices very well, so thats about all I can tell you. I can pick out some pepper. Apart from the spices, its bready, yeasty, and a little salty. The spiciness is in the flavor (especially the pepper, which comes through clearly in the finish). Theres a little bit of funk, some wood, a lambic-like sourness, and a surprising dose of hops at the end. Unlike any Tripel Ive tried before. With a little tweaking, it could contend with Allagashs.

Hum the Bitch is Back, okay now that is out of my system onwards with the rating, served in my GL mini snifter: Poured a beautiful golden hue with a huge bubbly head and sticky lace. The aroma has notes of bready and herbal esters, a light yeasty funk, acidic fruit vapors and a hint of aromatic bitters. The taste is shocking with its sour tang and bready overtones with a dash of pepper, clove, and cardmom on the finish. Woody and earthy characteristics are found within as well but I am in the minority here but I enjoyed the Reserva flavors and complexity more than what I found here. This is too twangy for a Tripel IMO. The feel is quite light considering the ABV and style. I am sure what to make of this, everything I sense says to me this is not all that great and perhaps is still too young.

Gusher!  Pours a gorgeous golden body with an incredible billowy head that lasts.  Great lacing as well!  Aroma is sweet and hoppy, almost a sour cherry smell in there.  Excellent belgian spices in there, as well.  Almost smells like a gueze.  Flavor is very dry, apple skin, hops lend amazing bitterness, malts balance with a slight toast flavor.  Very grassy, dry finish.  Spot on.

Pours a cloudy yellow with a large frothy white head.  Aroma of sweet cherries and grapes, alcohol, and grass.  Taste is very aggressive with notes of grapes, apples, pears, grassy and piney hops, and a strong alcohol kick.  Medium fizzy body.  Light and delicous... I loved this.

My wife was "in a mood" and just had to toss down a mad bitch. Poured a hazy amber with a HUGE, large-bubbled head. Excellent Belgian presence in aroma with musty "basement" yeasts, coriander, apple and big alcohol late. Pronounced yeastiness in flavor with moderate sweetness to finish, yet not as sweet as other tripels weve tried. Lively carbonation tried to dispel the alcoholic finish without much luck.
<font size=-4>From bottle at <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Place Restaurant and Beer Garden, LaGrange, IL<font size=-1>

Cloudy golden dark blond with tipical De Dolle foam. Aroma is dry, spicy, white pepper, fresh herbs, has a Duvel or triple like maltyness (very dry) and slight lemony fruity. The taste is pilsmalty and very massive. Pepper, bread yeast, green herbs, biscuits and loads of hops. Afthertaste is clear and very powerfull. watch out, this is quit a heavey brew.

Hazy, dull gold in color with an amoebic growth pattern taking place on top of a frothy white head.  Nice sticky lacing as we go.  Aroma leads in with fresh white bread, pepper, cloves, corn husks, coriander, candi sugar and lemon zest.  Quite the zinger.  Flavor is big time bliss.  Perfumey hops sprits the palate, closely followed by doughy biscuits, mute bananas, cornmeal, pepper and coriander.  Some datylic alcohol amidst the malty muskiness, but the prevailing verbose sweetness is right up my alley and perfect for where I think a tripel should be.  Prickling and palate engulfing with ample carbonation, finishing with spicy hops and crescent rolls pulled out of the over two minutes too soon.  Very nice indeed.
hazy yellow w/ off white head.  yeasty aroma of citrus and cloves.  sweet, full bodied w/ bitter aftertaste.

Sweet malt. yeasty aroma. A lot of mashed fruit smells. Cloudy brown/orange color with a thick white head. Sweet fruit fore then a very creamy cereal-like middle and a VERY malty finish.  Odd flavor sequence, but this does taste good though the after taste makes me feel like I burped up this mornings Total Raisin Bran.

14 Jun 2005 - Sweet hoppy apricot fruit aroma.  Cloudy light brown-orange colour, with a long lasting head and lacing.  Light apricot fruit and big hop flavour.  Too hoppy for me.  Bitter dry hop finish, lingering fruit and medium mouthfeel.  Overall, for the hop-hop freaks this may suit them, but for me this is ...t gek en teve voor mij (to much of a crazy bitch for me).

The chilled and gently handled bottle foamed over immediately upon opening. It poured an apricot colored cloudy beer with an ample rocky white head that dissipated quickly and settled to a nice small, thick foam that lasted throughout and left nice lacing on the glass. There were wonderfully rich aromas that presented themselves with significant notes of clove and orange. It had a medium body with significant carbonation and a slightly dry texture. The complex flavors began with a big fruity sweetness. As the flavor matured, some hop bitterness began to balance the malt sweetness and it began to dry out. The finish is quite long with a slight sweet dryness about it. The high alcohol content brings a lasting warmth to the finish as well.

Bottle. Best Pour Ever. STarts out clear gold w/ a huge white rocky head. Head resides to leave a nice island in teh middle of the brew. On second look, beer is clear gold on the bottom, then gradually gets cloudier and light brown colored. Lots of swirling sediment. Nose is very yeasty and fresh with some light caramel and sweet sugary notes. Taste is big caramel up front then leads to some light hopps, yeast and grass notes. A stingy, refreshing feeling on the tongue leads to a slight alcohol warming throughout the entire mouth.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, blankboy & tupalev - courtesy of HogTownHarry. Bright gold with a large white head and lots & lots of small floaties. Big aroma of yeast, spice, oranges and band-aids. Soft mouthfeel. Flavour starts with light fruit notes, but turns warm & boozy, with a suprising little hop kick in the finish. As my tasting mates suggest, the alcohol could be brought down a notch or two, but its sill quite an interesting beer.

UPDATED: SEP 18, 2005 Pours a hazy yellow-orange with a big, long lasting head and a bit of sediment. A nice full aroma of fruit (citrus and abricot), and alcohol. Has a strong effect in the back of the throat (it might be good if you have a cough) Banana flavors (especially) in the finish. A very nice tripel.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow & blankboy - courtesy of Harry.  Dark yellow, small white head, lots of floaties.  Bottle continued to foam out of the bottle , even as we half poured it and let it sit - weird. Strong alcohol in aroma.  Slight citrus and light malt as well, but who am I kidding this was all alcohol.  Taste was very strong as well.  Surprisingly though, I thought it made a good effort to balance itself off and it became a very enjoyable beer as I sipped it (the last one of a 19 sample night).  Some strong banana flavours emerged as well.  Not overly complex, but a strong and tasty brew that I am having a hard time describing (not for the first time).  Recommended, weird label, name, and all.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a cloudy yellow with some sediment, and an average to large white head. Mild fruity aroma with some citrus, yeast, spices and alcohol. First thing you notice in the flavour is the alcohol, its strong!, but at the same time its really tasty. A nice blend of hops, malt, fruit and spices that I enjoyed. If the alcohol was tamed down a bit more my rating would have been even higher, as it is I still recommend it.

Bottle (330ml). Shared with blankboy, GregClow and tupalev - bottle from my stash.  Poured a murky amber-yellow with a huge - huge - white foaming head.  Aroma was banana, lemon-citrus - alcohol! - sharp yeast - alcohol! - some pine resin, papaya and ... alcohol.  Taste is, of course, strongly, almost burningly alcohol, but after that dies down a bit, it follows the nose, with an added hint of chocolate toffee.  Mouthfeel is sticky and alcoholic.  This is probably a terrific Trippel under all of that booze, but the burn IS off-putting.

Hazy and orange-yellow.
Apricot aroma with notes of yeast and apple. Maltsweet, clean and fresh.
Some sweetness in the mouth. Dry and alcoholic.

Thanks to Secret Santa for this one.  Poured turbid dark straw/copper/orangish with huge white head.  Complex, big aroma that contained harsh citrus and barnyard elements, plus hops, spices, some fruit.  The taste was hopcity, with spices, apricot, malt, Brett, and a firm, complex, slightly harsh mouthfeel.  The finish was complex and slightly astringent, in a good way.  As it warmed, I noted chardonnay and even canteloupe hints.  Im happy they decided to name a beer after my wife.

Couleur orangée à lapparence nuageuse.  Moyenne quantité de mousse compacte et blanche concassée.  Arômes estérifiés, pêches, gomme baloune à lorange émergent dun liquide aux tendances levurées et sucrées.  Très alcoolique en bouche, puis sucré..sucre candi, le style semble bien représenté.  Carbonatation très piquante, corps dépaisseur moyenne propulsé par une carbonatation marquée, de fines bulles.  Finale ramenant le sucre.  Bouteille, Charlies Liquor, Boston, Janvier 2005.
Cant understand the infatuation with this one.  My only thought throughout drinking this beer was alcohol, alcohol, alcohol.  Ive had much better with higher alcohol percentages.

Bottle:  Aroma is a nice blend of strong citrus, yeast, clove, and light pepper.   Pours a dull cloudy yellowish-orange with a huge off-white head with excellent retention.   Flavor is sweet citrus and yeast up front.  Finish has lots of orange peel, lots of spice (clove and maybe ginger), and light pepper, as well as a light acidity.  Its about time Ive tried this considering how many times Ive passed it by assuming I already had.  A very good beer and definitely one of their best.  The best Tripel Ive had so far.

Marcellos Wine Market - Baton Rouge, La - .33 litre bottle. Pours a medium golden - slighlty murky with a thick, frothy white head that leaves a thick coating of lacing. Sweet, malty aroma of kids vitamins and a bit of cocoa. Sweet, syrupy flavor - maple syrup to be exact. Some chocolate in there as well. Alcohol is evident and very warming - would be better to save this one for winter. Thick, chewy mouthfeel. Very decent little Tripel.

Poured a HUGE head, with carbonation jumping in the glass. First sip burned me pretty good, but nice flavor, opened up the tongue! As it warmed, got much better, alcohol flavor subsided. Citrus and spice dominate to me. Good stuff!

UPDATED: FEB 3, 2013 First rating: 6/4/6/3/13 total 3.2. Big fluffy white head and a golden-orange colour. The aroma is sweet and fruity. A flavour of smooth malt and orange. There is a hoppy aftertaste (with some alcohol noticeable). (Bottle 33cl)
New rating: Big fluffy white head and a golden-orange colour. Very fresh fruity and medium sweet aroma. A flavour of smooth malt and orange. There is a hoppy aftertaste (with some alcohol noticeable). (Bottle 33cl)

Big head on a dirty gold liquid. Light mellon and alcohol aroma. Very interesting milk and caramel flavour. Traces of maple syrup and alcohol. Delicious flavourful beer without an overpowering alcohol.

Murky golden color with a huge foamy white head out of the bottle.  Almost pungent aroma of yeast and feet, with some spicey orange tones.  Very carbonated on the tongue.  Yeasty flavors with sweet orange and tangerine citrus flavors.  Very nice Tripel, but the label is sort of freaking me out.

Bottle. Aroma is very nice, yeasty and powerful, fruity and citric. Unclear, golden colour. The head is white, fluffy and creamy, big and stable. Quite alcoholic tasting. A little sweet and fruity. The bitterness is a little bit harsh, but I guess that is OK for a tripel.
Hazy bubbly amber with a nice aroma. Lots of flavour, good stuff.

Cloudy yellow-brown, large particles of yeasty sediment, massive foamy head leading to extensive lace. Huge aromas of tropical fruit, especially bananas, orange, and as it warmed, vanilla and sweet spices. This got better as it warmed! Heavy full mouth feel, but the alcohol is well supported by the flavours. Ive only tried a handful of Belgian beers, and in particular this is my first triple-- it really is fantastic.
user_location: the land of bitumen, beef & beer, Alberta, CANADA

text: From a bomber.  The only date I could find on the label was 1998, but that may have just been the date of the artwork on the bottle.  Pours copper with a huge white fluffy head and some excellent lacing that sticks around.  Some floaties can been seen in the glass.  The first smells present reminded me of a good gueuze.  Smells of straw, barnyard, cane sugar, and yogurt.  Tastes of grapes, citrus and other fruits with a vegetal finish and an excellent tingly mouthfeel.  This one is definitely a keeper.

Orange/amber color body with lots of floaties and a big offwhite foaming and lacing head.  Aroma of smoke spice and light sweetness.  tast of spice, mild sweet citrus.  Creamy mouthfeel with spice in the back of the tongue.
Vintage 01.  The carbonation was still extremely high for its age but the flavor was just right.  A bit on the barny funk side for a tripel but I didnt mind one bit.

Bottle. Hazy gold coloured, huge white head, floaty sediment. Citrus and spicey aroma. Flavour is complex and very nice, I think Ive just found my favourite tripel; spicey, fruity, wheaty, barnyardy. Full bodied, quite highly carbonated, well hid alcohol. Excellent.
Sweet hop aroma. Cloudy yellow amber colour with excellent head and lacing. Strong malt hop spiritus flavour. Fizzy palate.

750 ml bottle- unknown year.  Pours a thick medium golden color with a nice lasting head and good lace. Aroma is initially fruity with some apricot, peach, melon, then it is somewhat spicy with some pepper.  Also lots and lots of yeast in the flavor and aroma along with some cork, and other funky earthy smells.  Flavor is medium sweet and full bodied.  Lots of esters, fruits, and some spice in the end.  Moderate alcohol warming, but it is a relatively big bodied tripel, so the abv is hidden well.  Similar to westmalle but perhaps more complex with more of a yeasty profile.  Very smooth in the end.

Bottle (2002): Cloudy pale golden, large white fizzy head, fairly nice lacing, tremendous carbonation, with some large yeastie chunks floating about. &nbsp Floral & wheaty nose, somewhat musty/barnish, and even a bit candyish (pixie stix). &nbsp Very wheaty in the mouth, airy, with a some floral aspects that become somewhat biting at the end. &nbsp Moderate body and mouthfeel, nearing fullness but it was just too airy. &nbsp Finish was somewhat rough. &nbsp Comes across as a Saison mated with a Belgian Golden. &nbsp Not bad, but perhaps it needs more time to mellow out. &nbsp Thanks mattbob!

A fierce, thin-bodied Belgian tripel. Love the brewer but dont rate this. Poured a cloudy pale orange with a volcanic head that took an eternity to simmer down. Nice lacework. Loads of yeast in the aroma, plus peppery alcohol, cloves and peaches. Very fizzy in the mouth, and thin in the body for a tripel, only partially redeemed by that huge warming finish. Theres a pleasant oiliness to the mouthfeel once the carbonation settles down but that takes too long. The 10% abv is right upfront. The dominant flavours are pepper, honey, cloves and vanilla. I prefer the fusels to be more restrained. This was too clumsy and aggressive for my taste. (33cl bottle, International Beer Shop, Perth)

eric broke out this 2001 bottle for his tasting, and after this, i cant wait for the reserva...poured a cloudy orange with an enormous fluffy head, aroma of spices, citrus, and a little alcohol tanginess. flavor was spicy with a distinct hoppiness and a slightly sour twinge. some yeast and malts come on late, with a grassy aftertaste.  the alcohol gave a warming sensation, but didnt really affect the enjoyment of drinking it.

Gushed out of the bottle. Pours a lite amber with an enormous loose head. Aroma of higher alcohols, oranges and maybe some ginger and coriander. Flavor is med sweet with a rush of honey and straight phenols. Lite body with an enormous amount of CO2. Finish is quick and insubstantial. One of the poorer tripels Ive had. I think this was infected.

This one was four years old and it aged quite well. Carbonation was high and it was pretty cloudy in the glass. It was pretty farmy with a nice grass-like taste and mix of other elements. the mouthfeel is awesome on this one. It is very pleasant on the tongue.

Pour is a cloudy but bright yellow with a humongous white head that wont stop growing.  Aroma is bready and yeasty with lots of clove.  Flavor is complex.  I get lots of yeast and vanilla as i first sip then as I work my way down the glass I get spices and pepper.  A tasty beer experience and a little pricy but a nice b-day present for myself.  Also, alcohol is hidden well for a 10%.

2001... Poured a hazy golden color with a large white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of hay, yeast, citrus, caramel malts, spices, and yeast.  Taste of vanilla, citrus, yeast, lightly sour, and a good amount of alcohol.

Cloudy, with a giant head thats very very pale. Leaves puffs on the glass as you drink it. Vanilla and clover and peppery aromas. Sweet across the tongue, with a sour aftertaste. Yeasty along with the sour. Somewhat dry finish and nicely warming.

Cloudy (unfiltered) amber and translucent with a REALLY REALLY hyperactive head on it.  Smells sweat and bready.  Makes the mouth water.  Sweet attack with a broad, bready flavor that quickly evaporates into an alcoholic tang.

Flowers, black pepper, orange peel, and yeast aromas, maybe some vanilla and pear hints; sweet and crispy front end,  flavor consists of apples and grapes, tangy yeast and pineapple, wood and pepper; dry, sourish finish, with quite prevailant burning alcohol; this is good, but not one of the better tripels, I think... its a little too peppery and yeasty, for me
Ce grand brumeux dorée est une bière non filtrée et non pasteurisé, a un chaud arome de malte et un goût plein,  doux et amère.

Bottle. Probably shouldnt have tasted this straight after the Oerbier. Lovely hazy orange gold with a massive rocky white head which looked spectacular in my Duvel tulip. Orange peel and spicy alcohol dominate the aroma with acetyl notes and subtle hops in the background. Taste is dry and herbal, dominated by the warm alcoholic finish; the mad bitch definitely bites. Feel is good, but not up to the Oerbier.

(Bottle 33 cl) Hazy and dirty (as most Dolle brews), orangey golden with a huge head.... Lots of fruity esters, lots of yeast and rather complex aromas. Sweetness galore from the added candi-sugars but the hops make this drinkable indeed. An Abbey Tripel - really? 081296

beer pours a fizzy, hazy gold with a big bubbled head that retains well and laces in sheets. nose is huge, with strong earthy elements balanced by a big fruit charecter (lemon and berries), along with some yeasty spiciness. its a really complex nose, that keeps evolving as the beer warms and breathes. flavor is quite big, starting with a suprisingly thick and sweet maltiness that quickly washes away in a wave of herbal dryness. also notes of alcohol and phenol. mouthfeel is pretty good, as CO2 cuts the thickness well, but it is a little hot, and a little less than smooth.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2008 A Mes rate: one of the many bottles I have had from Dranken Geers.Figured it was time to re-rate this one. Beautiful dark gold colour with a thick and creamy white head and glorious condition. Typical De Dolle aroma. Lots of sweet yeasty notes that they do oh so well and some glorious hops with a fine malty backbone. Assertive as hell in mouth with lots of peppery spice, gorgeous sugary yeast and a very slight hint of that characteristic De Dolle sourness. Big alcohol on the finish that spoils it a bit for me but all in all a very enjoyable regular for me as are all the De Dolle beers to be honest.

Poured light orange with a huge off-white bubbly head. Almost looks like foam. Yeast sediment is noticable. A sweet and sour spicey aroma with hints of lighter fruits: banana, pear, peach, apricot, lemon, and orange. Citrusy taste: apricot, orange, and pepper. Dry finish with a sour aftertaste. A little warming in the finish as well.

Huge white head on top of a hazy dull lemon yellow body. Aroma of banana, marshmallows and spice. Citrus, wheat, some pears in the taste, good carbonation, some taste of pepper (due to the alcohol?), dry and a touch sour.
Bottle.  Classic tripel with de dolle slant. Cloudy ale, with upfront bready and yeasty flavors giving way to some sweet pear taste and crisp finish.

Cloudy wheat appearance with firm white head. Tastes of banana and citrus with substantial wheaty malt foundation. Sweet and slight spices. Excellent mouthfeel for a triple. More lush than Golden Monkey, but I love the GM combo of spices. Could not detect the abv at all. Easiest 10% Ive had- potentially dangerous.

Hazy dark gold in colour with a dense, bubbly white head.  Aromas are sweet lemon and spices, quite mellow and dry with alcohol.  Flavours are dry, bitter, yet mellowed lemon.  Fruity and quite sweet.  The alchohol is warming rather than aggressive.  Has a superb "foam in the mouth" palate.  Not the best De Dolle, still pretty good.

bottle. Floating  solids in a hazy, viscous suspension.    Rich grapefruit color with a head that lingers.  Citrus is a strong flavor here with  sour apples and yeast.  Finishes short and dry.  I was expecting more, it just lacked umph in all areas.
a wheaty, cloudy color.  bready in aroma, raisony in flavor.  a mouthful of fruit.  didnt get much of a reaction from me.

Overly sweet with wildly difficult-to-describe fruit notes that seem to confuse more than please...Complex? Yeah, I guess, but seems more like confusion.  Ill have another and rerate at a later date.
Golden with big white head. Spicy sweet aroma with hints of alcohol. Big  spicy sweet taste with notes of alcohol. Lasting spicy aftertaste

pours a dark hazy golden color.huge rocky head. lacing is superior to any ive seen before. huge sticky gobs of puffy white lace. aroma is sweet and fruity and a little musty. tastes of spice, apricot, and alcohol which is subtle and not overpowering. mouth feel is dry and lightly tart.

I like these mad brewers.  The brew poured a hazy apricot color with a chunky white head.  The aroma is fruity and spicy with a goodly degree of tartness.  You could spend some serious amount of time trying to figure out what youre smelling.  And tasting.  Its sweet with apples and bananas and lemons and pepper and cinnamin and all kinds of good stuff to keep you on a good diet with your system well cleaned.  A complex, interesting, and enjoyable tripel.

This golden beer poured with a massive white head, eliciting a banana scent. The flavor is bittersweet with an alcohol finish. In keeping with the De Dolle tradition, this beer is a very unique, but marvelous creation.

no one ever bought a de dolle product for the beauty of the label--theyre typically about as attractive as those swollen red- bottomed baboons that even the nature channel is embarassed to show with a zoom lens.  this mad bitch label has all the artful grace of a prison tattoo. but mien gott in himmel, in every other respect this beer is as lovely as a glimpse of perfect cleavage. dulle teve has its own built-in bottle-bottom bilge of heavy particulate matter, its lazy swirls of rising yeast look like the smoke stacks of a sleepy alpen village.  it pours a perfect horned owls eye  yellow, as resolutely yellow as egg yolk. the head was a sand blasted bone white mousse, i could paw out a gob of it and wad it up like a piece of paper-mache-- it contained both pearly bubbles and firm beautifully sheeting creamy froth-- you can put your hand on the bottle and almost feel the champagne turbulence of exuberant effervescence inside.  as a tripel lover, i can tell my beer loving bretheren than this product is everything you love about tripels times approximately 1.4. aroma is champagne, apples and mildewed cork, cotton tablecloths drenched in white wine, and gurgling with pear brandy and yeast.  a gorgeous mixture of heavy cream and tropical fruits, a very soft feel, full body, elegantly sweet, with a natural symmetry of bitterness and strength. rudely named, the "mad bitch" is in fact a million times more meg ryan than madonna, nothing coarse or vulgar here-- its sweetness and gentle grace that id want to bring home to meet mom, its a porch swing romance, a girl next door that knocks you off your feet.

Pours hazy amber with big ole head. This is a heavily carbonated ale. Interesting spices in the aroma and flavor, im detecting some cinnamon, pumpkin, and lots of others, quite complex. Very sweet but finishes easy. Alcohol is not apparent in flavor but this is definitely a belly warmer.

thanks to Blake for this it opened as a gusher.
Poured a cloudy dark amber w/ a huge fluffy white head.  Smelled of sweet apricots, and brushes of cinamon & nutmeg.  Good medium body smooth finish well carbonated palate.  Tastes of bananna, doughy bread, apricots, with a sweet warm touch of alcohol in the finish.  Overall a great belgian and my fav tripple so far.
