Bottle, kindly shared by Blake.  Cloudy orange color with a beautiful puffy white head.  Spicy, estery aroma of apricot / green apple with a caramel malt background.  Once the carbonation selltles down its less abrasive on the tongue, and the pear skin / rye  / spicy yeast can come through.  Green hoppy finish.  Good stuff!

Bottle.  Aroma: cinnamon or nutmeg, bready, wheaty, banana.  Appearance: murky, thick, awesome head, beautiful lacing, liquid caramel color.  Flavor: spicy, dark fruits, plantain, light grains.  The palate is strongly carbonated.  I dont normally like tripels, but this suckers tasty.

Bottle: Poured a murky brown color ale with a small off-white bubbly head with average retention. Aroma is spicy with some barnyard malt. Taste is somewhat spicy (honey, cloves?) with some notes of floral malt and light funky yeast. This is not bad but was expecting a bit more character and Im wondering if something was not wrong with this bottle, will have to re-rate that one.
Hazy straw color; head was THICK and would not go away- great lace. Very nice yellow fruit flavors. Alcohol is very evident. Warms up quite nicely- getting spicy. Favorite new brewery?

UPDATED: APR 10, 2005 750ml bottle. The bottle is several years old and the liquor store was reluctant to sell it to me because they thought it was heat damaged. I have read there were some leakage problems with these bottles and the area around the cap does look bad, it is crusty and nasty. I popped the cap (no cork) and was greeted by some carbonation. I wiped of the gunk around where the cap was and I poured a glassful into my duvel tulip. There was plenty of carbonation; in fact I got an inch or two of a pretty, white head. I had refrigerated the beer for several hours today and I let it sit and warm, unopened, for a while. The temp at pouring was a touch over 50°. Really nice aroma of honey and yeast. The taste told me that this beer was still good, in fact very good. There is an initial spicy fruitiness. It is peppery and a bit sour. There is also a honey flavor and some mild estery notes. There is a nice depth of flavor and it does seem to evolve as you drink the bottle. The alcohol is apparent, but not over the top. The beer has a very full body. I consider myself very fortunate to have found a 750ml of this and I still have half the bottle left to enjoy. ADDITION: As the beer warms, its flavor changes more and more. The beer at 59° reminds me, initially, of a Victory Hop Devil, inasmuch as it is very honey-like, but not at all cloying. I am not sure if it is the hops or the alcohol, but that was what I was thinking as I was drinking it. The spice seems to now hold off until the finish. The start is fruity malt with yeast and ester (orange and banana notes) and the finish is dry and spicy. I am starting to feel the alcohol. I wonder, since this is a live beer, if the alcohol might be higher than the 10% that is listed, I mean it is possible and other beers are that way. On another note, when I poured out the last half of the bottle, the sedimentation became obvious, in fact it poured out of the bottle at the end and I stopped pouring when I saw the color of the beer change. The taste is no different than the first half, but I do detect some more perfumy notes in the initial taste. There is still the honeyish malt, but it is complimented by a floral? and fruity taste that carries onto the finish. The commercial description is accurate, there is a taste-evolution as I drink it, in fact I dont think it would have been as noticeable if I was drinking a regular 33cl bottle. This has been an incredibly enjoyable beer. I added a few points to my initial review. I had to pushed up the appearance, aroma, and  palate up a point each and the overall a point, to 18.

Dark yellow color, little white head. Spicy, strongly fruity aroma, some caramel in there too and mild alcohol. Mild sourness fits well to rich aroma. Medium to full bodied. Rich flavor too:spices, fruits, ends with medium alcohol and mild sourness. Spices and caramel last in aftertaste. Good strong brew, maybe lacks some character to have rate starting by 4.

Bottle. Light copper color with huge, white puffy head dragging Belgian lace as you sip the beer. Relatively clear, but full of "floaties". Spicy aroma with hint apples. Extremely carbonated with a syrupy texture, leading to a bit malty palate with warming alcohol and long bitter finish. Sweet, but still balanced. A small masterpiece!
Has a nice bountiful head with a hazy orange color. Spicy fruity nose,  very aromatic.  Full bodied mouthfeel.  Nice malt character, a little yeasty, still an overall enjoyable beer.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2005 33 cl bottle, bottled on? Light amber, pretty hazy, convincing creamy head (surprisingly big and lasting for such a potent beer), vigorous pearling. Strong aroma: raisin bread, honey, slightly perfumed, a touch of sour milk about it. Strong, sweet honey-ish flavour with pleasant citric-like fruitiness, earthy hops and warming alcohol.  A bit phenolic. The aftertaste is dry, malty (reminiscent of whisky) and contains some lingering hops. A fully satisfying massage for the palate with a dry finish.
A very good tasting strong beer.  With a full aftertaste.  Also stands for Mad Bitch.

Big Grassy Saaz hop nose with a nice peppery spice follow on. Lemon zest and apricots with a touch of plantain thrown in for good measure.
one of my favorites for style. Big and bold yet finishes dry and clean.

Murky brown/orange colour. Nice, creamy head. Sugary aroma. Rich, mouthfilling, rounded, quite sweet toffee-flavour. Just when its about to get cloying the alcohol-bitterness comes in and puts everything into balance. A very enjoyable beer indeed.

Hazy yellow golden beer with creamy off-white head. Aroma is filled of bananas, apricots, yeast and notes of spices. Tastes very malty, yeasty and notes of oak. The aftertaste is hoppy, spicy and the alcoholic taste very well balanced. This is the kind of stuff that makes a beerbrewers good reputation.
Drinking it at the Belgian beer festival today. Slightly cloudy, minimal head, pleasant champagne-like tingle on the tongue.

Bottled (BB 02/2005)
Hazy yellow with good creamy off-white head. Aroma is typical DDB-nose: banana, apricot, yeast, hints of alcohol and spices. Very soft malt character, alcohol kicks quite well but mouthfeel is extremely pleasant, yeast rounds the corners. When beer warms up, woody notes appear. Long hoppy and alcoholic aftertaste with spices and tar behind them. Open fire, winter outside, glass of this ... excellent.
Spicy Belgian tripple. This one has it all, fruity notes, a spicy character, plenty of alcohol to go along with the tons of flavor and is not too sweet. And 100% natural.
Bottle from Taverne Curiosa, Brugge. Utterly splendid. Cloudy Yellow Orange. Aroma of oranges, hops, spice, pepper, yeast. Great mouthfeel. Good dry spicy, hoppy finish. Dangerously Quaffable (c).
yeasty aroma with some orange spritziness, cloudy copper with an enormous tightly packed head, strong sprtizy orange very yeasty and with some clove notes
Dark cloudy yellow, big white head, hoppy, peppery and some citrus in the aroma, sweet flavor that finished bitter, not as outstanding as i had hoped for, pleasant mouthfeel though. Pretty good.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2005   This is a tripel that is loaded with hops from the beginning.  The aroma has apple, orange, wine, cider, caramel.  That is what I get from the taste as well.  Pours like the St. Bernardus tripel but with more yeast and a darker golden color.  The head is very creamy with nice lacing.  This beer has hops like a double IPA.  I was not expected this.  This is my first offering from De Dolle, and possibly the best Tripel I have had.

Bottled. 
Hazy blond colour. Aroma is citrusy, appley, rich malty, perfumy flowery. Flavour is heavy perfumy with almond paste and really, really bitter for being a triple. Reminiscent of Montagnarde.
Nice blonde hazy colour with some hints of red. A great belgian fruity aroma dominated by apple. Sweet malty taste with hints of apple and spice. Left a midly bitter aftertaste.
Pours a cloudy amber colour with a big white head. Spice and caramel apple aroma. Sweet malty taste. A good one!

Hazy golden colour with huge white head. Aroma of citrus, yeast and spices. Very carbonated. Sweet fruity flavour with lots of spices and a well balanced bitter finish. Usuallt Im not fond of tripels, but this one is good.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2005 On Tap. Called Mad Bitch at Maxs in Baltimore.  A little pricey, but worth it.  Hazy and a yellowish orange color.  Sweetness throughout with some  alcohol evident.  A good beer that I hope to find again.  De Dolle is a great beer.  Scary ass label, btw.

Maybe the foamyest beer I have ever poured. Pale and hazy with a 5" sea foam density white head that never quits. Crisp aroma of yeast, black pepper and pear with some dry sherry and mineral notes. The flavor is sweeter than the aroma would suggest. It is not as spritzy as the appearance would suggest either. Musty and fruity flavors mingle with the yeast. Strong bitter finish. Alcohol is apparent.
Cloudy orangish gold color with a large white head. Sweet bread, banana and spice aroma. Clove, banana, malt, nutmeg, other spices, and hops flavors. Nice crisp feel with a dry finish.

Poured a murky orange with a mammoth white long lasting  head and loads of lacings.  Even after many minutes it looked like a large marshmallow floating in my glass.  Aroma was fruity...oranges, apricots, green apples, and sugar.  Flavor was fruity with some banana, spice, hop bitterness, and alcohol.  Dry spicey finish and very wariming.  Medium bodied.

first off this beer gave off more head than a vivid adult video.it still has not simmered down and is making it difficult to get the first  sip.the appearance gives off a murky yellow body with little "floaties" swimming around in my chimay glass.ok after about 5 minutes the foam has come down to where i can get my first impression.this has a very nice complex flavor.its a mixture of apple cider,belgian yeast,sweet malts,lemonade,and a semi-dry finish.it reminds me alot of orval except its a bit sweeter.this is a very fun and complex trippel.

Hazy gold ale with a thick white head. Fruity oranges and spices, hops in final, sweet  candy sugar and hops. Alcohol in the finish, like grapa or another spirit. Body is smooth but not overly sweet or alcoholic.

In the 0.33L bottle. Pours a caramel color- very cloudy and dark gold. Has a giant white head. Lace is more of a foamy core. Many tiny bubbles. Taste of medicine and pears, maybe even clover. Good bitter taste with a strong alcohol burn. Sweet up front, but not too sweet. Incredible head retention. Such high EtOH that it burns your esophagus all the way down. This beer produces major league burps and then numbs your toes.

Bottled- Just like the picture.  Hazy dark amber color with a head that just about came over the top of my Duvel glass.  Aromas of apples and cherries.  Sweet and malty with a bit of yeast flovor.  Tingy mouthful. Great Beer!

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2011 Pours cloudy copper, huge head, lasts awhile. Tons of carbonation. Yeasty aroma with apple, pear, banana, bready. Candi sugar. Flavor is a bit of let down. Yeasty, alcohol, not much else. As it warms, tart green apple is coming through. Highly carbonated, even after breathing for a half hour, way too carbonated.

Light, murky orange color with a big white head. Spicy, yeasty aroma much like many Belgian tripels. Hints of coriander and banana also in the nose.
Flavor was somewhat sweet at first, but dried a bit on the finish. Flavor of malt, yeast, citrus and coriander. I liked this better than the two other De Dolle beers Ive tried(Stille Nacht & Extra Export Stout). A very nice tripel.

Staminee de Garre, Brugges, 2004: Poured a cloudy honey yellow with a huge rocky long lasting head. Grape bubblegum aroma. Malty sweet flavor with hints of grape. Moderate alcohol finish for a beer thats 10%. Very warming. Good lacing. A nice beer.
Dark yellow color with a large head.  Alcoholic nose.  Slightly bready taste, but nothing to back it up.  Decent, but dull.

33cl bottle, no BBD(wish theyd date the US stuff!)...lively bottle!  pours a rusty copper color, big off-white head, decent lace...very bubbly...huge nose of bananas, mangoes, strawberries, peaches,  vanilla...its floral...drinks smooth, almost creamy, sweet at first, then it runs to a dry, bitter, yeasty, warm finish...nice lingering yesat effect...malty flavor, honey...this beer transports me...and it wows me everytime I drink it...I think the first time I had it was in Houffalize at the Hotel Du Commerce, having picked it up at Delices & Caprices in Brussels the previous day...and it takes me back to that state...a sunny sprign afternoon in the Ardennes...yeah, this beer isnt from that area, but I still associate it with that moment in time, when everything seemed new, interesting, different, engaging, bold, true...uncompromising...and I love this damn monster!

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2005 Heavy Spice in aroma. Light fruits too. Hazy gold/copper with a huge white head. Very fruity yeasty flavour. Spice, cloves, though sweet? Smooth medium flavour. Nice. Re Rate: Same heavy spicy aroma, noted the light fruits too!. Same appearance. Flavour very well balanced, hides alcohol very well. Body wonderful. Refreshing yet warming. Prev score 7/4/7/3/15

750ml bottle corked and capped.  Beer pours cloudy medium golden with the most MASSIVE cream white head I have seen in a long time.  Aroma is complex and multi-layered.  Notes of flowers and fruit, some spices and a bit of funkiness too.  Fruit flavors really come out in the flavor, especially pear, lots of yeast, and a very dry, spicy finish.  An all night sipper and excellent tripel.
Gold Coloring with White Head.  Yeasty Aroma... Citrusy...Alcohol Warming and Bread Dough....  Very Good Triple.

Decent sized frothty head of medium to large bubbles.  Good carbonation.  Head reforms nicely upon swirling.  Fruity aroma with grapes, pears and spices.  Color is a slightly cloudy light orangy amber.  Carbonation explodes in the mouth.  Light fruity flavor with more spices and a noticable alcohol presence.  Warms as it goes down.  Dry finish with more alcohol.  A good belgian triple.
Hazy golden color, heavy spicy yeasty aroma, light sweet alcoholic taste, medium body, light alcoholic finish.

Bottle: Pours hazy golden colored with a huge white, fluffy, thick head.  Aroma: tart orange peel, lemon rind, sour apple, alcohol, spicy yeast, vinous grapes, perfume, banana, soap, vanilla, pepper.  Taste: Wow, I was surprised by the amount of malt in the taste.  I did not expect that from the aroma.  Very rich, malty and alcoholic, with some leather, cheese, spicy yeasts, bitter lemon, honeydew, vanilla, molasses, musty earth, grapes, port, raisins, cough syrup.  Finishes with pepper, yeast, bitter citrus and sweet grains.  An impressive amount of flavors to this one.  I really enjoyed the richer malt characteristics and spicy yeasts in this tripel.

Pours a golden hue with a frothy white head.  Aromas of citrus, perfume, and a little soap.  Mouthfeel is medium bodied with flavors of grapefruit, slight pepper, good yeast backbone, but not overbearing and a slight vanilla/honey finish.  One of my favorite triples.

Poured orangey golden with HUGE white head...smelled citrus, vanilla, and yeasty...excellent aroma...taste is rich and complex...citrus, lemons and melons...vanilla, mild sugar...pepper and cloves...finish is lingering with pepper and sweetness...a fantastic tripel!!!!!!!

Orange blonde color with yeast in suspension, thin white head. Powerfull, assertive, dusty aroma and flavor of yeast, citrus and spices. Bitter finish. Medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation. Those crazy brewers are really something !

Tart citrus (tangerine/lemon), earth, suede, barnyard aromas. Plenty of yeast character. Murky, opaque orange-tan with decent white head that diminishes unfortunately rapidly. Sweet malt and tangerine citrus flavours with coriander spiciness and a yeasty tartness. Lots of alcohol warming. Soft in the mouth with carbonation that gently stimulates the tongue. Bottle enjoyed with beerbuzzmontreal, MartinT, Rastacouere and a gang of bierophoux.
Bottle. Really spicy assertive belgian tripel. yeasty, citrusy, appley, the alcohol is a bit peppery and it shows a little bit, nice and warming. Classic Belgian tripel.
huge, rocky head of big and small bubbles.  smells very much like wine, and the taste matches.  very fruity and also quite tart.  prominent alcohol in the finish.  very nice.

Tripel number 1 for the night, and my favorite of the three. On the pour, it had the coolest head I think Ive ever seen. At first, I thought of Shaving cream, but then I was like, no, its exactly like the froth on a Latte. Anyway, had a darker color, similar to apple cider and smelled like a nice fruity white wine. Also present were scents of sour apples, honey, and flowers. The taste was very nice, as there was some tartness to accompany the sweetness, that is to say lemon. Also in the taste was pear and, dare I say, light whiskey. In the end, it was quite dry with a noticeable presence of alcohol, probably a good thing, given that this was 10%!

10.03.04  330ml bottle.  Hazed and bespeckled yellow gold hides beneath a mammoth, rocky, mountainous, persistent head.  Aromas, besides being characteristically DeDolle (yippee!) in their yeastiness, are a medly of orange and spice, plus some clover, vanilla, and peach.  Im in love before I taste the stuff.  Hell, I was in love before I even opened the bottle.  Body is cool and perfectly carbonated, only slightly coating, happily yielding to the aggressive hop finish.  The flavors are a floral hoppy boquet, tons of orange and lemon, maybe some pineapple.  Sweet toffee notes surprise my buds just as a warming alcohol presence sweeps over the whole show.  Hoppy and fresh, fruity and sweet, lively yet warming...Ive nailed the timing with this bottle as I cant imagine this brew being any better.  I think Ill have another.  Wow.
wait for the foam to dissipitate. Light yellow, darker cloudy yellow at bottom. Somewhat spicy coriander orange citrus pale strong with substantial yeast. Has the bite to it. Easy on tongue.

Very active pour, only slightly cloudy for this viberant gold beer with a white head that looks like a puffy cloud.  The aroma is fruit based, it has a cider and wine smell that lends to its sour presence.  There is a great feeling when you taste this beer.  Its very tangy and fruity with a sllightly noticable yeast flavor.  There is a backbone of sweet malts and a full mouth feel of fruit.

Sampled from the bottle at the brewery in Esen, Belgium.

Pale.

Sweet, strong and spicy nose. Notes of orange, pear, peach, cinnamon and icing.

Simply delightful in its flavor. Rich, sweet and spicy tripel/big belgian barley wine. Notes of pear, peach, banana and clove. This is a winner.

On tap @ Brew Kettle:  Hazy golden body w/a lasting white head and alc. legs on the glass.  Grainy malt and sugary sweet aromas w/ some floral hop.  Alcohol aroma, but not solventy, as well as banana and citrusy esters.  Well balanced and a bit on the malty side; sweet sugary and light bready malt flavors. Spicy, doughy yeast;  Alcohol esters and a very mild hop flavor in the finish & aftertaste which are sweet.  Some white grape juice notes.  Highly carbonated, smooth m/f; med. body and alcohol warmth.  A good tripel IMHO.  Fine complexities and well hidden alcohol

Rating 650. Bottle bought in Belgium. Bottle conditioned served cool into a chalice. Light gold with a big fluffy white head. Alcohol and spice in the aroma. First sip, and wow this is strong. The alcohol is hardly subtle but that doesnt matter as it actually seems to improve the beer. Great malty/spicy/alcohol flavours, so full of flavour with a long aftertaste. Really good.

330 ml bottle about 4-6 mos old served at 45-50 F. Poured a hazy peach apricot color. Big frothy densely beaded head like billowing clouds. Aroma was cake batter,vanillia frosting with hints of over ripe apricots and pears. My first sip. Tasted pretty much like the aroma and then my eyes went wide as the "Mad Bitch" dida lunatic dance on my tongue with stilletoe heels. WHOA!,SHIT! I wasnt expecting that. Spicey,peppery,what the hell was that? VERY fizzy,uuurpp!I was almost afraid to gor for another sip. I stared her down for a few minutes but eventually caved in to this golden Siren of the taste buds.
I spent 1/2 hour with this bad girl who became more subdued as she warmed up. Incredible brew that I could not handle but once in awhile.

My first dance with this wicked woman, a dame so loco that she grits a rose between her teeth, thorns and all...a tango with the Mad Bitch...
Off comes the cork, and out wafts instant sweetness and spice, up into my nose, urging me to release her from this cage, and out she pours into the most appropriate Duvel glass. The incredible, fizzy, yet creamy as a cloud head fills up 3/4 of the vessel, the body is a hazy pale orange, riddled with floating yeasties. She puts on a pretty impressive show, though she contains mysteries within, which we are about to partake of ...
Aroma, fresh and spicy, while still driven by delicate fruit, pear, apricot, pineapple, banana...a lovely, inticing thing, directing my lips to drink, already...Somehow, the brew slips out from under all that foam, and...Incredible! The shock of new, once again, sends a shudder through me, a paraxysm of delight...Im left uttering epithets and interjections...what kind of incredible concoction is this, that leads with hot peppers on the tongue, followed by lush fruitiness, backed up by serious malt! A devilish delivery of hops, followed quick by that spicy kick, almost harsh, but not quite, for its so adequately complimented by further flavors. It may seem like a messy marriage, this union of hops, spice and fruit, with the more powerful flavors fully in charge of the palate, but it instead stands out as an immaculate integration, a wanton wedding that provides release as well as relief. Taboos are uncovered, old rituals discarded, and something completely un-thought-of starts to seem commonplace...this is a moment where whats in the glass wends its way into your soul, by tasting the brew it becomes you, and now, youre that damnable dame! It seriously clings to you, never wants to leave the palate, doesnt take no for an answer, your brain says "no more", but your newly freed secret-self yens to stretch out some..."whats the harm?" 

{Shudder}
{Shudder}
"What did I do last night?"
"You messed with the Mad Bitch!"

Opening the bottle involved two tools of the trade: bottle opener and corkscrew. Even after the cap was liberated, the beast was screaming to get out -- attempting to burst through the cork. Once unleashed, foam proceeded to erupt. In short, she needed some time to process the situation before allowing me to indulge. Appearance: explosive effervescence, and an enormous bright white head -- diminishing with time leaving a clingy lace and a good film to lock in the flavor. The color was golden; hazy with lots of carbonation rising to the top. The aroma is of bubblegum (strong), fruity fresh and very full. Taste is full, sweet, with a spicy biting middle and a dry finish (quite complex); the bitterness ligers well into the next taste. Mouth feel is medium bodied, syrupy, and effervescent. The transition from sweet to dry is intensified by its intense bitter characteristics
This is a lively beer with a lot of character. Intense. Nothing laid back. I enjoyed much of the experience, but could not really get beyond some of the overpowering bitterness. Otherwise quite remarkable.

Monster head even after sitting for a while.Apicot color really murky streaming fillzles dancing up thru the haze.Insane fragrance of exotic fruits and yeast.Then maybe it comes on to a spiced tea aroma that makes it hard to stop sniffing.Will it taste this good??Almost,it is so carbonated that ,IMHO, it takes away from some of the flavor.Lots of teast but that spiced fruit flavor does poke its head out as does the alcohol.less carbonation would have made this more enjoyable.
Kind of a glowing orange colored brew with a thick whipped cream head. Spicy yeast nose. Very fruity flavor that reminded me a little of a cross between mango and peach.

bottled: had this one side by side with the stille nacht. pours nice yellow haze with a huge billowy head that kept coming and pushing and fluffing.  nose of nugget hops and some banana peel that you slipped on yesterday with a bit of nutmeg spice in the end.  in the mouth some sweetness with the nugget hops and spice coming up....as it warmed got much more alcohol taste and warmth.  for 10% much more drinkable then the 9% stille nacht. quite nice.

(on bottle)Very powerfull banananose, high carbonated mouthfeel and a fresh, alcohlic finish. Not a real highroller in my book, the different sents and flavours are fine, but seem to come in a row, not conecting. But the finish is wonderfull. The alcohol lingersgood finish indeed. and spices seem to enter your mouth from nowhere to prolong the feeling. Very good finish indeed.

11.2 oz: Mused and murky thick laquer orangish yellow color, a tall meringue puff of ivory sits a top; tons of thick lacing coats the snifter.

Nose is quite nice with a mild corriander spice and soft lemon tone; slender sugary tones, yeast, and a nice round display of caramel. 

Flavors ensue from the aroma with a wonderful array of caramel with a nice underlay of lemon hints and mildly exhibited spice. Perfect amount of heat and grab in its alcohol and sharpness. Maintains its overall semi-tropical fruity malting with caramel and sugars while a crisp little return of spicy hops and yeast dart through the finish where it has a sweeping sweetness that goes dry and peppery after a stint. Perfect!

Feel is briskly malty with a fruity/caramel backing and fullness the whole ride through, fluffy distribution across the palate at first, finely carbonated, and lots of other fun things inside that include some light and mild spices, some alcoholic heat, and a super jovial finish that goes from fruity sweet and sugary to dry, hoppy, spicy, and yeasty. Theres more here then I can describe at the moment as Im in full enjoyment mode. This stuff rocks! Why so mad...bitch? Be happy like me.
Happy now, be back soon. Yum! Rockin awesome triple thats right up my alley.

(bottle)  Cloudy yellow with a head that lasted throughout the glass.   A great belgian beer.   Well carbonated and fairly think tasting.   This was as close to drinking hard cider as I think I could stand. I liked this beer a lot, but at a whopping 10% alcohol I know that one will always be my limit.

This beer would be the best tripel in the world if it were slightly less carbonated. De dolle is an astonishing brewery! Pours with a head so rocky I need a harness and ropes to finish it. Lovely and golden. Smells like a cross between a duvel and chimay cinq cents. Very hoppy version. Almost a belgian strong in this regard. I could drink this morning noon and night.
G-rat

pours deep gold, big lacey white head.   aroma of honey, alcohol, yeast and peppery spice.   bready malt and yeasty flavour with more honey and pepper.  starts lightly sweet, then goes dry as a bone.  very nice.

Hazy amber with fleeting white head.  Nose held notes of yeast, citrus, spice.  The moughfeel was lively carbonation and smooth and medium bodied.  The flavor was sweet and alcoholic and fruity.  Not bad but not great.

So its the same old story again and again. De Dolle is the only company out there that makes belgian beer that I can tolerate and on top of that I love the stuff. Again, thanks again to brooklynboy for sharing this fine brew with me and the other guys at the corkscrew. Pours a nice golden colour with a thin white head that was quite long lasting. The nose is wheaty with lots of malts and suggar. The taste was nearly the same but it seems more rounded and complete and less one directional. there seems to be just a bit of flowres too. Good stuff!

Bottled.  A hazy darkish amber coloured triple with plenty of sediment.  The beer has a big long-lasting head and generous lacing.  The aroma is spicy but also lemony.  The taste is medicinal and strong with lots of alcohol, but also a bit of a smoky aftertaste.  A good complex beer.

Cloudy amber/orange color,large white head that faded slowly to a nice lace.The aroma was fruity sweet with some yeast notes.The flavor was very nice with a good fruity side and notes of spice and malt with a hoppy bitter side coming through as well.The alcohol makes an appearance on and off throughout the tasting but its fairly mild and well hidden for the most part.A very nicely done brew that makes me wish i had a few more around for later.

Murky cloudy, orange body.  Excellent lacing, white rocky head, that lasts mostly.  Hoppy (pine, citrus) and yeasty (soap) aroma.  Lightly acidic, heavily bitter initial flavour.  Moderately bitter (long) finish.  Ful body, watery texture, lively carbonation, matallic feel and alcoholic.

Deep golden body, beautiful short, everlasting, creamy white head, leaving a thin lace. Heavy carbonation. Perfume, yeast and hops in the aroma. Taste is balanced, dry and slightly malty (champage, orange peel, yeast). A slight tartiness in the finish, not really sour. Lacks some complexity. Smooth, velvety body. Outstanding drinkability, hides the 10% alcohol perfectly.

Poured a medium hazy amber color with a smaller white head. Tiny particles. Strong fruity and spicy smell with traces of yeast. Spicy and very fruity tastes(strong oranges, cloves and peppers). 
Slight alcohol in the taste but no where near the 10%. I really enjoyed this beer and will have to get more in the future.

Labelled "Mad Bitch".  Pours honey gold, with a big white head with medium bead. Aroma is lightly sweet, with some sea-water notes. Some clover, alcohol and honey carries over to the flavour. Bready and modest yeastiness.  For a tripel, it isnt very powerful. Underwhelming. Palate has gaps to be filled (as far as the style). Piles of champagne notes throughout, and into the very dry finish. All said, it is still quite good.

This great hazy goldcolored beer is an unfltered and unpasteurized blockbuster.It has a warm and maltlike aroma and a full bittersweet taste.This beer has a long afthertaste with a fine bitterness in the end.The mouthfeeling is round and  warming up in the end. By the way...Dulle teve means (arrogant bitch)

Deep hazy gold, absolutely masive head that doesnt quit.  Pretty stuff.  Aroma immediately winey, with sauvignon blanc notes of gooseberry, pineapple and mango.  Second whiffs revealed the almost raw barely underneath.  Flavor is complex, layers of thick tropical fruit, sweet malt, and that edge of Belgian funk.  This is just an awesome beer.

Bottle.  Looks like a hazy, rich, beautiful tripel.  I found this stuff quite overrated; the excessive sourness in the aroma and flavor ruined it for me.  Something about this threw the beer badly off-balance for me.  Somehow, it still had a nice mouthfeel and finish, making this one of the more unusual ratings Ive ever done (5/5 in appearance and palate, 5 and 6/10 in aroma and flavor!)

Hazy light orange colour with a HUGE white and thick head. Earthy aroma with yeast, malts, and an acidic fruitiness (apples). Flavour was nice and spicy and perhaps a bit more malty than most other triples. Obviously a bitter finish and a full, carbonated body. Pretty good stuff!

Light spiciness to the nose, otherwise the typical white bread tripel smells.  Medium blonde body.  Modetately sweet, lightly acidic flavor becomes a lightly bitter, lightly sweet, lightly acidic finish.  Medium-heavy body, creamy texture, lively carbonation.  The bottom line is: one could ask for a bit more complexity, but the 10% is well hidden.

Hazy orangish blonde color with an enormous white head.  Yeastly aroma with some citrus and alcohol.  Banana/clove flavor, very mellow and smooth.  Some of the 10% EtOH is evident.  Nice dry finish.  This brewery is becoming my favorite.
Pours a golden yellow. Nice head and lacing. Spicy nose. Hoppy bitter and malt body with a spicy finish. Great beer!

Lemon drop in a bottle.  The appearance is all kinda funky, as there are many facets to view, with lacing abounding.  The flavor just doesn't seem as complex as it pours.  The nose and palate suffer from being a little thin, and yielding to the alcohol.

A huge light and fluffy head that clung to the sides of the glass like a fat kid holding a cupcake.  Hazy appearance that was darker than a gloden brown, maybe honey colored.  Powerful alcohol flavor with a clove and fruity follow on.  Hits the palatte with the strengh that one might expect from a double digit % alcohol beer.  Flavor remains true till the very end, when it leaves you with a sweet, alcoholic, bitterness that remains.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2004 Beautiful appearance like always, yeast sediments a plenty at the bottom of a cloudy golden/honey body over which lies the typical, almost caricatural mountainous rocky/sticky white head. Expressive grassy (clover) nose with hints of alcohol, honey, hop perfume and cloves. Good malt base in mouth, but also a strong grassy and flowery hoppiness leading to a moderately bitter finish. Very creamy, spongy mouthfeel with usual De Dolle medium-high carbonation. Warming dry and slightly alcoholic finish. Solid, as expected, in the same vein of many tripels with a greater name, but I cant say its my favorite from the brewery. Once again, thanks to Boise pub crawler Sham.  A 750mL sample showed a lot of difference. Here the yeast was very dominating, musty while the malt was particularly candy-like. Spicy, full bodied, and well carbonated, but extreme level of yeastiness was perhaps too much.. not changing the score.

The so-called "Mad Bitch" packs quite a punch... poured clear, until the sediment let loose and created a cool Lava-Lamp effect in the glass...sturdy head, sorta spicy, some what sweet, not very bitter, very smooth for the high ABV.

(330 ml bottle)  Pours a cloudy orange color with a large, frothy, egg shell colored head.  Has a pleasant aroma of light malt, bread, caramel, straw, and banana.  Has a long flavor retention and warmth of the 10% abv.  Excellent!

(750ml bottle) Pours a creamy, white head and a cloudy, orange body. Much sediment and minute carbonations. Aroma of grapes, port wine, alcohol, candied sugar and oranges. Flavours of caramel and smooth malt. Hoppy, fry finish with some alcohol apparent. Not as complex as the nose tends to be.

Aroma is nice--yeastly, peppery, and doughy.  Not extremely potent, but not too light either.  Pours a haZy copper with a huge frothy white head.  Has a very nice mouthfeel.  Start is peppery and sweet and fruity tasting.  Cannot pin it down, though.  Its very yummy.  Sweetness in the middle dancing with an ethanol burn and some mild bitterness to entice you back at the end.  A very yummy beer.
Bottle at DBF 2004. Pours blond/golden color, with a nice big fluffy head. Aroma is very spicy, fruity and yeast. The flavor is the same, with a touch of alcohol in the background. Highly carbonated.
Golden color with a large fluffy white head. The taste is fruity with spicy and slight citrusy notes. Has som yeasty notes as well.

Wow, the cork popped off with such force it almost forced the opener into my eye! Pours a very aromatic pear with an enormous frothy white head. Smells great, sweet and fruity seems great for a lazy summer afternoon. Taste is initially a little sweet with some apple cider-like bite but deepens into a very flowery texture with a prominent alcohol taste and pungency. Tastes like my throat is corroding, which is kind of pleasant, but also unnerving. Not too bad, great triple!
UPDATED: DEC 8, 2004 I dont really remember a whole lot about this beer...  Sweet, carbonated, and that sucks.  Fruity though.  Im going to re-rate later.

UPDATED: JUL 25, 2004 Rerate after a few months cellaring, strong aromas of butterscotch/caramel were delightful.  Taste of doughy burnt butterscotch.  Much better.

Huge white foamy head with tiny bubbles. Very cloudy pour, spicy nose with slight alcohol twinge.  
Taste was all over the place as it warmed, fruit, spices, alcohol.
Enjoyable.

Once I removed the cap the cork immediately exploded from the bottle and the beer spewed forth.  Pours with a large head and a cloudy yellow-orange body with abundant suspended material.  Aroma is dry and sour, with pineapple, spices, earthy/musty notes, and a touch of white grape.  Reminiscent of a Saison or lambic (and of course several Tripels).  The flavor is neither too sweet nor too dry, with pineapple and orange notes delivering just enough citrus character to the otherwise dry, crackery, spicy, very estery body.  Bitter finish with detectable alcohol.  Tight carbonation leaves a nice mouthfeel.  A bit rougher around the edges than some Tripels I've tried, but the main drawback is the steep price (I believe I paid $11.99/bottle).  Perhaps the most "typical" offering I've tried from De Dolle.  However, this is characteristically well-done.

Resembles a volcano with its pendulous white peak, shallow caldera, and substantial seismic activity in an underlying honey-colored core. Has fine suspended particles and cottony lacing. Nose is of wheat bread, lightly sweet malt, yeast, and only faint citrus and esters. Flavor is less citrusy than other tripels but quite tasty. Grainy malts lead here followed by some medium acidity in the finish and very late bitterness. Some orange flavor does come through after a few ounces. Nice stuff. More thanks to loweredsixth.

UPDATED: APR 15, 2004 750 ml Bottle: Large head, with a hazy yellow color. Slight lemony aroma. The flavor is perfumey/flowery and ends slightly bitter. Similar to Duvel, but not as smooth, satisfying or priced as well (This was $10, Duvel is $7 or $8)

Alas, finally got  to try again. Had one from long ago that must have gone off ... Really don't remember too much about it other than being excited about kissing the Mad Bitch and having her slap my face and try to pull my tongue out. This has a great aroma - just so much there (and that's saying a lot for a guy with difficulties smelling anything). Sweet with bitterness to make all come together. Hope to meet the bitch again as she was much friendlier this time.

Unfortunately mine was skunked. The picture here shows a brown bottle, but mine was a 750ml green bottle. Light golden color with a little haze but relatively clear. Long lasting head, thick and rocky. Mine was very overcarbonated.  When poured very slow it still was 90% foam to 10% beer.  Flavor is smooth and clean yet complex.  Start is sweet and fruity which remains throughout the mid tongue and finish.  Not overly cloying, but balanced by the hop flavor and hop bitterness.  Flavors from the yeast are soft and balnced.  Not overly phenolic but balanced and just enough to add to the complexity.  Alcohol is suprising masked.  Overall great beer, mine would have been better with out the lite struck smell I had, but thats just poor storage.

33 cl bottle, served in Chimay goblet.
Pours w/ the typical Dolle Brouwers head, that is: massive, rocky and long-lived, much of the sediment not sinking through the head.
Cloudy dark gold w/ lots of sediment floating about. Highly aggressive, in-your-face taste dominated by hops and a good dose of yeast. Bitter and not for the faint of palate. A beer w/ tons of character.

Cool, cartoonish label. The alcohol is not tasted, but I definitely felt it. Pours with a huge head. Less banana than other tripels. Subtle aromas of peach, vanilla and some pepper. Flavor is light with citrus, hops and some vanilla sweetness. Easy to drink.

Hazy golden peach color with a huge frothy off white head. Light lemon and spice aroma. Flavor has a light orange peel bitterness, some peppery spice, hints of yeast and finishes somewhat tart and dry. Lively champange like fizz on the palate. A very nice tripel.

UPDATED: JAN 13, 2008 A friend of mine bought this bottle three years ago somewhere in Belgium. Even then i thought it was pretty old with a best before date of 1997. Somehow the bottle escaped my attention the last 3 years but now finally the time has come. Clear orange golden coloured, fantastic head, lots of carbonation, surprising after all these years. Aroma of hops, fruit (apple) and some spices i cant define. Flavour is a bit disappointing, quite alcoholic, watery mouthfeel. Finish is nice again, bitter and long-lasting.

This brew pours with a cloudy golden body topped by a thick head with lots of lacing.  The aroma is sweet and flowery with a slight citrusy fruit note.  The flavor is sweet and flowery with a slight bitterness and a touch of citrus.  Medium bodied, dry and slightly warming.

Cloudy golden color with a large white head. Aroma of lemon,citrus,bananas.Flavor is slightly sweet and acidic,doesn't fit with the aroma. Mad Bitch as the label states, she doesn't taste great but she gave good head.
Hugely giganto aroma that clubs you into giving in and drinking some...too bad the flavor doesn't match.      Huge head on a dark yello beer.  light fruity flavor.  Eh.
Hazy light orange filled with chunks of yeast, good white head.  Yeasty aroma with light fruits (lemons).  Starts and ends sweet with a touch of acidicy.  Overrated.

Only gushed a little unlike previous bottles I've had, poured a hazy amber/yellow with fine white foam that disappeared after a few minutes but lesft some nice lace. Quinine like nose and flavor, with lime, kiwi, mango and apple in there as well, with a good prickle/stickel of carbonation. Dry in the finish with a Sancerre-like mineral quality. Sophistacated and complex, yet the perfect match for rustic food like the ol' croque monseur or fried chicken.

Very cloudy pale yellow. Huge head--nice and fluffy but quickly diminishing. Sweet baby-powder floral aroma with a bit of spice. Very soft carbonation. Lightly sour, slightly bitter. Complex and easy-drinking especially considering the style and ABV.
Mad Bitch! Trippel @ 10%. Fruity trippel in taste with a nice head and perfect in the finish.

(750 ml) Hazy dark oranges colour. Big foamy white head. Apricot, peaches, banana and spices in aroma with very pleasant sour note. Wonderful complex flavour. Bittersweet flavour of tropical fruit, brown sugar and lemon. Good spicy alcohol flavours in the finish. Small notes of cedar wood. Creamy, lively and crisp mouthfeel.
Pours a translucent yellow, big white head. Aroma is spicy, sweet, slightly astringent. Very nice rendition of a tripel, spicy, thick, belly warming.
Cloudy yellow body and foamy white head.  Good strong body with some good ol' Belgian spices.  I don't really have that much to say about this...it's a good beer:  heavy, sweet and enjoyable.

750ml bottle, "mad bitch" - I took the cap off of this to find a wet cork with traces of mold on the top - "crap," I thought, "if I open this and it smells like wet garbage I'll be pissed, this was 12 bucks" - thankfully, what emerged from the bottle was a well-preserved, and very well-crafted tripel ale - large, though unsustained head - good lacing - aroma of bananas and sugar - flavor is quite sweet, with notes of banana, honey and some slight citrus - a bit of bitterness toward the end balances things out a bit - pastry-ish flavor combines with the honey notes to create a flavor that I can only describe as something akin to baklava - de dolle does it again.
Hey, no more "Mad Bitch" on the label? The banana, spice, cloves and bready aroma are just the beginning. The taste is all of the above with a warm alcohol finish. Tasted like spiced banana bread.

Bottle. This beer formed a huge sized white foamy head with fine-medium sized bubbles that were very long lasting. The body was hazy and uncarbonated with a yellow hue. The nose was sweet and floral. The flavor was sweet, a bit sour, spicy and alcohol. The mouthfeel was smooth and it had a bit of a stinging feeling. This beer's lacing was sparse.

This bottled brew poured an incredibly large invigorated head of foamy finely sized white colored long lasting bubbles that left behind a minimal lacing.  The body is a carbonated hazy yellow color.  The aroma is floral in nature with some grassy notes while the mouth feel is smooth for its vinuousness initially then the smoothness dies away leaving a rather vinuous aftertaste.  The flavor is mostly vinuous alcohol, clove and malty notes.  There is a complexity to it that is noticeable, but rather covered up by the alcohol content.  A strong belgian brew not to be toyed with lightly lest the wench take her anger out on ya!  Afterall, they don't call her the mad bitch for nothing!

Sampled February, 2004; Hop Leaf, ChicagoWith a name like the mad bitch this beer had certainly produce some results.  The beer pours a hazy orange-gold color, and produces a prodigious white head.  There is a lightly dusty, herbal, floral, and grassy aroma to this beer.  It is sharp and herbal in taste, and is very well carbonated.  It is lightly sweet with notes of honey and spices.  It is almost spicy hot in character, quite interesting actually.  This beer is definitely musty in character, it is like it has been lightly dusted with some pollen from a slightly astringent, yet floral flower.  It is slightly lemony in character, with a hint of apple to it as well.  The beer gets a bit sweeter as the copious amounts of carbonation starts to dissappear.  There is also a nuttiness here in the middle of the beer, which adds to the complexity.  I really like the interplay between the spiciness and the fruity sweetness, a very good balance that melds into an incrediple beer.
Cloudy golden in color. Fruity, Belgiany in aroma. Taste - excellent. Just the right mix of fruit and alcohol. One of the best Belgian beers I've had to date, probably the best.

UPDATED: MAR 27, 2008 (Bottled, BBE 12/2003, sampled 03/2008) Dry and fruity, slightly alcoholic aroma. Perfectly balanced flavor with no alcohol at all. At least as good as a fresh one, although probably past its peak. Beautiful!
(Bottled) Dark orange color with a medium, tight and creamy head. Extremely fruity, very crisply spicy-anisey aroma with salmiac and sour cream. Slightly sugary, very fruity anise flavor with berries and some alcohol burn in the finish. The ABV is quite well hidden, though. Medium to full-bodied, smooth, although moderately high-carbonated and refreshing palate. A very enjoyable and tasty, mouth-blowing tripel. The bottles seem to vary quite much in quality: the last one I had was very dry, acidic and carbonated, with overpowering alcohol - and no complexity whatsoever.
(Earlier rating, bad bottle? 5-4-5-3-11=2.8) Amber color, big head. Dry pear cider aroma with some sour apple involved. Flavor is heavily hoppy and sour. Extremely carbonated, cider/sparkling-like palate. Not my favorite, thats for sure.
This has a warm dark orange color to it and a killer head. Taste is spicy and sweet. Pretty malty. Maybe a little to bitter, from the yeast? I don't know. A decent triple.

hazy light to medium golden...huge frothy head. aroma is yeasty and quite tart and lemony, much more so than the karmeliet tripel i just had. under the yeast, there's a candy sugary aroma as well. flavor has no tartness. initially sweet and banana-ey with a little clove, finish is mildly hoppy and alcoholic.

UPDATED: SEP 6, 2007 Rerate of corked 750ml bottle aged probably 4-5 years, but I dont know because its not dated (sampled on 9/6/07): Pours a transparent bright effervescent golden with a large, frothy white head.  Aroma of sweet floral hops and biscuity pale Belgian malt.  Body has nice fullness and carbonation along with a sweet light caramel and floral yeasty earthy flavor.  Seems to have aged well.

Corked 750ml bottle sampled 1/28/04: Pours a cloudy golden with a thick pillowy and well-lacing white head. Tart barnyard aroma with some bready yeast and candi sugar presence, very reminiscent of a saison.  Body starts sweet with a touch of caramel and biscuit malts, goes through a more tart bready stage and finishes dry, bittersweet and refreshing, without any trace of alcohol.  A very drinkable beer and masterfully done.  This mad bitch has made me happy.

Massive white head upon a cloudy golden body.  Strawberry yeast aroma, with a very light yeasty sticky feel to the body. Aight I suppose. What the hell does the name mean on this anyway? I need to learn to speak belgish.

Bottle pours a hazy 24 karat gold with a big frothy head, Belgian lace, and lots of bubbles streaming off the bottom of the glass.  The aroma is slightly yeasty, pineapple and pear like, and overall sweet smelling.  The flavor is sweet, pineapple, bitter hops, slightly earthy, almost orange like, pepper (you can taste a bit of the alcohol, but not 10%), perhaps a clove like spiciness, and slightly yeasty with a slick and rich body.  Overall, this is pretty darn good, but I prefer other De Dolle products.
UPDATED: DEC 19, 2007 Big foamy head that disappeared real quick. Nice straw golden color with pepper everywhere.

Tall creamy head on a  hazy orange golden body. Strong fruity nose of oranges, yeast and alcohol. Nice heavy fruity flavor with plum, oranges and hay tones. Soft sour aftertaste. De Dolle amazes me once again!!

Bottle conditioned. Slightly hazy gold, vast billowing head of foamthat lasts, but moderately low condition. Some apple aromas mingled with alcohol initialy, almost calvados like, becoming honeyed and grainy as it settled down a little. Thick and malty in the mouth with hints of liquorice, a slight perfumed spiciness and a spirity alcohol kick. More liquorice in the finish with some hop bitterness noticable and a long alcoholic glow as it goes down. Not quite the mad bitch I had expected, more of a stroppy slapper.

750 ml bottle, at least a year old.  Stunningly large and stable head tops a bright orange translucent-bordering-on-opaque body full of swimming yeasty particulates.  Nose initially quite strong, sour and yeasty, but softer fruity aromas soon appear -- pineapple, pears.  Rich and succulent on the tongue, peppery and slightly alcoholic (though nothing feeling like 10%) marvellously balanced between tart acidic citrus, and sweet buttery toffee hard-candy with a nice hint of vanilla.  Perhaps just a tiny bit less complex than the Oerbier 2002 of last night, but more drinkable and enjoyable right now.  Wonderful mouthfeel, wonderful beer.
Yeasty, dry finish. Chardonnay and sharp oak notes. Not sweet or fruity. Wheat texture. Will compare with 750 ml soon.
Hazy golden coloured. Aroma of yeast and citrus fruits. Sweet and fruity flavour with spicy notes. Slightly alcoholic. Funny name.

The beer after decanting a beclouded yellow orange with tons of dross and a rather substantial head that is creamy in consistency and an off white color, the lace forms a fine sheet to cover the glass. Earthy aroma of yeast, sweet malted grain, hints of pineapple, and a marvelous beer to sniff, start is ambrosial and thickly malted, top is fair to middling in feel. Finish is stern in its acidity, the hop powerful but pleasant in their spiciness, very dry and long lasting aftertaste with the 10 percent ABV, applying a bit of Belly Warming, a fine beer from a fine brewery, and one I see rarely for some reason.

The aroma is of oranges, citrus, yeast, and cloves. The color is an unclear orange with a fine but collapsing head. The flavor is sweet of oranges, cloves, and the alcohol that discretely plays over the tongue. A fantastic flavor.
Big, big head. Spicy aroma, coriander?? Lots of alcohol in flavor, and a bit to sour.

UPDATED: SEP 5, 2006 750ml: Banana peach. Unfiltered.  Mountainous white head sprays the glass with intricate lace. Invigoratingly estery nose with notes of dessert apples, honeycomb, doughy yeast, melon, and black pepper. Delightfully musty, as well. Carbonation expands then condenses into a soft cream. First sip is soothingly yeasty and heavily estery with peppery alcohol and herbal hops. Notably flowery, bitter, and peppery throughout the brew with long honeyed pale malt notes to balance the esters and herbal aspects. Finishes with a blend of table grapes, salt, and doughy malts with a lingering grassy character. Exuberantly ripe and balanced in every aspect.  Understated, yet extraordinarily complex. A real gem of the world.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Nice.  Dusty golden, big bubbly head.  Nose musty, sweet, and sugary, a bit herby.  Lovely flavor, soft and sugary, bit peppery, good spice.  Loads of yeast, nice and chewy.  A lovely, lovely tripel.

Clear golden-yellow with a huge white fomay head. Spicy pepper and grassy hops aroma. The flavor like the aroma is peppery with a big hit of grassy hops. Some citurs and sweetness comes through about mid-taste. The body is medium with lively carbonation. The alcohol is almost totally masked. De Dolle does it again. Yum yum.

UPDATED: APR 21, 2004 yeast explosion in this one... atom bomb is a better phrase. This is a very heavy tripel. Taste is a bit special, VERY yeasty. Some toffee and spice flavors, hides the abv very well, but heavy on the palate. This is a very special brew.. and I can tell you, the mad bitch bites!! ... considering the influence, I might think this was a 12%+ abv
Big beer. Light yellow in color. Fruity aroma with heavy carbonation. Sweet taste. Very enjoyable.

Hazy yellow colored with a moderate white head.  Floral, sweet, and hoppy.  Flavor has a fair amount of hoppiness to it almost like a Prima Pils, Saaz maybe.  Peppery.  Dry finish interesting Belgian Ale
Light yellow orange with a big thick head. Very fruity aroma with citrus notes and alcohol. Thin fruity flavor with an alcohol bite and heavy carbonation. Enjoyable and complex.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Murky golden color, enormous creamy head, took 10 minutes to pour because of it. Aroma of banana, yeast, spice and pears. Flavor was sweet and yeasty with a fair amount of bitterness for being as sweet as it was. Some spice in there too. Full bodied, some fizziness with a dry finish. Abv was hidden pretty well. Good stuff.

Best before: Dec 2003.
Caramelized sugar, candy, citric acidity, some decomposing leaves, quite complex, cant seem to find the right words for all the aromas. 
Dark amber, quite bubbly, head is a nice creamy layer. 
Strong, almost sticky caramel flavors which easily reach the back of the throat. Fruit on top 
of that. 
Dry mouthfeel, full and warming body.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2003 This beer rocks... the crazy Mad Bitch!
Murky, deep golden hue. The head is huge, white and frothy. Cool lacework. 
The nose is of banana, pear, toffee and alcohol. Minor notes of white wine and oak.
Heavy, alcoholic flavor with some very nice, malty notes. Apple and pear, lots of warm alcohol and toffee. Decently-balanced for a high ABV beer. Fairly well-bittered.
Full-bodied with an oily mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation.
The finish is sweet, astringent and fairly lengthy.

Peppery alcohol, yeasty nose.  Dense small white sticky head.  Pleasant golden orange hue.  Lively carbonation, nice mouthfeel.  Sweet pale malts, pears, apples, estery, medium bodied, finishing with a big spicy alcohol bite, with fairly assertive hops.  Very tastey and quie drinkable for the weight.

Poured out of 11.2 oz. bottle, bought at Hi-Times Wine Cellars in Costa Mesa, CA 10/21/03.  Pours to a golden cream soda color, hazy and with a frothy head that lingers.  Very volatile stuff-- gently poured but the head just explodes out of this beer.  Bright, glowing, spicy nose of grass and citrus (lemon).  Very bitter, charged hop and coriander flavor.  Intense burn of alcohol and fizz of carbonation, fruit flavor with bitter hop character.  Slightly sweet of candi sugar.  Mellows quickly but nicely to slightly woody/cedary finish with some apple, some malt, and candi sugar.
Really dense musty cellar nose.  Full mouthfeel with a cobweb sour maltish taste.  Sour horse blankets.

Hazy yellow, with a wit beer-like nose of orange zest and lemon, some spices, and plenty of extra alcohol. Yeasty initial taste...biscuity and cobwebby, acidic underneath.  Spiciness is almost Wit-like as well.  This is like a Tripel-Wit, truly a "mad bitch".  Awesome finish is alcoholic, fizzy, and leaves the strangest sweet aftertaste. Truly awesome.
Large white head. Little dark, golden colour. Aroma; little sweet, fruit (orange), citrus, grass. Little sweet taste, salt and pepper, hoppy finish. Well-hidden alcohol. Very drinkable.

Pours a clear golden color with a nice white puffy head, very cloudy and pretty. Aroma is surprisingly light but has hints of floral hops and a citrus & spice complex. Flavor is subtle with not much alcohol detectable but it comes out through the nose (not the smell but the feel) very aptly. Finishes semi-sweet and smooth.
Pours a hazy golden hue with huge head, with nice lace.  Lots of fruit in the nose, maybe pear, definately nice.  Spicy flavors with some more of that fruit. It's a spicy belgian!

Orange gold color. Large foamy white head. Aroma is fruity, spicy, and yeasty with a touch of mustiness. A medium bodied Belgian Triple. Fruity and spicy. Very fine champagne like carbonation. Orange, apricot, grapefruit, peach and vanilla flavors. Spicy and tart. Light and lively. There is a slightly alcohol bite at 10% but it not that noticeable. Damn interesting beer, as are most of the De Dolle brews. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and dry. Aftertaste is slightly sweet and very spicy.

This really had the potential to be a great belgian but it is just drowned out with too manythings going on at once.  Your palate is totally overwhelmed.  Spicy with citrusy fruits dominating, strong cotton candy taste, with a nice biscuity aftertaste coming in, but just dulled out by a strong malt taste, that will not back off.  Extremely over the top, not too much for me, but too much for the recipe.

Pale amber-orange, slightly hazy; thick yellowish head. Citrussy, lemony nose, candi-sugar, bit yeasty. Taste is candi-sugar, slightly peppery, but overimpregnated by coloured malts. Retronasal some hops and caramelised sugar. Extremely dry mouthfeel - if James Bond would drink beer instead of Martini, 't would be this. Alcohol-burn, liqueurish, artichoke in the aftertaste. I'm not a fan of duvel-like contraptions, but this is so over the top that it becomes great.

33cl bottle.  Great looking huge rocky head.  Basic aroma.  A bit overcarbonated, but the beer has a lot of sweet fruity malt that I like.  The sweetness is cut with an almost harsh bitterness and alcohol, both of which linger in the finish.  Pretty good, but I'd prefer St.  Feuillien, Val de Dieu and a few others.

(33cl bottle) Well I have about 3 inches foam and an inch of beer. This beer is rabid, pour with caution. The nose is spicy and sweet. The beers color is about on line with a pils. The carbonation level of this beer is excessive. The beer itself is very airy, fruity, and sweet. One negative is that the beer shows a little too much alcohol. The finish is relatively sweet and quick. I think this beer would be better if I did not have to wait so long for the head to fall enough in order to make sipping possible. However, once the carbonation dies down much more of this beers starts to show.

Hazy (almost opaque) brownish yellow color with a massive, thick, persistent white head. The aroma was sour, apple, grape, leather, musty, perfume, and some lemon. The flavor was similiar to the aroma but showed some alcohol as well. Bubbly, light feel.

UPDATED: MAR 17, 2008 2008-03-06. Golden amber body with a nice white head (3+). Sweet pale malt aroma does not reveal the alcohol as much as I would have expected. (7+) Tropical fruit over dry alcohol and sweet pale malt. (8+) Less alcohol forward than I recall. Quite nice. Medium palate (3+) Yay De Dolle! 7+/3+/8+/3+/17-19 4.1 - 4.2 Bottle shared with DSG at Trappisthuis, Gent

December 2007. Bottle. Hazy orange body with a nice creamy off white head. Sweet aroma of pale malt, and saccharine caramel or treacle, very light floral and buttery notes. Similarly sweet malt with moderate caramel and sugary notes throughout the flavour, yet finishes on the dry side with a modest announcement by the passing alcohol, but only a small hint of the full strength. Hints at bread or cookie dough. Smooth, dense palate. Very nice. Sweeter than your average tripel but I quite like this. 8/4/8+/4/17 - 4.1

July 2003. Used a Chimay glass, Hardly noticed the alcohol. Huge head, I was a bit over eager on the pour, but it settled nicely. Bit fruity and bitter in the finish. Very nice. Picked up for me in Belgium. 6/4/9/4/17 - 4.0
Yeasty, spicy nose, huge billowing head.  Initial wheat like stickiness in the malt flavor.  Surprisingly smooth and integrated, with little in the way of alcohol perception.  Very nice triple.
Very powerful. Quite acidic and spicey. Strong alcoholic finish. Bitter and fruity. A nice but dangerous triple. Very strong aroma.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2004 03 bottle. Um--underrated? holy ****, i am still in awe, i just finished this about 2 minutes ago.  Pours a little bit lighter than your average belgian ale.  cloudy BUT had a huge head.  That was a nice change, the head was actually closer to creamy than bubbly and it lasted.  Smells of a little bit of spice and clean belgian yeast.  
Begins full and dosent stop.  Wonderful complexity arises.  Am I tasting vanilla, orange, lemon, a tiny bit of anise.  Definitely some sweet honey appeal as well.  There is ample yeast flavor throughout, and a nice sour/bitter tone.  What impressed me most however, is the full body and great complex flavor down to the last drop.  Alcohol was quite apparent even for a 10 percent,  I think this beer makes for better cellaring than drinking it fresh from the vat, and it dosent need this much alcohol. Man do I want more of this.  and especially do i want some aged bottles.

Um--overrated? Sunny orange color with a smidgin of a head. Nice yeast and forest smell soon emerge. The flavor is slighly yeasty, but with a weird, offkey, citric sourness that detracts immensly, in my opinion--maybe it's grapefruit--I don't like grapefruit! Fresh tasting, but too sour/bitter. I have rated this generously.

Bottle. Dark amber coor with a big thick foamy white head and lots rising bubbles up the middle.  It hissed when the cap was pulled, and the head rushed forth when poured, yet settles within a reasonable time.  A spicy, pepper, candy, and alcohol aroma with a touch of orange and citrus but otherwise not heavily fruit based.  The flavor has vanilla at the front, a sharp spice in the middle, and a fruit base at the finish.  The alcohol is warming and strong.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2009 2009-11-26, at least 2 years old, 8-5-8-3-16=40Hazy light amber color; highly carbonated, huge head. Mild aroma, sweet and spicy. The malt flavor is quite sweet and a bit spicy, very pleasant combination; its clearly alcoholic, with an unforgiving warming feeling. Average bitterness; possibly the bitterness has vanished a bit with time. Perfect maturity and balance for this beer.2003-05-10, 8-5-9-4-16=42Cloudy golden color. Nice aroma, like some white French wines. Malty; original taste, with a delicate wood note that adds a great complexity. I would like to try it aged and in a bigger corked bottle.
Honey appearance, Apple with twist of anise, with a strong alcohol taste.  But still a complex mixture of flavors.  Smooth after warming.  Challanging but worth it

Pours a nice hazy shade of orange-brown. The stories about this having lots of carbonation are true, but my bottle did not explode. There was lots of head, though. Strong, pillowy light tan head. Aroma is a full bouquet of yeast, citrus zing, wheat, and spices. Bitter in taste but finishes a little more mellow. The tartness seems citrusy like biting a lemon but also has a molded or cellared scent like the Arabier. The alcohol is well hidden. For a 10% brew, the alcohol seems nonexistent. Great beer, though. Would love to try an aged bottle.

This one pours a clear (first pour out of a 750 ml), amber color with a big, rock, lasting white head. The aroma is very hoppy with lots of fruit and yeast notes. Medium body with full carbonation, the mouthfeel is smooth and the flavor is alcoholic and malty up front with a bitter and alcoholic finish. The alcohol is quite apparent throughout the flavor profile. However, the alcohol seems to subside as you drink more of it, allowing lots of fruit, hop, and yeast flavors shine through. Excellent beer from an exceptional brewer. And yes, this bitch is mad.

Bottled: Hazy yellow colored. Huge white head. Fresh citrus aroma. Yeasty. Spicy and quite complex flavour. Has lots of alcahol notes. Quite dry in the aftertaste. Pleasant beer, that you have to be careful with. Hits you like a horse

Very thick white head and a golden color.  Smells rather yeasty and with a some citrus feel.  Flavor has some malt sweetness with a little tastes of spice.  Palate has a nice sweetened kick to it.  Nice belgian beer that reminds me of Unibroue with the yeast.

Cloudy orange. Big banana esters. Malty. Some hop presence in both bitterness and flavor. Fairly sweet. Tastes like Westmalle yeast. Slight alcohol warming. This beer reminds me of my first pass on cloning Westy minus the dark candi sugar. Not bad but a little too sweet for my tastes.

Pours 98% off-white foam topped by specks of yeast, and 2% bubbling golden liquid (which starts clear but gradually becomes cloudy as one progresses through the bottle).  This rating ignores my early impressions, as the beer clearly needs to be served at a temperature of at least 55 degrees.  In both aroma and taste, this beer is orange/lemon sweet and tart, fairly spicy (predominantly ginger), and yeasty.  Fairly carbonated body, and the alcohol is masked quite well.
Blond beer with a big head. Citrusy and spicy aroma and taste. Sweet full start with a bitter sharp finish. The alcohol presence is strong but in no way disturbing. A very nice, tasty strong beer.

Wow, the cork just popped on this one after I took the cap off. She really must be mad. The head flowing out of it needed time to work down. After it calmed down, I was able to pour a cloudy gold beer with a nice bubbly white head that left some circular lace as it subsided. Some carbonation was present. There should've been, the way the cork exploded off. It had an aroma of citrus, clove and other spices. The flavor was of clove, a touch of anise with a slight smokiness and hint of the alcohol to it. The finish was a touch astrigent with elements of the smokiness. With the alcohol level present, this bitch could definately slap you silly.
This is a great ale.  Poured thick and foamy.  Flavor is spicy, bitter, and citrusy.  Finished dry, bitter, and alcohol warming.  Recommended.

UPDATED: JUN 30, 2005 What a fun beer!  Tart green apple, green banana, and fresh bread dough aroma.  Full foamy head with dull copper color.  Tart and tantalizing with apple, bready and yeasty flavors.  Dry, sharp finish.  Warming alcohol in the chest.  Immediately intoxicating and heady - somewhat fuselly, my head is swimming!  Otherwise quite nice, although a little hard to finish a whole 750 by yourself.  Final note: not overly foamy at all, didnt lose a drop - head was large but not over-sized.

First off, this beer is a damn ripoff because half of the expensive bottle will wind up down the drain as foam.  Believe everything you read about it.  Even the girl behind the counter told me this.  This is why this beer is getting a 1 for appearance from me.  On the other hand, it smells great, if you like the smell of baking bread.  As soon as I opened it, the whole room smelled of bread and people started asking about the beer.  But the flavor is just above average.  I never thought that one beer could rate a 10 for aroma and a 1 for appearance...  But I'll never buy this again, if I was in Belgium I would go to the brewery and get half of my money back.

I let this one sit in the sink and foam for awhile.  For all the carbonation involved (i was burbing like a mad man), it was a very smooth drink.  Sweet, citrus, yeasty, bitter at the finish.  This was very different - I liked it but some of it was hard to describe.  Stronger than I thought, too - the alc really snuck up on me.
Sweet honeydew aroma.Hazy blond appearance.Hides the alcohol well. Sweet yeasty flavor with hints of black pepper.Lingering herbal bitter finish.

Spicy, tripel-eaue aroma...flavor is spicy/grassy. Strong alcohol flavor present in the finish. Long, bitter aftertaste. The balance gets smoother as it warms, but overall the alcohol seems to overpower the present malt throughout.

FOAMER!!!!  I barely dented the cap and all hell broke loose from within the bottle.  20 minutes later after all had settled, I poured and then sipped.  Hmmm...sour and yeasty (just like the rest of De Dolle beers) but suprisingly not to my liking.  Maybe it was the foam orgy that had just taken place and caught me off gaurd, I dont know.  All I can tell is I probably will not be buying this again.

Vanilla and bananas in the nose. Attractive brew: hazy gold color and a huge foamy head. Citrusy, orangy tastes blended well with a strong yeast component. Rough and dirty palate - very assertive, but oh so good.

Golden to bronze in color with big, but diminishing, head.  The aroma is interesting, but not all that amazing or different.  The flavor, however, is perhaps the hardest to pin down that I have yet to encounter.  Sweet, spicy, a touch bitter, with citrus, tart and alcohol warm.  It got ten times better as it warmed.  Intriguing.
Big yeasty head.  Another wacky beer from De Dolle.  Make sure you let this one warm up a bit- it improves dramatically.  Lots of citrusy notes.  Reminds me a bit of Vuuve.

UPDATED: OCT 2, 2004 Yeasty but also sweet. Lemon comes through too. Orange body with a little head. brussels lace. (3.6).

Rerate: Apricot, orange peel nosem, meidum hazy orange color, fizzy carbonation. Yeast and banana taste. Not that convinced anymore.
Blond, slightly opaque with a superb foam. Aroma of lemon and yeast, quite aggressiv. Impression of freshness, nice acidity.
cloudy orange colour, nice head, orange and spicy aroma, citrusy, alcohol, some acidity, full-bodied, grape, long bitter fruity aftertaste

It has a beautiful golden colour, slightly cloudy with a long lasting head. It has an aroma of dried fruits (apricot, apple). It is slightly acidic. The aftertaste is fresh and slightly tart. Pleasant but lacking a little bit of character.

Huge lasting white head. Orange color, slightly cloudy. Aroma is citrusy, fruity and malty, with orange peel notes. Flavor is sweet, with honey tones, ending in a slightly spicy bitter finish. High ABV appears only at the end of tasting.
Medium bodied.

Orange color, with a lot of small yeast particles floating through. Thick lacing. Fruity aroma, also malty and yeasty alltogether. Really a taste-sensation. I like triples to be spicy actually, as the delirium tremens, guillotine and even the Hertog Jan triple. But this one, is really special. Very complex taste, so complex you do not notice the 10 % ABV. Long lingering palate, delicious palate! Excellent triple!

UPDATED: JAN 21, 2004 hazed orange with a gigantic head...musty citrus laced yeasty aroma with hints of orange soda and straw...yeasty flavors with notes of orange and aspirin..slightly bitter near the end.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2013 Bottle from Olbutikken (June 2013 bottling date). Head is initially huge, frothy, rocky, white, fully lasting. Body is hazy medium yellow, bottle conditioned. Aroma is moderately malty (toasted grain, caramel), moderately hoppy (herbs, flowers), moderately yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of candied pineapple, candy sugar, pepper, and alcohol. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately to heavily bitter. Medium to full body, velvety texture, lively carbonation, moderately alcoholic. Some batches are more like a tripel, some more just a sweet, strong golden...but this ones always tasty.

Um real good beer. Everything everybody else said, with the addition of a green grape flavour I caught will eating the head that wouldnt die. Hoppy the way I like. To much alcohol flavor at the back end though. But overall just swell.

Deep hazy golden color with an abundant creamy head.  Floral and alcohol aroma.  Decent lace.  Strong alcohol that subsides as it warms.  Nice pale malt character enbraced by a nice saaz bitterness. Touches of white pepper and coriander in the finish.  A very nice nightcap.
Typical of DeDolle, a stong, spicy, yeast flavor... and very active... open carefully!

Lovely strong spicy, citrus aroma.
My first tasting was overwhelming. Good massive, complex and spicy taste. Alcohol 10% is not in the taste and just slightly in the palate. I guess this is one of the best strong ales when it comes to hiding the alcohol. Fantastic!
This mad bitch really had me last night. 10°... wow (especially after a rochefort 10 and some lighter beer)

Hops, grapefruit and liquorice in the aroma. Strong hopbitter, herbal taste with some liquorice. Loads of hops and a slight tartness. Alcohol burn. Full bodied with some sweetness shining through the hops. A bit too hoppy, nevertheless a fine beer.
Good tripel, a little bit the same like Arabier. Honey, citrus, something bitter.
UPDATED: OCT 25, 2004 Muscular, dusty yeast, creamy barley and piney, Spalty hopsLeathery feel and vanilla enveloped orangesI long for a rocking chair

Faint hazy amber with huge rocky island lasting creamy head. My bottle did not appear to have anywhere near the amount of yeast flakes or lumps such as other raters have reported. I think that this beer has the fruitiest aroma of any of the beers I have rated so far - it reminds me a lot of Duvel. Aromas include passion fruit, pineapple and loads of peach, some bitter hops, spices and stale cured meat and old wine cork yeast . The body is beautiful, big and bold, the mouth fills quickly with a quick burst of all the aroma fruits plus spices, liquorice and coffee. Then the bitter and warming alcohol kick in quite nicely in the middle followed by a a long bitter finish stretching to a a yeasty dry after taste. At times this beer and all that alcohol seem some what raw - kinda like a work in progress but it is still very intruiguing and  one definitely worth trying. If you like Duvel and yeast you will probably like this one. In Belgium the 330cc bottle in Belgium costs  ~$1.40 - man is that good value!

Remember when you poured too much soap in the washer at the coin laundry? Pouring this beer is a real trial w. the head that will not stop and even after dying down it coats the glass like a milk shake. The appearance, other than the head is a nice orangey, very active cloudy brew. Flavor/aroma are reminiscent of the Duvel school of strong golden ales, very spicy w. a licorice/candy sugar accent. I still havent finished pouring and Im not so sure what Ill do w. the yeast and sediment. Maybe pour it in a slug trap in my back yard (gardeners know what Im talkin about).  Alcohol burn is way too prominent, but subsides as the beer warms. I love De Dolle and fans of Belgians should check out any De Dolle they can find.

750ml. Semi hazy straw/light peach. Tons of yeasty flakes swirling around. Massively thick, foamy and alive (looks like its moving) off white head. Monstrous big bubbled carbonation that causes an inversion of liquid and flakes. Spicy aroma, lemony hops, candied sugar, farmy aspects and cat pee. Lightly spritzy, spicy, lemony, musty with a huge rocket fuel-esque alcohol punch. Lightly tart and dryish with a juicy hop and alcohol ester mix. Although a bit much alcohol taste at times. Light to medium bodied. Nicely spiced altough some may find it overbearing. Dry and spicy aftertaste with loads of yeast notes and estery alcohol. Turns bone dry at mid bottle. Tremendous yeast pour further clouds this, and adds what looks like a pile of salmon eggs to the bottom of the glass. Adds some depth of body and a slight increase in tartness. Tries to mellow out the alcohol. Also adds a light flowery sweet thickness to the body as well. Finishes better balanced with all the wacky flavors going on. Very unique and very busy, like a super charged Saison.
Aptly called Mad Bitch beer as youd have to be mad to buy this a second time.
Good triple, typical beer of the Dolle Brouwers. Bitter in the beginning, sweeter later on.

Great Triple, but not my favourite.
Do not drink this beer too cold, i will try it once again.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2003 I have never been scared of a beer...until now. This thing is freakin' me out just looking at it. First off, it is the single most cloudy, unpasteurized beer I've ever seen. The huge amount of dregs I could barely make out through the thick green champagne bottle glass made me wonder if it had gone bad (I don't think so...), and were creepy enough, but the label (mine is a bit different than pictured) sealed the deal. I'm goin' to the devil. This brew piles everything in to such an extent it boggles the mind: the sheer volume of yeast makes it like a high school biology experiment gone awry, hop oil literally drips down the sides of the tulip glass and my tongue, it is mildy sweet with a strong lemony malt type of taste, mixed with orange rind. Bitter hop blasts throughout the tasting session come wave after wave. Bizarre, challenging, and probably the most nutritious beer I'll ever drink.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text:
UPDATED: NOV 26, 2003 Sampled draught at Akkurat, Stockholm.
Murky dark yellow, lively rich head. Grassy hops up front. Sweet and full bodied with soft, rounded mouthfeel. Pepper and tar strikes, and then gentle toffee takes over until the grassy bitter finsih. Rich and complex.
Old rating, bottled. Dark yellow. Sweetish smell. Light and lively mouthfeel. Sweet and very hop aromatic. Big biterness. Very tasty! (8/4/8/15/16)

The Mad Bitch here is a long breather. Ive given her about 15 minutes with a slight crack in the cap and it hissed and bubbled the whole time. The first pour was mostly all white foam and post-pour, the beer had to be re-capped and de-gassed slowly again over two minutes time. After the wait, the very lightly golden foam settles over a good looking, lightly cloudy radiant orange brew. The aroma is killer, its Wit Bieresque with slight hints of bandage or plastic and very pure alcohols. Oh man, this is nice. Very creamy -- silky smooth. Clear neroli and alcohol flavors, punches the gut with alcohol, semi-dry. I cant believe theres any more sugar in this after being bottled so long and having taken on so much CO2. Very tangy. The citrus flavors blend very well with the strong alcohol and heathery hop characteristics. At $11 per bottle, its a splurge but for me it was quite worth it.
Sweet abricot and citrus aroma. Dark amber coloured. Citrus, alcohol and malt sweetness is what you taste. It finishes a bit with an alcohol bitterness but also more citrus.

UPDATED: OCT 8, 2003 I have to say that this is some horribly done bottle art.  I'm pretty sure just about anyone could have managed better, including most children.  Anyway, this beer hides its 10% alcohol content well behind a mask of complex fruity, tart, bitter, yeasty, malty and fruity flavors.  Aroma is very estery, with the yeast and hops being dominant, and notes of pear, tangerine, white grape and melon.  Very nice, almost over-generous head and carbonation.  Peppery, spicy finish.  Hazy golden yellow color.  Quite an interesting beer.  This stuff just screams 'I'm Belgian!'

The name of this beer, according to the label, translates to Mad Bitch, and this is somewhat apt as the beer veers rather frantically from sweet  fruity notes to the strong punch of the Goldings.  Complex and hard to find.  Thanks, Jim!
Their interpretation of a strong golden I think?  So much of their truly unique house character.  Great
